April 23, 2020

NEWS EVENT

BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST; NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST; SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR; STEVE KORNACKI, NBC NEWS NATIONAL POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT; RICHARD ENGEL, NBC NEWS CHIEF FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT; DR. VIN GUPTA, MSNBC MEDICAL CONTRIBUTOR; DR. NAHID BHADELIA, MSNBC MEDICAL CONTRIBUTOR; STEPHANIE GOSK, NBC NEWS CORRESPONDENT; JACOB WARD, NBC NEWS TECHNOLOGY CORRESPONDENT; BILL GATES, BILL & MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION CO-CHAIR; MICHAEL OSTERHOLM, PHD, CENTER FOR DISEASE RESEARCH & POLICY DIRECTOR; MICHAEL BLOOMBERG, FORMER NEW YORK CITY MAYOR; DR. ANNE RIMOIN, UCLA SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSOR OF EPIDEMIOLOGY; GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY)

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ANNOUNCER: With the country largely locked down and economic turmoil growing, the debate to reopen intensifies.

BILL GATES, BILL & MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION CO-CHAIR: Things won't go back to truly normal until we have a vaccine that we've gotten out to the entire world.

ANNOUNCER: How is returning to work done safely without sparking a second wave of deaths?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We need to test anybody and everybody. Only then can we think about reopening the economy.

ANNOUNCER: Tonight, the critical demand for coronavirus testing.

GOV. LARRY HOGAN (R-MD): Every governor in America has been fighting to get tests since the beginning of this crisis.

ANNOUNCER: How much testing it will take to reopen the country?

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY): After you do the testing, states have a second big task put together an army of tracers who then trace each person tested positive.

ANNOUNCER: This is an MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST: Well, good evening. Brian Williams here with you, along with Nicolle Wallace.

And over the course of the next two hours, we're going to examine two very important steps to reopening our country -- coronavirus testing on a massive scale and contact tracing.

Right now, over 868,000 people have tested positive for coronavirus in our country with more than 49,000 souls gone. Today, we learned another 4.4 million Americans filed jobless claims last week, bringing the five-week total to more than 26 million people that we know of.

One key in returning people to work, getting back to normal is, of course, widespread testing. So, tonight, we're going to look at the importance of both diagnostic and antibody testing and hear about the number of tests that we need to safely reopen.

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: And, Brian, another important issue is contact tracing. We're going to be hearing a lot about this. It's the process of tracking down everyone who may have been exposed to the virus. We'll go through how it's conducted and why it's absolutely critical to stopping new infections.

Tonight, we'll be joined by three key people working hard to fight coronavirus. Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York, and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

We also have a full team of correspondents standing by with the latest reporting here in the U.S. and overseas, as well as the team of doctors.

WILLIAMS: Bill Gates sat down for an exclusive conversation with Savannah Guthrie earlier today to talk about where he thinks we are right now in this pandemic, the dangers of states reopening too quickly, a possible resurgence of the virus in the fall and winter, and his thoughts about a prediction he made back in 2015 in a TED Talk that a future pandemic was indeed coming.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR: You have made fighting infectious disease really your life's work -- at least the second half of your life. Just where we are right now in terms of this pandemic? That famous saying, are we at the end of the beginning or at the beginning of the end?

GATES: Well, I wish I could say that we're halfway through, but I don't think so. It takes time to make a vaccine. The social distancing that we've had to engage in has huge economic effects. It's very tough on people. There's a lot about the disease we don't understand.

So we know that we can get out of this, but it's going to be awhile before things go back to normal.

GUTHRIE: You talk a lot about not the new normal but the new semi-normal and what that might look like for us, the time before we get a vaccine but when we can start to return to some activity.

How do you envision that?

GATES: We're going to learn as we go, and the key thing is to have these tests where they have been prioritized and you're getting quick results. That will allow you to change the policies before you get back to filling up the hospitals and having a high death rate.

And so sadly, we can't promise people as we open up that we won't have to go back, that some locations or some activities will see that they're causing a spread and have to restrict those things even more. You know, I'm hopeful the high priority things like a lot of manufacturing, construction and even schools will fit into this but, you know, we're going to learn as we go and we need to watch.

GUTHRIE: Let's talk about what's happening right now. There are states like Georgia poised to reopen some parts of their economy and even nail salons they're talking about, tattoo parlors. Is there anywhere in the country that's ready for that kind of reopening?

GATES: Well, the intensity of the infection has varied a lot across the country, but we know that if you go fully back to normal mixing, that then you get on to that exponential growth curve. And so, it's a question of prioritization.

In Asia, they have been fairly slow to reopen. They require masks. They don't even have all the employees going in yet.

The good news is that they've largely avoided a rebound. The numbers and disease will tell us where to go on this. You know, I'm afraid we'll have some people and some states that move too quickly and have to back off.

GUTHRIE: We are a nation of states, and it's going to be a patch work response, it has to be because every state will do something differently or at least it seems as it's shaping up that way. How do you think that plays out?

GATES: So, the U.S. is kind of unusual that the federal level, you know, has said that testing is fine when in fact, for opening up, you know, we're at least a factor of three or four below where you would really catch things in a quick way. Some states will sadly give us the information about what -- what is too much and, you know, citizens will also very pretty widely in terms of some aren't going to come out and do much for a long time, whereas a few, you know, are like chomping at the bit or maybe aren't adhering to what the restrictions are.

You know, it's too bad that -- to have it be a political thing. Adherence, you know, ideally would be widespread that we understand that you can infect other people. So, it's not just your individual choices but you're affecting all of society in how you behave.

GUTHRIE: And as you well know and understand, the issue is, is that there is a very severe economic price to be paid for these public health measures that are so important, and that's the balance that's trying to be struck here. Some people are going to look and say, did we overreact? And others will look at it and say, perhaps we underreacted.

Where do you come down on that?

GATES: Well, certainly, everybody looking back wishes they had reacted faster. If you catch this at a very low level like a few countries did, you know, because you got community testing and contact tracing, then you don't have to do the shutdown. You know, beyond that, you know, everybody hopes that the cause they believed in before this happened somehow it fits in. So, you know, I think the speculation is great. I think it will be a lot of change. I hope it's more about the world working together to solve big, big problems.

GUTHRIE: Yes, you've likened this fight against the coronavirus to a world war except for this time we're all on the same side. We're all fighting the same thing, this virus. How hopeful are you about ingenuity? You know, we saw innovation after World War II, incredible leaps in technology. Is this that kind of opportunity as well?

GATES: Well, I definitely think in terms of some of the health approaches, you know, making vaccines cheap and quickly, coming up with new classes of drugs that can address these things, the speed with which diagnostics can get out and, you know, sharing what you're seeing through symptoms on the cellphone internet basis. There's going to be some amazing innovation, and that will make us less vulnerable.

GUTHRIE: Well, that's a hopeful note to end on, but I also have to ask you, you're home as well. I know you're working on behalf of the Gates Foundation, so your self-isolation is not equal to ours. I guess you're not watching "Tiger King" on Netflix or eating too much. But, what are you doing with the extra time you may find yourself with these days?

GATES: Well, my daughter did get me to watch "Tiger King", you know, at night, a little distraction is allowed even though it's a busy time. You know, thank goodness the internet both brings us information and brings us entertainment and lets us do these meetings online. You know, online schooling, some place is good, not good. But, you know, we're, you know, crammed into less space, but there's some virtues to that in terms of, you know, being together as we deal with something that is, you know, shocking and completely unexpected.

GUTHRIE: Bill Gates, thank you so much for your time. We really appreciate it.

GATES: Thank you.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: Nicolle, think of it. At a time when income inequality has been right there, a front-burner issue in our country, and we're watching the effects of it as so many people get crushed.

We have featured tonight in a two-hour special two billionaires. What do they have in common? They made their money in tech. They are giving the money they made in their adult business lives away, and they are heavily involved in this fight. We have also learned that when this is over, what we're going to have in common is a used face mask and we all will have seen "Tiger King".

WALLACE: I had nightmares about the snakes in the mailbox after one episode. But I have to say those two that we featured are doing a lot. They're going to have to do more. I mean, this is going to be a brutal, brutal, brutal economic -- period of economic despair, to be blunt, for --

WILLIAMS: Oh yes.

WALLACE: -- people all over the world, not just in this country. And so I applaud their efforts. Everyone, everyone, we -- it is going to be a brutal reality. The things that we have to do to protect our communities and protect our loved ones are going to have really, really devastating economic impacts. They're going to lead to economic insecurity, and we have to address that with the same sort of fervor, the same sort of moonshot marshal plan that we address the pandemic. And I'm sure that we'll rise or I hope that we'll rise to that occasion as well.

Still ahead for us, experts agree that until there's a vaccine, testing, testing, testing, testing is our very best way to get a handle on the pandemic. Is the U.S. doing as much testing as it needs to, and do states have the materials and the capability to administer those tests? NBC's Stephanie Gosk will join us with the breakdown. And NBC technology correspondent Jacob Ward will join us on the Google-Apple partnership hoping to mobilize your mobile phone to stop the spread of the virus. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIAMS: As we've established, as you're hearing day and night, across the country, there's this urgent need for testing and contact tracing on a massive scale. And so our reporting team has the latest on the race to contain this virus.

NBC News technology correspondent Jacob Ward reports that contact tracing apps could soon help track the spread of this in this country. But first, NBC News correspondent Stephanie Gosk has our report on testing and the road to reopening.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

STEPHANIE GOSK, NBC NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The battle in the fight against COVID boils down to one thing, testing.

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO, (D) NEW YORK: No one ever imagined this testing system was going to become hyper relevant to survival.

GOSK: A new study in Los Angeles indicates the number of people that have or had COVID-19 may be up to 55 times higher than previously known. Public health experts say it is not something states can handle alone.

DR. DAN HANFLING, CO-CHAIR, NATIONAL ACADEMY OF MEDICINE,

MEDICAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH PREPAREDNESS: To ask the states to go about finding their own solutions is a recipe for disaster.

GOSK: Dr. Dan Hanfling has worked on national preparedness planning programs for presidents Obama and Trump. He says the Trump administration's guidelines don't go far enough.

HANFLING: It misses the mark widely because we don't have the means for either testing or contact tracing. Both critically important if we are to understand prevalence of disease. It's a fantasy to think that we're going to be able to reopen safely in the absence of those capabilities.

GOSK: Right now, a million people are being tested a week, a number experts say needs to triple. Vice Admiral Raquel Bono oversees Washington State's response to COVID-19. She says state labs could be processing more than twice the number of tests but lack critical supplies.

RET. VICE ADMIRAL RAQUEL BONO, DIRECTOR, WASHINGTON STATE

COVID-19 HEALTH SYSTEM RESPONSE MANAGEMENT: It's swabs and transport medium as well as reagent. The person who is using the swab and taking the sample also has to be in PPE.

GOSK: And each state is competing for these supplies.

BONO: We're all pitted against each other trying to get the supplies that we know we need.

GOSK: Another obstacle, test accuracy, health officials tell NBC News they're seeing inaccurate diagnostic and antibody tests, showing false positives or false negatives.

BONO: It is less accurate than we had hoped, and so there was a whole lot of false positives. It points out to the importance of being able to accurately and rigorously develop these tests so that we don't inadvertently put people at harm.

GOSK: Without testing on a massive scale, we lack a clear picture of when stay-at-home orders can be lifted. But a recent report by 48 economists and social scientists suggests it can be done quickly. Dr. Danielle Allen of Harvard University is the lead author.

DANIELLE ALLEN, HARVARD UNIVESITY PROFESSOR: The best approach for economic recovery is one where we get to open and stay open. The way you open and stay open is by having the capacity to control the disease.

GOSK: Controlling the disease, she says, will require 5 million tests a day in order to start lifting restrictions in June, ramping up to 20 million tests a day by August.

But the key to getting there is national coordination. She suggests the federal government create a pandemic testing board to supervise testing, contact tracing, and supply chain issues.

How important is that centralized effort to having success in testing?

ALLEN: You really do need that centralized coordination in order to move things faster than the market itself could achieve.

GOSK: The argument among those who want to open up quickly is that we are going to have such dramatic economic costs in this country that it is -- the pain is not going to be worth it.

ALLEN: The argument we make with them is that the path we're proposing gives you a stronger recovery.

GOSK: That plan estimates national testing, tracing and isolation would cost $15 billion a month compared to the cost of stay-at-home orders, $350 billion a month. And if no action is taken and restrictions lifted, there would be a sharp increase in deaths costing $15 to $20 trillion. The researchers say economic growth and testing go hand in hand.

ALLEN: This is a moment for (INAUDIBLE) America to show up. We can do this. Again, no law of physics has to be broken. It is purely a question of organizing ourselves to deliver on the capacity that we already have.

GOSK: Stephanie Gosk, NBC News.

JACOB WARD, NBC NEWS TECHNOLOGY CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): I'm Jake Ward in San Francisco. If we're going to reopen America, experts say we need a way to keep track of who is infected, who is not and where their paths have crossed. But we don't have enough investigators to follow each other around. A human researcher can track down the past contacts of maybe two people a day. But for the first time, we're talking about contact tracing hundreds of thousands of people.

DR. ART REINGOLD, EPIDEMIOLOGIST, UC BERKELEY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC

HEALTH: Contact tracing is more than just were you in touch with Mr. Jones? Were you in 10 feet of proximity of Mrs. Smith? Technology could help with the process in a number of ways.

WARD: Scale is where technology can really help. Nearly all of the phones here in the United States run either Google or Apple operating systems. That's why a Google-Apple contact tracing app due out in May is such a big deal. You want to know if you've been exposed to someone who tested positive for COVID? Maybe those phones can tell you.

(on camera): Let's say I go running in my neighborhood and I pass a couple of people pretty closely. Well, their phone and my phone would be registered together as part of a contact history, and then if any of them were to test positive for COVID-19, well, I might be notified that I should probably be quarantined for two weeks.

(voice-over): The companies say you can choose whether to opt in. It'll use Bluetooth to detect other phones rather than the GPS data that countries like China have been using. And your information won't leave your phone unless you agree to share it. Oxford University researchers say 56 percent of the population has to use such an app for it to be effective.

The idea is that it's all up to you. You decide if you want to report your test results. And if you were near someone who tested positive, the app will only offer advice on what to do. But health data is extremely personal data, and even if it's kept secure, let's imagine a world where a single notification from your phone changes your life.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To what extent are there follow-on limitations to my liberty or to my economic prosperity that comes from being tagged in this way?

WARD: The huge reach of these companies makes them the fastest way to monitor the nation. The question is, are we prepared for a world in which a computer program tells you whether you should stay home from work for the public good? Jake Ward, NBC News, San Francisco.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: So, Nicolle, the smart reporting also knows to leave us with a little hope, and these are hopeful nuggets amid a death toll you and I have just watched grow staggeringly high.

WALLACE: Yes, and it's the theme we keep coming back to, American ingenuity, everyone doing their part. I think that, you know, when you watch that reporting about technology, there's just a piece of me that worries that so many people will be distrustful because of the battering that our institutions have taken over the last decade of sort of American public life. So hope springs eternal. I guess we all order things on Amazon, or most of us do.

So there's that.

WILLIAMS: Yes.

WALLACE: There's still more to come though from us when our MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening" continues. Don't go anywhere.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. NAJY MASRI, LSU DIRECTOR, HOSPITALIST SERVICES, OCHSNER

MEDICAL CENTER: We need more testing. We need expedited testing. We need to identify all of those individuals out there who are infected so we can get them to quarantine and self-isolate. And we need validation on that testing. We need to be able to trust a negative so that if we tell someone that they have a negative COVID test, we are comfortable that they are not infectious, that it's a true negative and they can return to society and whatever the new normal is going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Dr. Najy Masri in a city I love, New Orleans, Louisiana, pleading for validated tests. They passed a sad rubicund there today. The Governor John Bel Edwards announced that more people in his state have now died of coronavirus than died in Hurricane Katrina. Governor Edwards also said he hopes to start phase one of reopening Louisiana early on in the state of May. Nicolle?

WALLACE: It's one thing that every single person in this country seems to agree on that more and better tests, more readily available tests, more user-friendly tests would help this country, would go a long way. The truth is right now as we sit here, Brian, we have a president who thinks the testing is just great, that it's perfect.

WILLIAMS: Yes, that's a problem. I -- it all goes back to Crimson Tide for me. Even though Denzel was -- Gene Hackman was mean to Denzel, but that's a subject for another time. Gene Hackman as captain of the submarine decided to hold a missile drill during a kitchen fire. He said that's the best time to hold a missile drill. We're having a kitchen fire that could consume the house. I worry about the missile drill. I worry, God forbid, about anything worse, and we have to all hope that the election is secured coming up in November.

For us, for now, these are all topics for another time. That's going to do it for our two hours coverage.

WALLACE: Thanks for joining us tonight. "The Rachel Maddow Show" starts right now.

END

MSNBC SPECIAL REPORT: TESTING & THE ROAD TO REOPENING

APRIL 23, 2020

SPEAKERS: BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR

STEVE KORNACKI, NBC NEWS NATIONAL POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT

RICHARD ENGEL, NBC NEWS CHIEF FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT

DR. VIN GUPTA, MSNBC MEDICAL CONTRIBUTOR

DR. NAHID BHADELIA, MSNBC MEDICAL CONTRIBUTOR

STEPHANIE GOSK, NBC NEWS CORRESPONDENT

JACOB WARD, NBC NEWS TECHNOLOGY CORRESPONDENT

BILL GATES, BILL & MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION CO-CHAIR

MICHAEL OSTERHOLM, PHD, CENTER FOR DISEASE RESEARCH & POLICY DIRECTOR

MICHAEL BLOOMBERG, FORMER NEW YORK CITY MAYOR

DR. ANNE RIMOIN, UCLA SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSOR OF EPIDEMIOLOGY

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY)

[*] (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ANNOUNCER: With the country largely locked down and economic turmoil growing, the debate to reopen intensifies.

BILL GATES, BILL & MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION CO-CHAIR: Things won't go back to truly normal until we have a vaccine that we've gotten out to the entire world.

ANNOUNCER: How is returning to work done safely without sparking a second wave of deaths?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We need to test anybody and everybody. Only then can we think about reopening the economy.

ANNOUNCER: Tonight, the critical demand for coronavirus testing.

GOV. LARRY HOGAN (R-MD): Every governor in America has been fighting to get tests since the beginning of this crisis.

ANNOUNCER: How much testing it will take to reopen the country?

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY): After you do the testing, states have a second big task put together an army of tracers who then trace each person tested positive.

ANNOUNCER: This is an MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST: Well, good evening. Brian Williams here with you, along with Nicolle Wallace.

And over the course of the next two hours, we're going to examine two very important steps to reopening our country -- coronavirus testing on a massive scale and contact tracing.

Right now, over 868,000 people have tested positive for coronavirus in our country with more than 49,000 souls gone. Today, we learned another 4.4 million Americans filed jobless claims last week, bringing the five-week total to more than 26 million people that we know of.

One key in returning people to work, getting back to normal is, of course, widespread testing. So, tonight, we're going to look at the importance of both diagnostic and antibody testing and hear about the number of tests that we need to safely reopen.

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: And, Brian, another important issue is contact tracing. We're going to be hearing a lot about this. It's the process of tracking down everyone who may have been exposed to the virus. We'll go through how it's conducted and why it's absolutely critical to stopping new infections.

Tonight, we'll be joined by three key people working hard to fight coronavirus. Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York, and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

We also have a full team of correspondents standing by with the latest reporting here in the U.S. and overseas, as well as the team of doctors.

WILLIAMS: Bill Gates sat down for an exclusive conversation with Savannah Guthrie earlier today to talk about where he thinks we are right now in this pandemic, the dangers of states reopening too quickly, a possible resurgence of the virus in the fall and winter, and his thoughts about a prediction he made back in 2015 in a TED Talk that a future pandemic was indeed coming.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR: You have made fighting infectious disease really your life's work -- at least the second half of your life. Just where we are right now in terms of this pandemic? That famous saying, are we at the end of the beginning or at the beginning of the end?

GATES: Well, I wish I could say that we're halfway through, but I don't think so. It takes time to make a vaccine. The social distancing that we've had to engage in has huge economic effects. It's very tough on people. There's a lot about the disease we don't understand.

So we know that we can get out of this, but it's going to be awhile before things go back to normal.

GUTHRIE: You talk a lot about not the new normal but the new semi-normal and what that might look like for us, the time before we get a vaccine but when we can start to return to some activity.

How do you envision that?

GATES: We're going to learn as we go, and the key thing is to have these tests where they have been prioritized and you're getting quick results. That will allow you to change the policies before you get back to filling up the hospitals and having a high death rate.

And so sadly, we can't promise people as we open up that we won't have to go back, that some locations or some activities will see that they're causing a spread and have to restrict those things even more. You know, I'm hopeful the high priority things like a lot of manufacturing, construction and even schools will fit into this but, you know, we're going to learn as we go and we need to watch.

GUTHRIE: Let's talk about what's happening right now. There are states like Georgia poised to reopen some parts of their economy and even nail salons they're talking about, tattoo parlors. Is there anywhere in the country that's ready for that kind of reopening?

GATES: Well, the intensity of the infection has varied a lot across the country, but we know that if you go fully back to normal mixing, that then you get on to that exponential growth curve. And so, it's a question of prioritization.

In Asia, they have been fairly slow to reopen. They require masks. They don't even have all the employees going in yet.

The good news is that they've largely avoided a rebound. The numbers and disease will tell us where to go on this. You know, I'm afraid we'll have some people and some states that move too quickly and have to back off.

GUTHRIE: We are a nation of states, and it's going to be a patch work response, it has to be because every state will do something differently or at least it seems as it's shaping up that way. How do you think that plays out?

GATES: So, the U.S. is kind of unusual that the federal level, you know, has said that testing is fine when in fact, for opening up, you know, we're at least a factor of three or four below where you would really catch things in a quick way. Some states will sadly give us the information about what -- what is too much and, you know, citizens will also very pretty widely in terms of some aren't going to come out and do much for a long time, whereas a few, you know, are like chomping at the bit or maybe aren't adhering to what the restrictions are.

You know, it's too bad that -- to have it be a political thing. Adherence, you know, ideally would be widespread that we understand that you can infect other people. So, it's not just your individual choices but you're affecting all of society in how you behave.

GUTHRIE: And as you well know and understand, the issue is, is that there is a very severe economic price to be paid for these public health measures that are so important, and that's the balance that's trying to be struck here. Some people are going to look and say, did we overreact? And others will look at it and say, perhaps we underreacted.

Where do you come down on that?

GATES: Well, certainly, everybody looking back wishes they had reacted faster. If you catch this at a very low level like a few countries did, you know, because you got community testing and contact tracing, then you don't have to do the shutdown. As people see the infection rates, as they see the stories about the emergency rooms, you know, they weren't going to be traveling to theme parks or, you know, going to sports stadiums.

And so, it's a false choice to say it's the government who is solely responsible for this economic activity going down. People, you know, fear getting sick themselves or infecting their parents and so we just didn't have a choice.

GUTHRIE: You famously talked about a coming pandemic at this nightmare scenario back in 2015 on the heels of the Ebola crisis and you said in your TED Talk that you worried about a virus that could be 1,000 times worse. Is this that virus?

GATES: Yes. The human to human respiratory spread is the scariest scenario and I showed a simulation in that 2015 talk that, you know, showed you could have tens of millions of deaths and trillions of economic costs. So, this did. It's a respiratory virus that is causing that damage. And so, it's a nightmare.

You know, I wish it had come, you know, five or ten years later than governments might have done the preparation to move quickly like a few governments did and the technologies would have been further along.

GUTHRIE: I went back and looked at the numbers. On March 1st, we had had two deaths in this country. Thirty days later on April 1st, we had 4,800 deaths. Today, as we sit here, not even 30 days later, we have 47,000 deaths.

Can you just talk about that exponential growth and exponential decline?

GATES: Yes, so if I'm infecting two other people for every active infection, you know, then over the course of the month, you can go from a small part of the population to a very large part, and so clearly, in March, the infections were exponential and then you have about an 18-day leg between infections and deaths.

And so, April, exactly as you said, we've had huge numbers of deaths. If we maintain the isolation, the deaths out in the summer would be very, very small. Very quickly, it can go from barely detectable to huge and, you know, I think people will be shocked that in some locations, the ICU will hardly have anyone in it at all within the next few months.

GUTHRIE: I read that you said that we are nearing the peak in this country, hopefully. And then you've also said we're really not anywhere near the end of this, and I can't be alone in thinking, well, how does that work out? How can we be almost at the peak but yet so far away from a solution and an end to this and a return to normal?

GATES: Well, the vaccine is the most likely solution, and so, great scientists are rushing to get that done. And actually, I've been surprised how quickly they're moving. There is a number that have even begun that human testing that's key there.

And so, it could be that in a year, we have lots of a vaccine and then once you get it out to lots of people, then you -- you're -- you have enough community immunity that you won't see this widespread problem again.

You know, we have this first peak in the U.S. With the right policies, we'll have small, some areas that go back and have infections, but we shouldn't see countrywide anything like this but a -- you know, miracle therapeutic or the vaccine are the only thing that we'll be able to say, OK, we're back to normal.

GUTHRIE: I do want to ask you about the second wave, this notion that the virus could come back in the fall. We heard the CDC director saying it could be even potentially more difficult in the fall and winter because the seasonal flu will also be going on.

Dr. Fauci said he's certain there will be a second wave of this virus.

What's your perspective on how bad it could be?

GATES: Well, if we're -- if we're still being careful about social contact, if we're wearing masks, if we're doing distancing where possible, if we got the testing capacity up, I'm hopeful that the fall will not be nearly as bad as this first peak. The flu is a challenge because the symptoms are common enough that knowing exactly who to test, you know, which are people with symptoms, will be a little confused because of all those flu infections that will be taking place.

But the vigilance of not getting too relaxed when you're seeing pictures of empty ICUs, that's not intuitive because you could get back on that ramp.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: Part of Bill Gates' conversation with Savannah Guthrie.

Here is a billionaire willing to spend his own money and a billionaire who spends his time thinking about this.

WALLACE: Yes.

WILLIAMS: And when Savannah asks him is this that virus, he calmly answers yes.

WALLACE: Yes, to hear him use the words nightmare scenario, I was watching it and thinking about just how long Bill Gates has been a giant in the public health arena. He was talking about the sorts of things people were afraid of when I was in government.

I mean, it's been reported by "The New York Times" this week that George W. Bush became obsessed with pandemics and had all of us reading some of the same books that I know Bill Gates talked about in that TED Talk, and that this was the nightmare scenario the last three presidents were scared of. That President Obama had a team that handed this team a plan to deal with something like this. George W. Bush had done some work on that plan, too, and to hear Bill Gates talk about that brings back all that muscle memory that you just don't see in this more sort of chaotic administration on full display.

But there were a lot of other science headlines in there and lucky for us, we're able to get reaction from Dr. Michael Osterholm. He's the director of the Center for Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota and the author of "Deadliest Enemy: Our War Against Killer Germs."

I saw you earlier today on this network and there were so many practical pieces to what Bill Gates was saying about we don't get to normal until there are some really powerful therapies or a vaccine.

How far off is that?

MICHAEL OSTERHOLM, PHD, CENTER FOR DISEASE RESEARCH & POLICY DIRECTOR: Well, we don't know right now if we're going to have a vaccine. I just have to be very honest with you.

WALLACE: Yes.

OSTERHOLM: We hope we will have one, but hope is not a strategy.

Drugs will be very important in reducing the severity of illness and hope for preventing deaths, but it won't stop the transmission. People are infectious in the earliest stages of their illness even before in some cases they get sick, so the drug would come after that.

So, the epidemiology or meaning, occurrence of cases will continue to occur. And I think one of the things that's being missed here is that when we talk about, are we going to have the curve flatten, what's going to come back? Look at it this way, as we know in this country between 5 and maybe 10 percent of the population has been infected even in the metropolitan areas. You heard in New York today, it maybe 14 percent.

DANIELLE ALLEN, HARVARD UNIVESITY PROFESSOR: The best approach for economic recovery is one where we get to open and stay open. The way you open and stay open is by having the capacity to control the disease.

GOSK: Controlling the disease, she says, will require 5 million tests a day in order to start lifting restrictions in June, ramping up to 20 million tests a day by August.

But the key to getting there is national coordination. She suggests the federal government create a pandemic testing board to supervise testing, contact tracing, and supply chain issues.

How important is that centralized effort to having success in testing?

ALLEN: You really do need that centralized coordination in order to move things faster than the market itself could achieve.

GOSK: The argument among those who want to open up quickly is that we are going to have such dramatic economic costs in this country that it is -- the pain is not going to be worth it.

ALLEN: The argument we make with them is that the path we're proposing gives you a stronger recovery.

GOSK: That plan estimates national testing, tracing and isolation would cost $15 billion a month compared to the cost of stay-at-home orders, $350 billion a month. And if no action is taken and restrictions lifted, there would be a sharp increase in deaths costing $15 to $20 trillion. The researchers say economic growth and testing go hand in hand.

ALLEN: This is a moment for (INAUDIBLE) America to show up. We can do this. Again, no law of physics has to be broken. It is purely a question of organizing ourselves to deliver on the capacity that we already have.

GOSK: Stephanie Gosk, NBC News.

JACOB WARD, NBC NEWS TECHNOLOGY CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): I'm Jake Ward in San Francisco. If we're going to reopen America, experts say we need a way to keep track of who is infected, who is not and where their paths have crossed. But we don't have enough investigators to follow each other around. A human researcher can track down the past contacts of maybe two people a day. But for the first time, we're talking about contact tracing hundreds of thousands of people.

DR. ART REINGOLD, EPIDEMIOLOGIST, UC BERKELEY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH: Contact tracing is more than just were you in touch with Mr. Jones? Were you in 10 feet of proximity of Mrs. Smith? Technology could help with the process in a number of ways.

WARD: Scale is where technology can really help. Nearly all of the phones here in the United States run either Google or Apple operating systems. That's why a Google-Apple contact tracing app due out in May is such a big deal. You want to know if you've been exposed to someone who tested positive for COVID? Maybe those phones can tell you.

(on camera): Let's say I go running in my neighborhood and I pass a couple of people pretty closely. Well, their phone and my phone would be registered together as part of a contact history, and then if any of them were to test positive for COVID-19, well, I might be notified that I should probably be quarantined for two weeks.

(voice-over): The companies say you can choose whether to opt in. It'll use Bluetooth to detect other phones rather than the GPS data that countries like China have been using. And your information won't leave your phone unless you agree to share it. Oxford University researchers say 56 percent of the population has to use such an app for it to be effective.

The idea is that it's all up to you. You decide if you want to report your test results. And if you were near someone who tested positive, the app will only offer advice on what to do. But health data is extremely personal data, and even if it's kept secure, let's imagine a world where a single notification from your phone changes your life.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To what extent are there follow-on limitations to my liberty or to my economic prosperity that comes from being tagged in this way?

WARD: The huge reach of these companies makes them the fastest way to monitor the nation. The question is, are we prepared for a world in which a computer program tells you whether you should stay home from work for the public good? Jake Ward, NBC News, San Francisco.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: So, Nicolle, the smart reporting also knows to leave us with a little hope, and these are hopeful nuggets amid a death toll you and I have just watched grow staggeringly high.

WALLACE: Yes, and it's the theme we keep coming back to, American ingenuity, everyone doing their part. I think that, you know, when you watch that reporting about technology, there's just a piece of me that worries that so many people will be distrustful because of the battering that our institutions have taken over the last decade of sort of American public life. So hope springs eternal. I guess we all order things on Amazon, or most of us do.

So there's that.

WILLIAMS: Yes.

WALLACE: There's still more to come though from us when our MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening" continues. Don't go anywhere.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. NAJY MASRI, LSU DIRECTOR, HOSPITALIST SERVICES, OCHSNER MEDICAL CENTER: We need more testing. We need expedited testing. We need to identify all of those individuals out there who are infected so we can get them to quarantine and self-isolate. And we need validation on that testing. We need to be able to trust a negative so that if we tell someone that they have a negative COVID test, we are comfortable that they are not infectious, that it's a true negative and they can return to society and whatever the new normal is going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Dr. Najy Masri in a city I love, New Orleans, Louisiana, pleading for validated tests. They passed a sad rubicund there today. The Governor John Bel Edwards announced that more people in his state have now died of coronavirus than died in Hurricane Katrina. Governor Edwards also said he hopes to start phase one of reopening Louisiana early on in the state of May. Nicolle?

WALLACE: It's one thing that every single person in this country seems to agree on that more and better tests, more readily available tests, more user-friendly tests would help this country, would go a long way. The truth is right now as we sit here, Brian, we have a president who thinks the testing is just great, that it's perfect.

WILLIAMS: Yes, that's a problem. I -- it all goes back to Crimson Tide for me. Even though Denzel was -- Gene Hackman was mean to Denzel, but that's a subject for another time. Gene Hackman as captain of the submarine decided to hold a missile drill during a kitchen fire. He said that's the best time to hold a missile drill. We're having a kitchen fire that could consume the house. I worry about the missile drill. I worry, God forbid, about anything worse, and we have to all hope that the election is secured coming up in November.

For us, for now, these are all topics for another time. That's going to do it for our two hours coverage.

WALLACE: Thanks for joining us tonight. "The Rachel Maddow Show" starts right now.

END

urn:contentItem:5YRK-PC61-DXH2-64R4-00000-00MSNBC Special Report: Testing & The Road to Reopening for April 23, 20202020-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMSNBC LIVE9:00 AM ESTBill Gates, Michael Osterholm, Michael Bloomberg, Anne Rimoin, Andrew Cuomo, Vin GuptaNEWSDomestic042301cb.462MSNBC Special Report: Testing & The Road to Reopening for April 23, 2020Brian Williams, Nicolle Wallace, Savannah Guthrie, Steve Kornacki, Richard Engel, Vin Gupta, Nahid Bhadelia, Stephanie Gosk, Jacob Ward

An MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening.".

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ANNOUNCER: With the country largely locked down and economic turmoil growing, the debate to reopen intensifies.

BILL GATES, BILL & MELINDA GATES FOUNDATION CO-CHAIR: Things won`t go back to truly normal until we have a vaccine that we`ve gotten out to the entire world.

ANNOUNCER: How is returning to work done safely without sparking a second wave of deaths?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We need to test anybody and everybody. Only then can we think about reopening the economy.

ANNOUNCER: Tonight, the critical demand for coronavirus testing.

GOV. LARRY HOGAN (R-MD): Every governor in America has been fighting to get tests since the beginning of this crisis.

ANNOUNCER: How much testing it will take to reopen the country?

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY): After you do the testing, states have a second big task put together an army of tracers who then trace each person tested positive.

ANNOUNCER: This is an MSNBC special report "Testing and the Road to Reopening."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST: Well, good evening. Brian Williams here with you, along with Nicolle Wallace.

And over the course of the next two hours, we`re going to examine two very important steps to reopening our country -- coronavirus testing on a massive scale and contact tracing.

Right now, over 868,000 people have tested positive for coronavirus in our country with more than 49,000 souls gone. Today, we learned another 4.4 million Americans filed jobless claims last week, bringing the five-week total to more than 26 million people that we know of.

One key in returning people to work, getting back to normal is, of course, widespread testing. So, tonight, we`re going to look at the importance of both diagnostic and antibody testing and hear about the number of tests that we need to safely reopen.

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: And, Brian, another important issue is contact tracing. We`re going to be hearing a lot about this. It`s the process of tracking down everyone who may have been exposed to the virus. We`ll go through how it`s conducted and why it`s absolutely critical to stopping new infections.

Tonight, we`ll be joined by three key people working hard to fight coronavirus. Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York, and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

We also have a full team of correspondents standing by with the latest reporting here in the U.S. and overseas, as well as the team of doctors.

WILLIAMS: Bill Gates sat down for an exclusive conversation with Savannah Guthrie earlier today to talk about where he thinks we are right now in this pandemic, the dangers of states reopening too quickly, a possible resurgence of the virus in the fall and winter, and his thoughts about a prediction he made back in 2015 in a TED Talk that a future pandemic was indeed coming.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR: You have made fighting infectious disease really your life`s work -- at least the second half of your life. Just where we are right now in terms of this pandemic? That famous saying, are we at the end of the beginning or at the beginning of the end?

GATES: Well, I wish I could say that we`re halfway through, but I don`t think so. It takes time to make a vaccine. The social distancing that we`ve had to engage in has huge economic effects. It`s very tough on people. There`s a lot about the disease we don`t understand.

So we know that we can get out of this, but it`s going to be awhile before things go back to normal.

GUTHRIE: You talk a lot about not the new normal but the new semi-normal and what that might look like for us, the time before we get a vaccine but when we can start to return to some activity.

How do you envision that?

GATES: We`re going to learn as we go, and the key thing is to have these tests where they have been prioritized and you`re getting quick results. That will allow you to change the policies before you get back to filling up the hospitals and having a high death rate.

And so sadly, we can`t promise people as we open up that we won`t have to go back, that some locations or some activities will see that they`re causing a spread and have to restrict those things even more. You know, I`m hopeful the high priority things like a lot of manufacturing, construction and even schools will fit into this but, you know, we`re going to learn as we go and we need to watch.

GUTHRIE: Let`s talk about what`s happening right now. There are states like Georgia poised to reopen some parts of their economy and even nail salons they`re talking about, tattoo parlors. Is there anywhere in the country that`s ready for that kind of reopening?

GATES: Well, the intensity of the infection has varied a lot across the country, but we know that if you go fully back to normal mixing, that then you get on to that exponential growth curve. And so, it`s a question of prioritization.

In Asia, they have been fairly slow to reopen. They require masks. They don`t even have all the employees going in yet.

The good news is that they`ve largely avoided a rebound. The numbers and disease will tell us where to go on this. You know, I`m afraid we`ll have some people and some states that move too quickly and have to back off.

GUTHRIE: We are a nation of states, and it`s going to be a patch work response, it has to be because every state will do something differently or at least it seems as it`s shaping up that way. How do you think that plays out?

GATES: So, the U.S. is kind of unusual that the federal level, you know, has said that testing is fine when in fact, for opening up, you know, we`re at least a factor of three or four below where you would really catch things in a quick way. Some states will sadly give us the information about what -- what is too much and, you know, citizens will also very pretty widely in terms of some aren`t going to come out and do much for a long time, whereas a few, you know, are like chomping at the bit or maybe aren`t adhering to what the restrictions are.

You know, it`s too bad that -- to have it be a political thing. Adherence, you know, ideally would be widespread that we understand that you can infect other people. So, it`s not just your individual choices but you`re affecting all of society in how you behave.

GUTHRIE: And as you well know and understand, the issue is, is that there is a very severe economic price to be paid for these public health measures that are so important, and that`s the balance that`s trying to be struck here. Some people are going to look and say, did we overreact? And others will look at it and say, perhaps we underreacted.

Where do you come down on that?

GATES: Well, certainly, everybody looking back wishes they had reacted faster. If you catch this at a very low level like a few countries did, you know, because you got community testing and contact tracing, then you don`t have to do the shutdown. As people see the infection rates, as they see the stories about the emergency rooms, you know, they weren`t going to be traveling to theme parks or, you know, going to sports stadiums.

And so, it`s a false choice to say it`s the government who is solely responsible for this economic activity going down. People, you know, fear getting sick themselves or infecting their parents and so we just didn`t have a choice.

GUTHRIE: You famously talked about a coming pandemic at this nightmare scenario back in 2015 on the heels of the Ebola crisis and you said in your TED Talk that you worried about a virus that could be 1,000 times worse. Is this that virus?

GATES: Yes. The human to human respiratory spread is the scariest scenario and I showed a simulation in that 2015 talk that, you know, showed you could have tens of millions of deaths and trillions of economic costs. So, this did. It`s a respiratory virus that is causing that damage. And so, it`s a nightmare.

You know, I wish it had come, you know, five or ten years later than governments might have done the preparation to move quickly like a few governments did and the technologies would have been further along.

GUTHRIE: I went back and looked at the numbers. On March 1st, we had had two deaths in this country. Thirty days later on April 1st, we had 4,800 deaths. Today, as we sit here, not even 30 days later, we have 47,000 deaths.

Can you just talk about that exponential growth and exponential decline?

GATES: Yes, so if I`m infecting two other people for every active infection, you know, then over the course of the month, you can go from a small part of the population to a very large part, and so clearly, in March, the infections were exponential and then you have about an 18-day leg between infections and deaths.

And so, April, exactly as you said, we`ve had huge numbers of deaths. If we maintain the isolation, the deaths out in the summer would be very, very small. Very quickly, it can go from barely detectable to huge and, you know, I think people will be shocked that in some locations, the ICU will hardly have anyone in it at all within the next few months.

GUTHRIE: I read that you said that we are nearing the peak in this country, hopefully. And then you`ve also said we`re really not anywhere near the end of this, and I can`t be alone in thinking, well, how does that work out? How can we be almost at the peak but yet so far away from a solution and an end to this and a return to normal?

GATES: Well, the vaccine is the most likely solution, and so, great scientists are rushing to get that done. And actually, I`ve been surprised how quickly they`re moving. There is a number that have even begun that human testing that`s key there.

And so, it could be that in a year, we have lots of a vaccine and then once you get it out to lots of people, then you -- you`re -- you have enough community immunity that you won`t see this widespread problem again.

You know, we have this first peak in the U.S. With the right policies, we`ll have small, some areas that go back and have infections, but we shouldn`t see countrywide anything like this but a -- you know, miracle therapeutic or the vaccine are the only thing that we`ll be able to say, OK, we`re back to normal.

GUTHRIE: I do want to ask you about the second wave, this notion that the virus could come back in the fall. We heard the CDC director saying it could be even potentially more difficult in the fall and winter because the seasonal flu will also be going on.

Dr. Fauci said he`s certain there will be a second wave of this virus.

What`s your perspective on how bad it could be?

GATES: Well, if we`re -- if we`re still being careful about social contact, if we`re wearing masks, if we`re doing distancing where possible, if we got the testing capacity up, I`m hopeful that the fall will not be nearly as bad as this first peak. The flu is a challenge because the symptoms are common enough that knowing exactly who to test, you know, which are people with symptoms, will be a little confused because of all those flu infections that will be taking place.

But the vigilance of not getting too relaxed when you`re seeing pictures of empty ICUs, that`s not intuitive because you could get back on that ramp.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: Part of Bill Gates` conversation with Savannah Guthrie.

Here is a billionaire willing to spend his own money and a billionaire who spends his time thinking about this.

WALLACE: Yes.

WILLIAMS: And when Savannah asks him is this that virus, he calmly answers yes.

WALLACE: Yes, to hear him use the words nightmare scenario, I was watching it and thinking about just how long Bill Gates has been a giant in the public health arena. He was talking about the sorts of things people were afraid of when I was in government.

I mean, it`s been reported by "The New York Times" this week that George W. Bush became obsessed with pandemics and had all of us reading some of the same books that I know Bill Gates talked about in that TED Talk, and that this was the nightmare scenario the last three presidents were scared of. That President Obama had a team that handed this team a plan to deal with something like this. George W. Bush had done some work on that plan, too, and to hear Bill Gates talk about that brings back all that muscle memory that you just don`t see in this more sort of chaotic administration on full display.

But there were a lot of other science headlines in there and lucky for us, we`re able to get reaction from Dr. Michael Osterholm. He`s the director of the Center for Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota and the author of "Deadliest Enemy: Our War Against Killer Germs."

I saw you earlier today on this network and there were so many practical pieces to what Bill Gates was saying about we don`t get to normal until there are some really powerful therapies or a vaccine.

How far off is that?

MICHAEL OSTERHOLM, PHD, CENTER FOR DISEASE RESEARCH & POLICY DIRECTOR: Well, we don`t know right now if we`re going to have a vaccine. I just have to be very honest with you.

WALLACE: Yes.

OSTERHOLM: We hope we will have one, but hope is not a strategy.

Drugs will be very important in reducing the severity of illness and hope for preventing deaths, but it won`t stop the transmission. People are infectious in the earliest stages of their illness even before in some cases they get sick, so the drug would come after that.

So, the epidemiology or meaning, occurrence of cases will continue to occur. And I think one of the things that`s being missed here is that when we talk about, are we going to have the curve flatten, what`s going to come back? Look at it this way, as we know in this country between 5 and maybe 10 percent of the population has been infected even in the metropolitan areas. You heard in New York today, it maybe 14 percent.

This virus is not going to stop transmitting among people until it hits 60 or 70 percent of the people. So, either we`ve got to do that with a vaccine and get them to be immune from that perspective, or they`re going t get it through natural infection. That`s a lot of additional cases to occur over the months a ahead.

WILLIAMS: Doctor, I will not forget the first time you and I spoke. It was in the midst of our political coverage, this virus while dangerous seemed so far off and it was a vague threat. It`s now very real.

I know we`re mostly talking about testing tonight, but absent any political considerations, what do you see people doing wrong right now because you know the strength of this opponent?

OSTERHOLM: Well, first of all, again, I keep looking at the 16 to 18-month course and keeping that in mind is that`s what we`re embarking upon. Far too many people look at this as a sprint and we`re just about over. We`re debating can we reopen now with the idea that`s the end of it.

And in fact, we could have many, many more peaks. Those of us who study infectious disease, and I`ve spent the last 45 years of my life studying this very thing, we don`t know if this coronavirus, will there be a big peak in the next fall? There could be. Will there just be slow burn constantly seeing infections occur like we`re seeing right now in countries like Singapore and Japan that one time had it under control or will we see a series of peaks like Mr. Gates talked about? We don`t know.

But we know one thing, this virus won`t stop until it infects as many as 50 -- 60 to 70 percent of us. So, we have to have a battle plan not just about this week or this month or next month. We`re in this for the long haul.

I unfortunately promise you, we will be having this same discussion where some form of it one year from tonight.

WALLACE: That`s such an ominous prediction. I`m sure you`re correct.

But I wonder if we`re not out of the gates yet in terms of being able to talk about reopening, can you just clarify what the three -- are the three legs of that stool for identifying our starting point, the diagnostic testing, the antibody testing and contact tracing. Or is there another step? It`s confusing to know where we even start with a clear picture of where we are today.

OSTERHOLM: Well, first of all, we have to do testing, but we`ve got to also stop talking about the way we have. We have far too many people that come on shows like this or write articles saying, test, test, test. We have to understand we have a major shortage of reagents today.

The world was not ready to suddenly supply all these test kits, and so, it`s not a matter of money. It`s a matter of physics. We don`t have the reagents.

We have to build these manufacturing facilities to do that. Our government has not helped facilitate that. We needed a Marshall Plan to build that up.

So testing is critical. We need it. Second of all, we have to make sure that we have surge capacity in our hospitals so when the testing shows us that the cases are starting to come back, that we can handle them. We don`t want to overload the hospitals.

And, by the way, that surge capacity doesn`t mean just beds, it also means protecting our health care workers.

The third thing that we absolutely must do in all of this is then do what you just said about contract tracing, have a way so we can constantly try to hold this virus down. Until you have those kinds of things in place, it`s very hard to reopen and not get caught with suddenly this very rapidly rising number of cases.

WILLIAMS: Well, Doctor, you just said the magic phrase to me, the Marshall Plan and I`ll do it one better -- a Manhattan Project. If this is indeed going to be the event that perhaps marks the rest of our adult lives as Americans, why not?

OSTERHOLM: Well, I actually in an op-ed piece I wrote in "The New York Times" almost month ago, which I predicted we`d have a shortage right now that we see if reagents, I actually did call for a Manhattan Project, an intellectual one, that covers all these issues. My Marshall Plan is just about testing reagents.

But I think you`re right on the mark, Brian. We need to bring together that right now and what this country is missing is a core. We`re missing a leadership component that can bring everyone together without regard to partisan politics, without regard to age, race, gender, location.

You know, I said on your network just three weeks ago that one day, it wouldn`t be a red and bluish shoe. It would be a COVID color issue. Look what`s happened in the Midwest right now. All those red counties are turning COVID because of what we`re seeing happen.

So I think that you`re exactly right. We need a Manhattan Project, where one, tell the truth. We need straight talk. What`s really happening, what`s not?

I don`t want to hear another time we have enough testing. The 50 governors will tell you, that`s not true. We need to understand, are we going to have more cases or not? Don`t tell the public we`re not going to have any more cases because they may go away with more sunshine or warm. There`s no truth to that. That`s like defying gravity.

So, I think that`s part of what will make a Manhattan Project work if we all come together to solve a common problem that is this virus and it`s going to be here for awhile, so let`s get on with it right now doing that.

WALLACE: Dr. Michael Osterholm, I think it might solve more than coronavirus to give people something like that to work on together, you`re right. That`s what people are hungry for.

Thank you so much for joining us.

OSTERHOLM: Thank you very much.

WILLIAMS: We have much -- we have much more of our colleague Savannah Guthrie`s exclusive conversation with Bill Gates throughout this program tonight.

WALLACE: The Gates Foundation is in the thick of that hunt for a vaccine. Up next, hear what Bill Gates says he feels hopeful that we may be on the optimistic side of the timeline to find a vaccine and the unprecedented steps now being taken right now to find a vaccine and mass produce it.

WILLIAMS: Plus, does Bill Gates think the U.S. is doing a good job at testing presently? That`s all next.

There is much more still ahead this hour. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo will join us to talk about the day he learned this stunning fact -- more than one in five New York city residents tested found to have antibodies to the virus, meaning far more New Yorkers might have had coronavirus without becoming sick or showing symptoms.

Stay with us.

WILLIAMS: Welcome back to our special broadcast tonight.

We need to identify all of those individuals out there who are infected so we can get them to quarantine and self-isolate. And we need validation on that testing. We need to be able to trust a negative so that if we tell someone that they have a negative COVID test, we are comfortable that they are not infectious, that it`s a true negative and they can return to society and whatever the new normal is going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Dr. Najy Masri in a city I love, New Orleans, Louisiana, pleading for validated tests. They passed a sad rubicund there today. The Governor John Bel Edwards announced that more people in his state have now died of coronavirus than died in Hurricane Katrina. Governor Edwards also said he hopes to start phase one of reopening Louisiana early on in the state of May. Nicolle?

WALLACE: It`s one thing that every single person in this country seems to agree on that more and better tests, more readily available tests, more user-friendly tests would help this country, would go a long way. The truth is right now as we sit here, Brian, we have a president who thinks the testing is just great, that it`s perfect.

WILLIAMS: Yes, that`s a problem. I -- it all goes back to Crimson Tide for me. Even though Denzel was -- Gene Hackman was mean to Denzel, but that`s a subject for another time. Gene Hackman as captain of the submarine decided to hold a missile drill during a kitchen fire. He said that`s the best time to hold a missile drill. We`re having a kitchen fire that could consume the house. I worry about the missile drill. I worry, God forbid, about anything worse, and we have to all hope that the election is secured coming up in November.

For us, for now, these are all topics for another time. That`s going to do it for our two hours coverage.

WALLACE: Thanks for joining us tonight. "The Rachel Maddow Show" starts right now.
