urn:contentItem:5XSH-WS01-F0JS-Y52V-00000-00MTI Outlook 2020: Changing China Is Opening Up For Medtech Entrants2019-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMTI Outlook 2020: Changing China Is Opening Up For Medtech Entrants

The potential of China's vast health-care products market is alluring. It has proved substantially off-limits for much of the global medtech industry, and has rarely been in the early launch strategies of global companies. China's government wants that to change, as evidenced in the latest Five-Year Plan and the recent Healthy China 2030 report.

The changes that are underway are part of the new climate for business overseen by Chinese president Xi Jinping, who is trying to attract more foreign innovative companies. They include necessary structural changes and initiatives like special trade zones intended to increase China's appeal as a destination market.

But it wouldn't be China without some form of controls in place, Chinese-only standards and national UDI systems, etc. But these controls are decreasing incrementally, according to Nick Beckett, the co-head of life sciences and healthcare at international law firm CMS. Beckett, also head of Asia-Pacific IP at CMS, spends much of his time in Beijing and greater China.

With greater demand for the type of products and services routinely available in the Europe and North America, China has reached a health-care watershed, Beckett said.

Chinese Medtechs Under-Represented in Global Top Rankings

Four Chinese companies feature in Medtech Insight's Top 100 medical device companies by dollar-ranked revenues for 2018: Lepu Medical Technology (Beijing) Co. Ltd. (cardiovascular products and services, Beijing);   MicroPort Scientific Corp. (orthopedic and cardiac products, Shanghai); Jiangsu Yuyue Medical Equipment & Supply (Zhenjiang); and Shinva Medical Instrument Co., (sterilization and disinfection equipment, Shandong). (   "MTI Top 100 Leading Medtechs See Steady Organic Growth In A Market On The Cusp Of Change" "Medtech Insight")

Chinese manufacturers are under-represented at this level, and so are foreign companies and their medtech innovations in China. But demand in China is growing for the technologies that western patients already have access to. Changing attitudes about the value of healthcare will help transform China's health-care industry and market in the decade ahead. Mindful of the need for quality healthcare for the vast local population, top decision-makers, from Jinping down, are overseeing an ongoing process of support and investment in the sector.

The overall framework is set out in the 13th Five-Year Plan for economic and social development of the People's Republic of China 2016-2020, listing China's strategic intentions and major objectives, tasks, and measures for economic and social development. By the end of the plan, for a national population anticipated to reach 1.42 billion in 2020, the major goals are: doubling China's GDP and per capita personal income from 2010 levels; moving industrial production towards the medium-high end; and visibly supporting and fostering innovation-driven developments, business start-ups and internationally-competitive enterprises.

In a section dedicated to promoting a healthy China, the Plan promises deepened reform of the health-care system, an emphasis on prevention, and strategies to control of chronic diseases  ̶  cardiovascular, neurological and vascular diseases, diabetes, cancer, respiratory disease and mental illness. It speaks of a tiered medical diagnosis and treatment system and promised to improve the capacity of general practitioners, with the number of active physicians targeted to reach 2.5 per 1,000 people.

A Role For Market Mechanisms And Reform In Key Areas

Enlarging the scale of the national health industry and perfecting the health-care services systems are two of the five specific goals of Healthy China 2030: A Vision for Health Care, released in October 2016 by Jinping as a blueprint for the changes China should make in the coming decade. With innovation at its center, it advocates a role for market mechanisms. In 29 chapters, it recommends 13 indicators and four core principles for how China must reform key public health services, food and drug safety systems and the Chinese medical industry.

The ground is increasingly fertile and the population is ready for the health-care reforms and delivery improvements of the kinds detailed in these two reports, according to Beckett. Speaking to Medtech Insight, he observed that, in healthcare, China is indeed at a turning point. The markets may have heard that before, but he expects real change to come.            

One reason for increasing optimism that China is more ready now to turn the corner is that the youth of the country, more connected through social media, international travel and foreign education and experiences, have a greater awareness than their parents' and grandparents' generations of what goes on beyond China. Other parts of the world have access to innovative devices and drugs and China's millennials are now demanding them too. Overseas companies are monitoring this, factoring in the impact it will have. Beckett observed that these companies will need to be more patient- and consumer-focused and ready to bring their new or yet-to-be-developed technologies into China to provide information and support local patients.

This comes at the same time that artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning and the advantages offered by big data - a major focus in the Five-Year Plan 2016 - 2020  ̶  are being brought to bear. AI is seen as a transformational step, and the next few years will be fascinating in terms of who will drive developments in the digital health-care ecosystem. China is a global leader in AI, alongside the UK and US. Its homegrown major tech groups, Tencent and Alibaba, especially, continue to make huge strides in digital health-care delivery. In some ways, the traditional big pharma companies, especially, appear to be unprepared for this change despite the accelerated pace of developments over the past four to five years.

The uptake of AI in China is one of the focus areas of a CMS "legal perspectives" document titled "AI in Life Sciences," which quotes a government prediction of the value of the Chinese AI industry in 2025: RMB400bn (according to the national "Plan for the Development of a New Generation of AI"). The puzzle is that pharma, and to an extent medtech too, while talking up the prospects of AI are still grappling with the hows and whys in terms of monetizing it and bringing it into business models. They still more often talk about specific bolt-ons only, but by contrast, China's Tencent, for one, is not waiting around (see below).

Awareness of Healthcare On The Up

The sense that China is ready to open for health-care entrants is boosted by the knowledge that, while the population has traditionally had a low fundamental awareness of health, a new awareness of that very fact means that remedial action is unavoidable. The millennial generation's attitudes will be a contributory factor to the speed of change ahead.

Historically, as a very poor country, China has lacked a health-care infrastructure. With no or low primary-care availability and no local general-practitioner interface, patients have been forced to into usually crowded hospitals to seek an appointment. With no yardstick for their ailments, patients have been prone to overreact to very simple issues, and so there remain big challenges around educational issues, and about patients being able to seek appropriate health-care attention for perhaps minor health issues. Here is an area where awareness, from an albeit low base, is set to rise markedly.

Coupled with that, China's new vision of itself as a "strong and growing country" in turn fosters notions that it should rightfully have good healthcare. That is still not the case in the large rural areas, but there, too, a better basic understanding of health is developing. The advent of technology, including personal health-care information apps that give basic information about conditions, are facilitating and driving that change.

In view of this, medtech companies should be providing support to those patients who are more receptive to it and maybe even more demanding of it. This will lead to demands for better basic health-care provision. Healthy China 2030 and its recommendations are central tenets of the administration, which now finds it must provide in the large rural communities the standard of health care enjoyed by the slightly more affluent people in Shanghai or Beijing. "The government had to up its game in terms of quality of health-care services, and tied to the opening up of the market to private investment, it's apparent that it is all coming together," said Beckett.

'One China'

China's policies are built around a "one country" approach for health care, and good provision across the provinces and into the remote rural zones. Remote monitoring technology, such as telecare/telemedicine systems, is seen as increasingly critical in rural China. Allowing private investment is one of the strategies to develop health-care provision in China's the second- and third- tier cities.

The Five-Year Plan underlines the "one country, two systems," approaches for Hong Kong and Macao. Hong Kong's current protests against its government over China's drive for more influence there are being watched closely for potential effects on business. China also seeks to build cross-Straits cooperation with Taiwan, under the One China approach.

Private healthcare, although still very small-scale, has been making inroads in China in the past three to five years, manifested in the establishment of specialist clinics for respiratory disease, for example. "The groundwork has been done to allow greater investment now in both private and public private hospitals," said Beckett, adding however, that while China can "move at the speed of light" for building projects, etc, in policy, law and regulation it sometimes moves much more slowly.

Pilot Zones

Using pilot zones is a common approach of the Chinese authorities. A prime example in summer 2019 was the way it tested the new marketing authorization holder (MAH) tool for medtech. The MAH is a very significant concept that until recently did not exist in China. Medtech product license owners were typically the manufacturers. Only they could own the market authorization and they could only transfer it to another manufacturer.

With so much economic activity tied to manufacturing capability, this led to difficulties. The MAH system, first used in three zones and then in a further 21 this year, makes transferring market authorization much easier and will lead to contracts being set up in manufacturing development. Contract research organizations and contract sales organizations are expected to flourish in what will become a wider outsourcing environment.

But such processes often take several years, as the Chinese need to be totally comfortable before rolling out a scheme nationwide.

The medtech MAH rule is also seen as a boost for local innovation. "It will be a move from basic and mid-level devices, to higher-end and probably higher-price devices, and thereby will help Chinese commercial operators be better able to compete globally," said Beckett.

Jinping's "One belt one road" (OBOR) trade outreach project focuses on improving connectivity and cooperation across Asia, Africa and Europe. Though not primarily a tool for medtech projects, if China were to develop large medtech champions, they too could use the OBOR to develop trading routes and find trading partners, eventually helping their global health-care trading plans.

Slow China

Critics would argue that "eventually" has too often been a signature word for Chinese policy initiatives. The long-awaited amendment to the PRC Drug Administration Law was due to come into effect on 1 December 2019. It is a second major systematic and structural amendment to China's drug-administration framework since the implementation of the last significant amendment in 2001. But the amendment has been in the works since 2015.

The catalyst was the China's State Council's issuance in October 2017 of the Opinions on Deepening Regulatory Reforms to Encourage Drug and Medical Device Innovation. This proposed fundamental changes to regulatory systems, including the simplification of clinical trials, implementing the Drug Marketing Administration Holder system, establishing a patent-linkage regime and perfecting the drug-registration process. The marketing administration system for medtech is slowly and carefully coming into place now.

"Politically, China tries to do things in such a way to get everyone on side; not to do anything suddenly," Beckett observed. A frustration is that several of China's regulatory authorities are often involved in looking at the same issues at the same time. For example, three were studying China's anti-trust and competition law. This overlap can slow down the passage of regulatory instruments.

In the medtech domain, the National Medical Products Administration (NMPA), the Chinese agency for regulating drugs and medical devices, has been mulling the dropping of the country of origin (COO) certification requirement for "priority" devices that qualify for its "green channel," a fast-track innovation approval pathway. But nervousness about making big decisions among individual regulatory executives has led to a situation where no decision has yet been taken. Regulatory officers would rather not make a decision than make a wrong decision. In terms of the COO, the nervousness is at individual level, not at a state level. "Looking at it through the lens of the Chinese state, it's clear China is not in a hurry, I feel," said Beckett.

Green Channel For Medtech Is Still Underused

NMPA's green channel has not so far been called into action as much as had been anticipated. It was set up in 2014, but five years on, this route to fast-track certain devices remains underused by manufacturers. The consensus is that the initiative has value, however. And on the regulators' side, it is a sign of preparedness to expedite the right products, Beckett noted.

From a western company's perspective, as an initiative, it ties in with foreign clinical trials exemptions, quicker regulatory reviews, and products getting to market much faster, and indeed, coming to market first, he explained.

IP More Protected And Courts More Active

The regulations and infrastructure being put in place now in China are more internationally aligned, and are more acceptable to companies in the west, which are no longer worried quite so much about each and every step they take. In the area of intellectual property, China has formalized dialogs with judges in the US, UK and Japan, which is making China more internationally accepted. "The lens is slowly changing, and we may soon have data exclusivity and a patent linkage system. We already have patent recognition and special courts protecting companies' rights," said Beckett.

The standards are changing and the infrastructure is being put in place that allows investors in China to have more confidence. From China's perspective, there is a drive to elevate domestic life-sciences companies to "national champion level," so that they can eventually compete globally. Although there is a long way to go in the life sciences and health-care spaces, where there are ongoing learning requirements and need for talent and know how. This makes China receptive to foreign investment and assistance in ways which other industries - for example, telecoms - simply do not need.

The recent development in the Drug Administration Law (see above) also answers in some ways the need in China to align more with international standards. The authorities are looking at bringing in a pharmacovigilance standard, and are changing the emphasis from pre-approval to post-approval. The pre-approval stage in pharma is much faster now, enabling companies to bring products to market more swiftly, but at the same time, with increasing liabilities on them. China is on the same basic path in devices, making strides in exemptions from local clinical trials. "It all fits," said Beckett.

Cleary, China is more prepared to use a mix of international and Chinese standards in its regulatory infrastructure. It is developing its own unique device identification system for medical devices, but using ISO-based, China-specific standards, GB, the code for national standards issued by the Standards Administration, and YY, the code for medical devices, issued by the NMPA. The medtech industry follows both sets of standards, says Chao Xu, co-founder of Chinese consultancy J-Medtec, in Berlin.

Imitation Helps Achieve Greater Goals

"China is not afraid to copy - historically seen as a high form of flattery in China," said Beckett. Its law, for example, is very heavily based on European law, and the patent linkage system is partially derived from the US system.

The same principle applies in the case of WeChat, the multi-purpose messaging, social media and mobile payment app, owned by Tencent Holdings. Tencent specializes in internet-related services and products, has become bigger than the concept it imitated, Facebook, and is increasingly important in digital healthcare. It was the first Chinese firm to have a market valuation of over $500bn. Of the three big tech players in China, including Alibaba and Baidu, Tencent is the fastest growing in healthcare.

Tencent Trusted Doctor now claims to connect 440,000 certified doctors with more than 10 million patients online. It collaborates with Germany's Merck KGaA, and it also operates WeDoctor, a web- appointments, education, diagnosis, and consultation tool. Alibaba is developing services to support China's primary care system through online doctor consultations.

Primary Care Issue To Be Solved

Such tools are gaining a lot of ground in the relative absence of primary care in China, where there are some very early-stage plans to install primary care services in hospitals and a push to establish smaller clinics that integrate technology.

At the same time, China sees the need to increase the standing and social status of general practitioners, who believe they are perceived as inferior to specialists. A 2017 survey by the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and others revealed that Chinese physicians bear heavy physical, mental and financial stress. Low confidence, trust and respect for them from wider Chineses society are their other complaints. Soberingly, over 70% would not encourage their children to follow their career path. 

Talent Being Brought In

China is encouraging foreign talent into the country, including in Nanjing, the heart of the Chinese pharma industry, to leverage the knowledge to innovate and help advance the local industry. Nanjing University is a leading university in the pharmaceutical field in China. The country is welcoming innovative products in the life sciences domain, but the government plans to retain the firm hand of control over any decisions.

Another tool for developing healthcare and local health-care business are the special zones, such as free trade zones and a medical tourist pilot zone. For example, Hainan province could take advantage of its location in the South China Sea to maximize the huge trading potential with Vietnam, the Philippines and Thailand, among others.

Action Vs Corruption

Jinping has led a big push to rid the country of corruption at all levels over the past five or six years. The historical problem with corruption partly lies in the multiple layers of distributors and the power of money. After the Chinese government fined GlaxoSmithKline PLC for $436m for illegal kickbacks in 2014, companies have redoubled their compliance and auditing activities, set up proper local training, and reviewed their procedures.

But the involvement of third parties in sales and marketing still presents challenges, as it means manufacturers losing sight of what happens and possibly losing control. The government has tightened up this whole area by reducing distributor numbers, slimming down brands, introducing invoice controls and generally tidying up the system. "[Corruption] was built in, and changing it has been a big challenge, but Xi Jinping has taken strong action and it's now a lot better than it was," said Beckett.

The tariff issues between the US and China have done nothing to help China's global trade ambitions, but the effects are being seen in the US too, where providers are having to consider finding alternative sources for Chinese imported devices. VC funding has been impacted recently by the US trade tensions after a big VC funding uptake in 2018.

Strategic Signposts Point To More Healthcare

The Five-Year Plan and Healthy China 2030 initiative are strategic signposts for massive change, and a strong indication of where China is focusing.

They acknowledge that Chinese role model names in medtech and pharma are not there as yet, and at present, aspiring innovators in China are looking at companies like Johnson & Johnson as models to emulate.

They underline the critical nature of partnerships to success in China. And they encourage  companies to "be the first in China," under the package of measures being developed for the health-care products industries. China has not yet featured in the launch strategies of global companies at an early stage: it used to be at the very end of such plans. Now, it's getting to a point where companies might consider to launch in China first. "But it's very early days there, and that notion needs more time," said Beckett.

Locally, investment is being improved, as seen, for example, in the new health-care incubator fund in Shenzen, in the Greater Bay Area. It is a government-funded initiative, and does not yet involve huge figures, but it is an attempt to encourage start-ups from all over the world to come to China.

Conservative China Is Serious About Health-care Improvement

Conservative China's plans make it one to watch in health care in the next five years. Its plans, central government-led, are seen as critical for China, targeting an area of great need, and providing opportunities for western and Chinese companies alike. The market is there, the infrastructure is being put in place, and there is a move towards a more consumer-led, innovative economy. China plays the long game, but it seems that western minds can probably have growing confidence - and less nervousness - regarding future medtech and pharma business with China.       

By Ashley Yeo

urn:contentItem:5XRX-08C1-JD3R-7000-00000-00MTI Outlook 2020: Medtechs Enter The Decade Of Digital, Consumers and Wellness2019-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMTI Outlook 2020: Medtechs Enter The Decade Of Digital, Consumers and Wellness

The patient is increasingly the focus of the combined efforts of health-care stakeholders, dictating more and more how the broad concept of value must be integrated into health-care delivery. Digital technologies will expedite the process. Yet critics claim health care is too slow to transform.   

2020 will be the year when the industry shake-out from the EU Medical Device Regulation will become fully visible; until now, it has been mainly silence and speculation. The MDR has united medtech executives on one thing: it must not slow down access to innovation for patients. But is it a failure in waiting?   

Innovation will remain the spine of the industry, but disruptive forces are telling manufacturers the old business model won't suffice. Tomorrow's medtech champions will target wellness, consumers, disease management, diagnostics, data management, the remote patient, chronic disease management and genomics, as well as clinical research. Is a major shake-out coming?

"Digital is no longer a vertical, it cuts across all sectors. It is a horizontal." Andy Fish, AdvaMed's chief strategy officer, was telling the press in late fall 2019 that medtech companies will come to incorporate digital as a means to an end, not as an end in itself. "Digital is now the coin of the realm," he said, explaining the rationale behind the US industry association's decision to invest time and resources in a new Center For Digital Heath. ("Reimbursement A Top Goal For New Digital Health Lobbying Center" "Medtech Insight")

It is further recognition of the health-care value of digital, now and in the future, and another step on the road to the integration of modern methods of care delivery. It is also a reflection of the transition in health-care industries from supply push to demand pull.

Innovation spawns early adopters, but they are not the real market for medtech companies of any size. Delegates were reminded of this essential truth at the French annual medtech start-ups meeting, in spring 2019 (see below). In such a fast-moving climate, there can be a tendency to overplay the early prospects of a technology - digital or "traditional." Later in a technology' lifecycle, the continual, incremental and less-visible changes that make a real difference tend to be underplayed.

This also applies to value-based health care (VBHC), where much is happening even if progress is not as fast as expected, according to Eric Thépaut, president for Europe, Middle East and Asia, at Boston Scientific Corp. (   "MedTech Forum 2019 The Future Is Here But Industry Still Needs A LongTerm Vision" "In Vivo") VBHC, he said, "is a long-term initiative where a step-by-step approach is needed." It is a delivery concept that one day will become mainstream, similar to how once disruptive medical tools and technques, nanotechnology, molecular diagnostics, point-of-care testing and telehealth for instance, are now factored in as part of the medtech routine.

Elsewhere in medtech, other routines are changing fast: 2020 will see the biggest change to EU medtech regulation since the 1993 Medical Device Directive (93/42/EEC), when the EU Council's Medical Device Regulation (MDR, 2017/745) comes fully into force. That is the promise. But as the clock ticks down to implementation day on 26 May, the magnitude of the task has been causing more and more jitters. Many stakeholders want the EU to acknowledge that, while the MDR is generally welcomed, it is coming too soon. It's certainly the right thing to do, but it is arriving too fast, so it is actually the wrong thing to do, to paraphrase ResMed Inc. CEO Mick Farrell, during MedTech Europe's MedTech Forum panel discussion in Paris in May 2019. (   "MedTech Forum 2019 Building Growth In The Outcomes Era" "In Vivo")

There are still not enough notified bodies accredited to do the work required by the MDR. There were seven under the MDR, and two under the IVDR for in vitro diagnostics, as of 8 November 2019. Under the previous EU directives, there were 58 such organizations. This prospective shortage of resources makes the new regulation work against high-quality patient care, the very thing the MDR promises to strengthen. ("BSIs Gary Slack Explains Why MDR TakeUp Is So Slow" "Medtech Insight")

Signs of a more flexible approach from the European Commission appeared in October 2019, when talk emerged of some Class I products additionally being able to use the MDR's four-year grace period, remaining under MDD oversight until 2024. There was also a proposal for a two-year delay to 2022 in Eudamed. These moves open the door to possibly further concessions from the commission in 2020, which would suit most of industry very well. Brexit - effectively voted through by the 12 December UK general election  ̶  throws a spanner in the works, and may yet be the catalyst that allows a more concerted rethink on MDR timetables without the commission changing its sacrosanct policy line on implementation.  

Favorable Demographic Trends Are There To Be Exploited

On a broad scale, the outlook for medtech business is good, with global healthcare expected to benefit from continued favorable demographic trends. The world's population is anticipated to grow by more than a billion by 2030. The number of people over the age of 60 is forecast to rise by 500 million, to 1.4 billion, with the prevalence of cancer, cardiovascular diseases and other long-term conditions rising in tandem. Medtech is a safe if maybe unexciting investment, with average market growth in the mid- to high single digits expected to be perpetuated in the near term.  

Average health-care spending is expected to increase annually by 4% to 5%. Next year, around half (some $4trn) of all health-care spending will be targeted at cancer, and cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, according to Deloitte's Global Healthcare Sector Outlook.

This is good news for medtechs companies, but there is a complication: innovation is changing. Big-scale innovations in the traditional device areas are becoming fewer. An increasing amount of innovation is coming from digital iterations and advances. Abbott Laboratories Inc.'s recent Merlin 10.0 app for the CardioMEMS HF sensor system is designed to keep heart failure patients out of hospital and allows physicians to communicate directly with them is just one example of where large companies are able to broaden their offerings with digital enhancements. (   "Abbott Launches New App To Keep Heart Failure Patients Out Of The Hospital" "Medtech Insight")

The US FDA is fully behind mobile apps, aware of their potential to help individuals manage their own health and wellness and gain access to useful information when and where they need it. The US, arguably the most fertile and receptive market for medtech innovation, is once again leading the way in a new cornerstone of the industry, just as it did in fall 2013, when it broke the turf on implementing unique device identification (UDI).

It seems mobile apps are being adopted almost as quickly as they are developed: in 2017 alone, 325,000 health care apps were available on smartphones, according to FDA-reported industry estimates. The agency posted an updated Policy for Device Software Functions and Mobile Medical Applications Guidance ("MMA guidance") in fall 2019.("Industry Optimistic About Second CDS Draft Guidance FDA Releases More Final Software Guidances" "Medtech Insight")

Into The Data-Driven Era Of The 2020s

Apps are where the medtech and digital confluence is at its most obvious. Digital is prompting a rethink among those medtechs who are reviewing whether they should be targeting consumers and wellness, or patients and sickness. The simplistic view is that there is a clear marketing advantage, at least, in seeking  consumer/wellness branding, accoring to ZS principal Brian Chapman. ("MedTech Forum 2019 Consumers And Wellness Or Patients And Health Care" "In Vivo") But as a rule, medtech has yet to view patient-consumers as its real customer; its efforts are still focused largely on provider systems. 

Nevertheless, medtech is "truly beginning to acquire the tools and capabilities that will allow it to enter a data-driven, personalized new era," according to Kevin Lobo, chairman and CEO of Stryker Corp., and the current AdvaMed chairman. EY's latest annual Pulse of the Industry report (2019) quotes Lobo as saying that data-driven medical devices will be at the forefront of health care's transformation. Digital and AI are currently the standout features in an industry that in his view has seen "generally conservative activity" in the past year.

Boston Scientific Corp.'s Thépaut agrees, and says there is no changing course now. "Digitization is going to completely transform health care, albeit later than has happened in the consumer world," he said, alluding to the type of criticism often directed at health care. But there are clear reasons for this to be so. "We are focusing on patients in a highly-regulated industry, and health care will always be unique." Commoditizing it would not be good for the ecosystem or the patient; however, it will evolve significantly, he believes.

Patients were arguably already "at the center," but now they are going to be even more so, with device-derived information more fluid and available faster. At present, the European industry remains focused on products and therapeutic value, but what is required, in Thépaut's view, is a very open dialog with patients. US FDA guidance seems to acknowledge this shift (see below). Indeed, at the 2019 MedTech Forum, it was sobering to find both that the medtech industry was unable to pin down all the benefits that digital could bring; and that it was open about that.

"Blurring Everything"

While the medtech industry is still  at the digital learning stage, initiatives like AdvaMed's rebooted Center For Digital Heath will fill in many of the knowledge gaps. The CDH will look at adoption, regulation and reimbursement of digital tools across the industry. The big medtech names and certain software manufacturers are already members. How its agenda shifts will be likely be significant in telling us how health care will be delivered in the 2020s, and by whom.  

The British In Vitro Diagnostic Association (BIVDA) is going along the same path. BIVDA chairman Darren Stenlake of (Sysmex Corp.) told an association meeting in early October that "digital is blurring everything," and highlighted the UK industry's plans to focus a new working group on IT infrastructures, cybersecurity and malware.

Unmatched Appetite For Innovation

But it will not be to the total detriment of traditional medical technologies. Indeed, innovation levels are currently at seldom-reached heights, to judge from activity at the US FDA, which broke its new novel medical devices approvals record in 2018 with at 100 new device approvals. ("2018 US Device Approvals The Year Of De Novos And Digital Health" "Medtech Insight")  Nevertheless,  as an investment proposition, medtech is currently perceived as less favorable than biopharma, and the intense competition within the sector means a clear run on innovation does not last for very long. But the appetite for and pace of innovation in medtech cannot be matched.

The consensus is that massive opportunities are available in medtech, as seen in Abbott Laboratories Inc.'s significant breakthrough with MitraClip. Abbott's structural heart franchise grew to $1.2bn in 2018. (   "Diabetes Mitral Repair And Diagnostics Drive Big Quarter For Abbott" "Medtech Insight") The next-generation MitraClip percutaneous mitral valve repair system was perhaps the single most eye-catching "traditional" medical technology in 2018. A rich year for Abbott in 2018 also yielded the HeartMate 3 LVAD as a destination (long-term use) therapy, and the Xience Sierra drug-eluting stent system. The group was able to boast healthy cardiovascular sales, and is now the fifth-leading medtech group by sales, after   Medtronic PLC,    Johnson & Johnson,   Philips Healthcare and   GE Healthcare. (   "MTI Top 100 Leading Medtechs See Steady Organic Growth In A Market On The Cusp Of Change" "Medtech Insight")

Devices for minimally-invasive procedures will likely gain increasing momentum in the patient-centric 2020s. Peripheral artery disease micro-catheters, small incision radiation-therapy devices in breast cancer therapy, and urology drainage catheters that significantly reduce urinary tract infections are the types of technologies touted for future success. A clear theme is becoming visible for medtech R&D departments, which are now able to more rapidly determine if their technology has what it takes to gain acceptance in the value-based era.

Fellow cardiovascular company Edwards Lifesciences Corp. expects revenues from its transcatheter mitral and tricuspid valve therapies to double to $80m in 2020. The global market for mitral and tricuspid repair and replacement therapies will reach $3bn by 2024 - and won't stop there, according to Edwards' CEO Michael Mussallem. The Sapien TAVR system will continue to drive the group's revenues - by 20% to 25% to over $4bn in 2019. (   "Edwards Invests In Mitral Tricuspid Solutions As TAVR Growth Exceeds Expectations" "Medtech Insight")

More recent technology breakthroughs that will continue to command attention in 2020 and beyond include diabetes technology group Senseonics' implantable Eversense CGM (see the ADA 2019 review). The group has become the third to receive the non-adjunctive indication, which allows a CGM to be used for insulin dosing in place of a fingerstick glucometer. But cost and ease of use are crucial factors in this consumer-facing industry segment. (   "Market Intel After A Year Of Partnerships Insulin Pump Manufacturers Will Face Fierce Competition" "Medtech Insight")

Connected health's potential is reaching into every corner of the devices world. For instance, global market for hearing aids is expected to grow to $11bn by 2023, a compound annual growth rate of 7.4%, according to Informa's Meddevicetracker. ("Connected Health Summit VCs Discuss Digital Health Investment" "Medtech Insight") This is on the back of the rising aging population worldwide experiencing hearing loss, and a younger population looking for more sophisticated devices. Into this market will come Bose's direct-to-consumer hearing aid, a device that does not need to be fitted by physicians, and can be sold online. This is a disruptive challenge to the majors, like   Sonova Holding AG,   William Demant Holding AS and   GN Store Nord AS.

And of course, Apple's every move in medtech is scrutinized, and never more so than when the de novo-classified Apple Watch gained de novo FDA approval in fall 2018 for an app that functions as an electrocardiogram.("FDA Explains Why It Approved Apple Watchs De Novo Despite Missing Primary Endpoint" "Medtech Insight")

There is a view that light-therapy-based devices will attract more market interest in the coming years. Philips Healthcare' VitalSky delirium-recovery technology, which will challenge traditional pharma approaches for a condition that costs $150bn per year in the US alone, is one such technology. It does not attract greater direct reimbursement, but it helps reduce in hospital stay length, and thus generates a secondary reimbursement effect. It's another example of the value-based, holistic care approach that will be the strapline fopr increasing numbers of medtech innovators in the coming decade. 

M&A Environment Changes To Affect Start-ups?

A cautious mood has settled in regarding M&A targets, especially given the strong valuations at present. In our annual table of major M&A, the list of purely medtech-focused $1bn+ acquisitions is relatievly short (see below). It is a cautious environment at present that will extend into 2020.

The MDR will also have a telling effect on those who succeed in the EU markets, who will be acquired and when, and which companies will decide to bite the bullet and cut programs and products. Another pressure on companies is that thay are increasingly expected to gain reimbursement before they can make an exit. And all this against an environment of overall industry financing levels declining for the second consecutive year in 2018, claims EY. However, venture capital continues to flow into medtech.

A good indication of where there are new seams to be exploited is provided by Cleveland Clinic Innovations in its Top 10 Medical Innovations, the annual showcase from the US hospital group that was voted US News & World Report's "2019-20 Best Hospital." Cleveland Clinic Innovations predicted in fall 2019 that the following technologies, procedures and trends would be gain ground in 2020:

Minimally-invasive mitral valve surgery (see above). This will further expand in the US, to individuals with secondary or functional MR, despite optimal medical therapy. The mitral valve is defective in around one in 10 individuals over the age of 75, causing regurgitation, so this is an important new treatment option.

Closed-loop spinal cord stimulation. Chronic pain is a reason for prescription of opioid medication, but spinal cord stimulation also provides electrical stimulus to the spinal cord. Closed-loop stimulation allows for better communication between the device and the spinal cord, and can reduce unsatisfactory outcomes due to subtherapeutic or overstimulation events.

Biologics in orthopedic repair. Cells, blood components, growth factors, and other natural substances are increasingly finding their way into orthopedic care, allowing for the possibility of expedited improved outcomes. To facilitate biologics license approvals, the FDA has opened new pathways to expedite reviews.

Antibiotic envelopes for cardiac implantable device infection prevention. Some 1.5 million US patients receive an implantable cardiac electronic device every year. Antibiotic-embedded envelopes can encase these cardiac devices, effectively preventing infection or even potentially life-threatening complications.

Ongoing breakthrough indications include LivaNova PLC's VNS in Treatment Resistant Depression, for which 2020 looks like being a good year. (   "LivaNova Launches RECOVER Trial Of VNS For Depression To Meet CMS CED Requirement" "Medtech Insight") While the US CMS study's primary endpoint is response is at 12 months, the company might be open to an interim review. Jefferies Healthcare foresees revenue contributions coming from VNS in TRD starting in Q4 2019, and increasing in 2020.

Investments In Digital Health - China Makes Presence Felt

US investment in digital health start-ups was up 16% at over $11bn in 2018, according to a new Top 150 Investments report and interactive research briefing from CB Insights in New York. Genomics company   Grail Inc. secured a total of $1.6bn, disease diagnosis company   23andMe Inc., $795m, and health-care services delivery company Babylon Health, $635m. The big rounds went to companies innovating across health insurance  ̶  Clover Health raising $500m (series E), and genomics company Ginkgo BioWorks, $290m (series E), for instance.

Notable in this list of 150 was how many Chinese firms occupy top rankings. The world's second-largest economy is investing significantly in health care, now a national priority as the population ages and demands better care. The Chinese health-care market is growing at a 17% compound annual growth rate, according to the World Health Organization.

The report showed that China's tech giant Tencent was a top three investor in digital health start-ups (based on the number of portfolio companies), alongside Google and Microsoft - these three representing over 70% of digital health deals made by the key big tech companies. Google is the undisputed leader in digital health investment, says CB Insights, mainly in genomics, clinical research, and insurance and benefits. Its subsidiaries and investment vehicles include Alphabet, Google Ventures, CapitalG, Gradient Ventures, Verily Life Sciences, and incubators such as Google Launchpad Accelerator. Intel, Samsung, Alibaba, Amazon, and Comcast have likewise almost all reached household-name status in digital healthcare. In November 2019, Google said it was acquiring FitBit for $2.1bn, boosting its presence in the wearable technology market. ("Google Buys Fitbit In 21Bn Deal Rivaling Apple" "Medtech Insight")

These groups' top targets are not medtech per se, but the provision of a wider wellness offering that encompasses data management, diagnostics, remote patient monitoring, drug delivery, telemedicine and chronic disease management, as well as genomics and the other leading targets listed by Google. The clinician expertise still resides among medtechs large and small, which the big techs do not have ready access to - and maybe do not want. But there is no hiding from the fact that these developments show how the health-care delivery model is undergoing huge change.

Real World Evidence And Massive Potential Of AI

AI and machine learning are increasingly being used in the development of therapy solutions, therapy delivery and provision of data for assisting biopharma clinical trials. Ixico Ltd., for instance, is working on neuroimaging methods that provide more accurate and richer brain structural and functional information. The 60-person company can also capture, analyze and measure digital biomarker data supplied by wearable biosensors or mobile devices. These are for parameters such as sleep, activity and heart rate. The aim is to deliver patient-centric, clinically-meaningful and objective data from patient subjects.

Better-targeted success has been an aim in neurological disease clinical trials for some time. There are still no effective therapies available to slow the progression of Alzheimer's, and a growing realization that new ideas are needed. Cognetivity, another small company, is developing a sensitive visual categorization platform in conjunction with advanced AI algorithms to cluster test performance in terms of accuracy, speed and image properties. It wants its technology to be seen as a blood pressure test-equivalent for dementia patients for use up to 20 years before symptoms appear.

Genomics' Rising Role In Healthcare Management

The awakening of minds to the potential of genomics is arguably the biggest single positive development that will guarantee the success of targeted therapy in the decade ahead. Genomics is one of three new industries (alongside digital and diagnostics) that the UK Life Sciences Industrial Strategy (LSIS), and NHS England's second "sector deal" aim to establish in the coming years. ("UK Plugs Into Golden Period For Medtech Innovation" "Medtech Insight")

The LSIS was authored by John Bell, Regius Professor of Medicine at Oxford University, who is a champion of genomics and of the power it brings to identify at-risk individuals with greater precision. Genomics will have a profound impact on the development of diagnostics and on new ways of treating disease, he says. The biggest genomics company, Illumina Inc., which has built its genomics reach around the 2007 purchase of UK DNA sequencing firm Solexa, is of the same mind.

Illumina CSO David Bentley believes that if genetic testing follows the trend of wearables, becomes readily accessible and can fill in gaps like phenotypes and medical indicators, such as pulse and blood sugar level, it will become a very popular diagnostic tool. ("Illumina CSO Bentley Paints A Vision For The Future Of Precision Medicine" "In Vivo") Many key genomics organizations already use Illumina technology, such as 23andMe and   Grail Inc. (see above), illustrating its pivotal role in individuals' health-care management.

 

 

Exact Sciences Corp. made its commitment clear in July 2019 with its $2.3bn purchase of cancer diagnostic tests developer   Genomic Health Inc..

Early Diagnosis Being Elevated To Its Rightful Place

Improved patient outcomes and cost-savings for provider systems have long been the obvious yet all-too-easily overlooked benefits of in vitro diagnostics and other diagnostic technologies. Conditions such as cancer, stroke, heart disease and diabetes can be treated or prevented through early and regular use of diagnostics. But despite widespread recognition of their value, diagnostic services have suffered from chronic under-investment within health-care systems, and slow or even non-availability of in vitro diagnostic tests in mainstream medicine.

The message of  "the earlier and the more targeted, the better" has become better understood with the success of AI and machine learning, and the power of big data. Diagnostics' true value is thus becoming more visible, and the importance of early diagnosis is being elevated in initiatives like the NHS Long Term Plan. The LTP states that by 2021, pathology networks will deliver quicker test turnaround times and improved access to more complex tests at less overall cost.

In vitro diagnostics are the biggest subsegment of world medtech market of $426bn in 2018, accounting for almost $55.4bn, driven by testing for cancer, diabetes, HIV and other sexually-transmitted dieseases, and malaria, according to Fortune Business Insights.  By 2021, the overall in vitro diagnotics market will have risen to $70bn, according to a 2019 global industry outlook   white paper from IQVIA Medtech.

The MDR And Brexit

The end of 2019 proved busy for EU regulators, having agreed to another delay to the UK's Brexit to 31 January 2020 (which will be enacted by that date in the wake of the UK general election - see above), and still having to face the EU Medical Device Regulation's (MDR) ambitious timetable. But in a welcome show of flexibility, as reported, the EU delayed Eudamed by two years until 2022, for products of all risk classes, and mooted a corrigendum on Class I up-classified devices in early 2020 - allowing certain class I devices to qualify for the four-year MDD extension that the higher risk classes enjoy.

What happens in 2020 is in the gift of the European Commission. The general view is that the EU is prone to pushing things to the last moment, so it is likely that more of the three-year MDR transition until 26 May 2020 will be eroded before any more contingencies are offered. But with the timing too tight, the consequence could be a raft of products needed by patients coming off the EU market on 26 May.

The UK Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) no longer has a voice at EU level; the Brexit vote has meant the UK has not been attending EU meetings or been included on early EU planning. One school of thinking sees that as regrettable, given that the MDR is the biggest hurdle and biggest change for the EU medtech industry since the early 1990s, when the first European Economic Community directives began to emerge. The negatives that the MDR has attracted have so far overshadowed its good elements, notably unique device identification and Eudamed, among other benefits.

Ed Rozynski, senior international advisor at the US Medical Device Manufacturers Association (MDMA), says that the MDR is a front-and-center issue for the MDMA's member companies in the US. He fears that companies and/or products might disappear, and that it could impact the availability of products at health-care providers. "We want it to be seen as a public health bottleneck, not just a regulatory bottleneck," he said. US trade officials have suggested that the US could help build notified body capacity. A trigger for EU intervention could be supply chain shortages at hospitals, which would quickly lead to a political solution. Rozynski believes that, in the end, the regulations won't change until the deadline is reached, or very soon before.

And on Brexit, which has been the No. 1 concern of new MHRA director of devices Graeme Tunbridge, making predictions has so far proved pointless. The fears of industry persist, and industry associations are very busy, but Brexit's effects on business and regulation remain an ongoing uncertainty. Rozynski speculated in late October that a post-Brexit trade agreement with the US could be made within three or four months and could "build bridges between two like-minded regulatory authorities."

US Tax And China Bumps In The Road

With 2019 elapsing quickly, the US 2.3% excise tax is still an ongoing issue for the US MDMA and wider US industry. It wants it removed permanently. It is more likely that temporary fixes will still be the reality. The US industry should know the fate of the tax by by mid-January 2020, which is when the first of the fortnightly tax demands would start to be made. The tax was suspended between 2016 and 2019. The MDMA is not alone in working on a solution for industry; AdvaMed wrote to US President Donald Trump in mid-October soliciting his support for a permanent repeal of the medical device tax.

The China-US trade tariffs dispute has made it harder for US buyers to secure Chinese-made devices. No end to the stand-off is in sight. The US might investigate alternative sources from low-cost sources, such as Mexico, Costa Rica and South-East Asia. 

Big M&A Deals In Medtech In 2019

M&A spending increased in the 12 months to June 2019, reports EY, but the uplift came from a larger number of smaller deals. The 2019 batch of major, disclosed, deals reveals significant spending from a limited number of acquirers.

The eyecatching deal-makers were: 3M Co., with $7.7bn-worth of spending in two major deals; Stryker, whose deal to buy   Wright Medical Group NV for $4bn will result in the combination of the third- and ninth-largest orthopedic groups; (   "Stryker Goes Shoulder To Shoulder With Wright Medical In $4Bn Takeover" "Medtech Insight") and   Exact Sciences Corp., a colorectal cancer diagnostics and services company, in purchasing   Genomic Health Inc.. Exact Sciences had sales of just $1.8m in 2014, rising swiftly to $454m in 2018, spurred by a US ACS recommendation that colorectal cancer screening should begin at the lower age of 45 (previously 50). 

Deal numbers are currently smaller, on average, and valuations getting higher. Medtechs are seemingly prioritizing tuck-ins and portfolio optimization, rather than opting for larger, more adventurous targets. The largest M&A deals in the first ten months of 2019 were as follows:

Robotics Market Growth Tempts Innovators

Competition in robotics is picking up, as many want a bigger piece of the action that the robotics pioneer Intuitive Surgical Inc. notably has done so much to create. They also know that space is limited in a market with very high entry barriers, hence the rapid attention to targeted M&A in the past two to three years.   CMR Surgical Ltd., Verb Surgical,   Olympus Corp.,   Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd.,   TransEnterix Inc. and Wego Holding Co., all serious contenders, now have even greater competition from   Medtronic PLC, with its Hugo RAS system that will rival Intuitive's da Vinci system in gynecologic, urologic, cardiothoracic surgery, head and neck and general surgery.

The market for robotic assisted minimally-invasive surgery systems is growing at some 20% annually and is worth about $4bn, according to Medtronic. The global market for robotic-assisted surgery systems is expected to reach $5.3bn by 2021. ("NASS2019 Robotics Spotlight Is On New Platforms By Globus MedicalNuVasive" "Medtech Insight") The large-scale move into robotics is a further illustration of how medtechs in 2019-20 are becoming immersed in disruptive technologies. (   "Stryker Closes Gap With Competitors In Strategic Spinal Robotics Acquisition" "Medtech Insight")

Medtronic also markets the Mazor robotic system for spine surgery. NuVasive Inc. and   Globus Medical Inc. are now developing orthopedics platforms, and   Auris Medical Holding AG (see table above) is also expected to compete with Intuitive in robotic-assisted bronchoscope devices with its endoluminal system for minimally-invasive biopsies in the peripheral lung. It follows   DePuy Synthes' purchase of   Orthotaxy SAS's robotic technology for orthopedics in 2018, which was seen as its belated entry into the sector.   

Siemens Healthineers AG and   Johnson & Johnson made the largest robotics M&A deals in 2019. Stryker was in there too, with the acquisition of Mobius Robotics.

Eternal Factors That Will Drive The Market In 2020-2030

For these larger medtech players, while the markets around them are subject to radical change and their core business will continue to be defined by major trends. There are six eternal factors that medtechs must address to ensure continuity of business and sales growth:

Demographics. Medtechs must find the opportunities that arise on the back of the growing, aging global population, given that demand for cost-efficient health-care solutions will continue to intensify;

Emerging countries. These represent new market opportunities, but securing a balanced portfolio geographically is something even industry leader Medtronic has not mastered fully. As global affluence grows in tandem with awareness of the benefits of healthcare, greater opportunities for medtechs to invest in private and public health-care systems will appear;

Long-term conditions. These continue to rise in importance as a function of demographic change and lifestyle-related issues;

Health-care providers. These are transforming and consolidating, and at the same time are introducing new remuneration models for health-care services, with valued-based health-care concepts becoming slowly but surely more central. Digitization and artificial intelligence are likely to be key enablers for health-care providers;

Readiness and the ability to take new the opportunities that are emerging. The range spans robotics; M&A opportunities; big data approaches to research and commercialization opportunities offered by digital, AI, and machine learning; the tighter regulatory climate in many parts of the world, from the EU, to Asean countries to the EAEU bloc; the ever-present threat of public scrutiny; the fact that prevention and early diagnosis are receiving more than mere lip service now; targeted therapy; the move towards home-based care and away from the inpatient setting; and the change in attitudes to business in general that will be ushered in by the millennial generation as they begin to occupy senior medtech management posts; and above all 

Overall patient experience. As Eric Thépaut said at the MTF 2019 (above), this must continue to be enhanced to provide better outcomes accompanied by an overall reduction in the cost of care. In his words: "The bottom line is that it should now be more about providing value for patients." 

By Ashley Yeo

urn:contentItem:5T56-WF21-JB20-G08X-00000-00MTP DAILY August 30, 20182018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMTP DAILY5:00 PM ESTBrad Todd, Sahil Kapur, Daniella Gibbs Leger, Kara Swisher, Julia Ainsley, Jaime Diaz, Brad Todd, Sahil Kapur, Daniella Gibbs LegerNEWSInternational083001cb.454MTP DAILY August 30, 2018Chuck Todd

President Trump renews his attacks against the press, claiming his interview, where he admits to firing James Comey because of the Russia probe, was fudged. President Trump hints he fired his White House Counsel for reportedly cooperating with the Special Counsel amid growing talks of replacing Attorney General Jeff Sessions after the midterm elections. President Trump goes after Google, claiming the giant tech company is suppressing conservative voices in its search results. U.S. denying passports to Americans at the border is `part of broader crackdown.` The Trump administration is questioning Americans birth certificates. Meet the Midterms -- Nixon and Cuomo go toe-to-toe in New York Democratic gubernatorial debate. President Trump says the Mueller probe is `illegal`.

KATY TUR, MSNBC HOST: My thanks to all of you guys, Matt Miller, Jen Palmieri, Charlie Sykes, Jonathan Capehart. It has been a memorable one.

That will do it for this hour. I`m Katy Tur, again, in for Nicolle Wallace. "MTP DAILY" starts right now with Chuck Todd.

Hi, Chuck. Hello.

CHUCK TODD, MSNBC HOST: Katy Tur.

TUR: Charles.

TODD: How are you? I see -- look, that`s what Pete does to me. By the way, next time, if Pete Williams ever does a Katharine on you, just call him Lewis.

TUR: You know, I had someone online yesterday say, I was surprised to find out that Katharine was your full name. And I said, really?

TODD: Well --

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: Yes. Is it that hard to figure out?

TUR: Well, apparently.

TODD: It`s like, oh, you`re a Charles? Yes, most Chucks are.

TUR: Yes.

TODD: Yes.

TUR: Katy, Katharine. What are you going to do?

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: All right. Thank you, Katy.

TUR: You bet.

TODD: If it`s Thursday, it`s the eye of the tweetstorm.

Good evening. I`m Chuck Todd here in Washington and welcome to MTP DAILY. If it`s Thursday, the President is making assertions that, to some, come across as paranoid, conspiratorial, full of projection, and at times, a bit Orwellian.

And if that isn`t concerning enough, we`re learning that some of the most important people whose jobs are to act as a guardrail against the President`s behavior or instincts are leaving, giving up, rationalizing it, or simply being ousted.

Folks, that is a recipe for bad things getting worse. So let`s dive in. The President today all but said reject the evidence of your eyes and ears. He suggested, without evidence, because there is none, that part of the tape of him on camera in that interview with my colleague, Lester Holt, was fudged, as he puts it.

OK. Not true. You might remember that was the interview where the President said, yes, he fired James Comey in part because of the Russia investigation. That was just one baseless allegation in a series of baseless allegations about the press, books, tapes, journalistic sources, and news executives that he claims are all conspiring against him.

The President, also, went after a top Justice Department official by claiming that this official was involved in some kind of Russian collusion and should be fired because of it.

The President suggested that he ousted his White House Counsel, Don McGahn, just 24 hours after saying McGahn was leaving on his own accord.

Folks, McGahn was a key check on some of the President`s impulsiveness. McGahn also testified to Bob Mueller extensively about his boss`s impulses, which reportedly included at least two attempts to fire Mueller.

So yesterday, we learned that McGahn is leaving. Today, we learned that the White House ethics lawyer is out effective tomorrow. And it looks as if the Attorney General is likely going to be ousted after the midterms according to several top Senate Republicans.

And amid it all, we`re hearing some Senate Republicans either shrug their shoulders or tell themselves that Hillary Clinton would be more corrupt or that the President is just too inept to commit a crime like conspiring with Russia.

Let`s bring in tonight`s panel. Sahil Kapur is a national political reporter with Bloomberg News. And they had a big interview with the President a few minutes ago, so we get some scoop there.

Daniella Gibbs Leger, a senior vice president for the Center for American Progress.

And Brad Todd is a Republican strategist and ad maker. I haven`t seen you in a while. Welcome back.

BRAD TODD, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Thanks a lot.

TODD: All right, Sahil, the President -- let`s get to the quick news here -- making quick headlines. I guess the biggest one is Jeff Sessions` job is safe for 60 days.

SAHIL KAPUR, NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That`s correct, at least 60 days. The President would not comment when my colleagues asked him what would happen to the Attorney General after that, but there`s widespread speculation, given the President`s very public attacks on his A.G., that his job may not last beyond that.

Now, Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, said earlier this week he has total confidence in Jeff Sessions and he should stay exactly where he is. That is a signal that McConnell doesn`t want anything to mess with the Kavanaugh hearings.

And the second things is, who do you put in his place if you get rid of Jeff Sessions? It`s a 50 to 49 Senate right now. Some of those Republicans are not going to be comfortable supporting another A.G. unless they promise to protect the Russia investigation and the Mueller probe, which is precisely why it seems the President wants Sessions gone. So it`s hard to know, you know, what the end game is here.

TODD: Let me underscore this midterm issue, though, Daniella and Brad, because I think the voters are going to have a say as to the future of Jeff Sessions. Meaning this, my theory is if somehow Democrats win the Senate, that actually might change Republicans` calculations in the Senate. If somehow they won the Senate.

Brad, is that a fair -- that, all of a sudden, you`d have a different set of -- because, right now, you have a bunch of Republican senators that are going, look, he`s popular with the base.

B. TODD: Well, it wasn`t widely noted last fall when Charles Grassley, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, sent out a tweet that that said I have no time to schedule any Attorney General confirmation hearings this year.

Some people may have noted that, last week, he said that now he does have some time. And he changed --

TODD: Yes. And he`s got a separate beef.

B. TODD: He does.

TODD: He does have a separate beef with the --

B. TODD: He does. But you can`t have a new Attorney General until you have hearings to confirm a new Attorney General, and you can`t do it on the floor until you have a majority leader willing to schedule a vote on the floor.

So even if the did want to fire Jeff Sessions, he`s going to be replaced with Rod Rosenstein. And so the -- and until the Senate Republicans decide that they think it`s time.

TODD: So is that -- that`s why it feels as if, at the end of the day, Mitch McConnell is a calculator. And I mean that as a compliment. He reads the tea leaves. And it`s about being in power. And if he`s not in power, he wants to figure out why he was not in power.

DANIELLA GIBBS LEGER, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR COMMUNICATIONS AND STRATEGY, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS: Yes.

TODD: And he would probably only have one person to blame if he`s not Senate majority leader this election year.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes, I think that`s right. You know, look, Donald Trump hasn`t listened to Mitch McConnell in the past either because I`m pretty sure Mitch McConnell did not want him to nominate Brett Kavanaugh for a host of reasons. So I don`t know how that`s going to play into his calculus.

I think, you know, we`ve already said what comes after Jeff Sessions. Donald Trump is not somebody who strikes me as someone who thinks down the line, so he very much just deals with impulses. And his impulse is at I want to get rid of this person who should never have recused himself from the Russian investigation in the first place.

So, you know, he is putting Republicans in a really tight bind. And you`re right, I think the voters are going to really speak very loudly -- I think you hear it happening already in these primary elections -- that they don`t like what`s happening.

TODD: But I guess I`d flipped it this way. If Republicans hold the Senate, even if they lose 50 House seats, Brad, which -- that calculus is not out of the question, right? Republicans could gain a seat, and Democrats could win 50 House seats. And you can --

B. TODD: Probably win three or four.

TODD: Yes, right, they may.

KAPUR: Yes, they may.

B. TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

TODD: If Trump has the cocoon of protection of a Republican Senate, right, that`s -- nothing in the House sort of changes his calculus.

B. TODD: Well, in a polarized country, control of the Senate is really important because it`s how you see the government.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: You confirm judges. You confirm cabinet secretaries. It`s how you can -- are able to control the personnel in your own government, so the control of the Senate is a big deal.

And I think that getting a larger amount of control of the Senate is going to become a bigger and bigger priority of Republicans as we get closer to the election, and they see a lot more challengers who have shots. It gives you a little blanket, too, for 2020.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes. I mean, I think that`s really important. But if the Democrats take back the House, there`s actually going to be oversight happening on this President.

TODD: No doubt.

GIBBS LEGER: There are actually going to be hearings, and they`re going to have subpoena power and all of this. So I don`t -- you know, I think, yes, having the Senate will still be a check or a blanket for the President, but if Democrats win back the House, he is going to have to -- like, there is going to be reckoning that`s going to happen.

KAPUR: The Senate is --

B. TODD: Every receipt for every holiday in every vendor they will take, at least.

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: There you go. That`s right.

KAPUR: The Senate is enormously consequential because of the issue of appointments. Everyone who President wants to appoint to a cabinet position or, you know, a federal position that is confirmable by the Senate would have to go through Chuck Schumer`s desk if the Democrats win two seats in November.

Now, judges, probably the most significant, most successful project of the Trump presidency. He got a 60th judge this week. He`s got 33 on the district courts, 26 on the appellate courts, one Supreme Court justice already. He`s got more eight more district judges coming next week, and a Supreme Court judge in the pipeline.

Imagine the difference if it`s Chuck Schumer rather than Mitch McConnell looking at these personal appointees. It would be a massive complexion change.

TODD: Daniella, this has a side note.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

TODD: Your party didn`t have a project, actually, that cares about the judiciary the way the conservative movement does. Are you starting to regret that?

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: My gosh.

GIBBS LEGER: Probably yes. I think --

TODD: I mean, they had sort of a very organized effort.

KAPUR: Yes.

TODD: I mean, it`s been something.

GIBBS LEGER: I mean, if I was in charge --

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: -- if I had all the moneys, yes, I would -- this should be --

TODD: But this has never been a liberal priority, has it?

GIBBS LEGER: And, you know, it`s something I`ve been talking about with my colleagues a lot. You know, at the Center for American Progress, we actually do have a project called "Why Courts Matter," so we understand the importance of the judiciary.

I don`t understand why it isn`t something that gets Democrats and progressives out like it does on the right. And money is a part of it. You guys put millions and millions of dollars into these fights, and our side just doesn`t do that.

KAPUR: Progressives were furious this week, by the way, when Senate Democrats agreed to fast-track votes on seven of Trump`s judges.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

KAPUR: Seven all within about an hour, so seven of them confirmed. That`s a huge deal.

TODD: I saw.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

TODD: By the way, what does Chuck Schumer do? Yes, go ahead.

B. TODD: And in the year 2030, there will be virtually no one in the current Senate still there, Donald Trump probably will be dead, and Neil Gorsuch will still be on the Supreme Court.

KAPUR: Long after President --

TODD: Right, Neil Gorsuch.

GIBBS LEGER: But all these --

TODD: How many of these judges?

GIBBS LEGER: Yes, all 60 of them.

TODD: Yes.

KAPUR: Long after Trump`s presidency fades into history, they`ll be making --

GIBBS LEGER: It`s so consequential.

B. TODD: Yes.

KAPUR: They`ll be becoming decisions. Almost all of them, I should add, are in their 40s and 50s.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

KAPUR: Most of them have been vetted by the Federalist Society. These are very conservative people who will be making decisions for a long time.

TODD: I need to -- we have a whole bunch of other mini news items that the President made in this Bloomberg interview, so let me just resuscitate some of them.

He says an E.U. proposal to animate auto tariffs, not good enough.

He says getting Canada into the new NAFTA -- I guess he doesn`t want to call it NAFTA, he calls it into -- the trade deal. It`ll be by Friday or within a period of time but it will come. It does feel as if the Canadians are circling that.

He says he does not regret appointing Jerome Powell as Fed Chair, even though he`s been upset about the interest rate decisions.

And he says he is thinking of linking capital gains taxes to inflation, which would be a massive tax cut for a lot of people. Would it not, Brad? Like that`s something --

B. TODD: God created Republicans to cut taxes.

TODD: So that`s what --

KAPUR: By themselves or without --

(LAUGHTER)

KAPUR: -- without congressional approval, though?

TODD: So none of those headlines are -- let me -- real quick, though, on getting a new NAFTA. He`s had a horrendous summer. There`s not a lot of good headlines, child separation -- you start going down with July. You know, Scott Pruitt happened in July. I was, like, for many people, that was last month.

But getting a new trade deal, getting a new NAFTA. That`s not a -- you know, it looks a lot like old NAFTA.

KAPUR: Right.

TODD: But at least he`s going to say, I did it.

KAPUR: He`s very eager for a victory on NAFTA. He doesn`t have much on the deliverable end on the issue of trade other than tariffs that have hurt -- you know, or that are making a number of members of his own party nervous, that are hurting Republican Senate candidates in places like Tennessee and Missouri. And, I think, North Dakota as well.

So I think he wants a victory. He at least wants to rename NAFTA --

B. TODD: Yes, yes.

KAPUR: -- and get the P.R. value of saying, I put my stamp on it. Beyond that, we don`t know what the details are going to be. There are some negotiations still happening with the Mexicans.

TODD: Sure.

KAPUR: The Canadians seem to be moving forward on this. But we -- there`s more questions than answers right now.

TODD: There`s no doubt the Canadians don`t want -- like, you could --

B. TODD: To be left out.

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: They don`t want --

TODD: Well, and the same time, they`d love to stand up to him but they can`t afford it.

B. TODD: I don`t --

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

B. TODD: I don`t want to -- I think we should understand how important the trade deal renegotiations are to the new coalition that, I think, has been forming not just because of President Trump, but he`s a product of that reformation.

You know, I`m from a town in east Tennessee that had two hosiery mills and a paper mill and a steel mill as a kid. They`re all gone.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: And for a lot of people there, they would tell you that trade deals that we had in the past two decades were part of that equation. And the last two presidents didn`t do anything to change the course of where we were headed on trade.

And so I think for a lot of people that`s been in the middle of the country and even blue-collar cities on the east coast will tell you this is a pretty big deal.

GIBBS LEGER: I know. The proof is going to be in the pudding, right? It`s all about the details. So he has maybe a minor P.R. win right now, but we`ll see what happens. And if this trade deal really is something that benefits the American worker, or like the tax deal, is it going to benefit the wealthiest?

And I`m sorry, after North Korea, I, you know, really don`t believe the hype when it comes out of this White House and its people.

TODD: All right, let me bring up one other political thing that the President did today. He sort of bragged about the fact that he`s not going to give a pay raise to federal workers. Politically, Brad, I get that not a single -- the base said, great, yes, screw the government.

B. TODD: I think he`s writing off Virginia.

TODD: Yes. Well, but this --

GIBBS LEGER: Not just Virginia, you know.

TODD: Yes, not just Virginia. I mean, it is sort of you have -- we don`t have it in the budget, he said. You could do the $1.6 trillion tax cut and you can`t do this? Again, how good of politics is it to bash government?

B. TODD: This was --

TODD: I mean, I hate to be this cynical.

B. TODD: Well, first of --

TODD: Is this a cynical decision --

B. TODD: First off, the Congress will decide it, not him, in the end. And I think that the public doesn`t trust government right now, either party. There are plenty of people in the Republican coalition who trust Donald Trump more than they trust Republicans in Congress.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: And this is an example of him being a disrupter and trying to say that he -- whether he actually does it or not, he is proving --

TODD: Do you think that is another one of those things, don`t believe it?

B. TODD: He is proving he is willing to say things people won`t say and that he`s not taking cues from other people in Washington.

TODD: He doesn`t necessarily do what he says on that one.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

KAPUR: And how does this affect someone like Barbara Comstock who`s running for Congress in a tough re-election in D.C.?

GIBBS LEGER: Exactly.

TODD: I think he just --

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Actually, he did better --

B. TODD: -- Virginia in 2020.

GIBBS LEGER: I mean, her opponent already put out --

B. TODD: That tells me Virginia in 2020 for his own race is what I`m sure he`s thinking about rather than that.

TODD: Well, there -- I think he realizes Virginia -- it may be a swing state again, not in the Trump era. I think that`s fair to say.

GIBBS LEGER: Right. I mean, Barbara Comstock`s opponent already put out a press release about it. And it`s not just Virginia. There are lots of states where there are lots of civilian employees that are going to be really hurt by this.

KAPUR: Yes, this is a matter of priorities. I mean, the President decided that he -- that the United States didn`t have the money and could borrow the money for a big increase in military spending and did have, you know, funds in the Treasury to offer tax breaks. But on this one, he --

TODD: Let`s be crass.

B. TODD: He called an increase on the military --

TODD: Let`s be crass, let`s be crass. There is not a single vote that he would get if he somehow said, I`m giving a raise to all federal government workers.

B. TODD: Not a single vote he would gain.

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

B. TODD: But the military vote does help him.

TODD: Well, and that`s --

B. TODD: Because a part of the federal workforce that identifies with Republicans is military.

TODD: Right. Which is why the rest of the federal workforce is probably getting a raise because they`ll not separate the two, is my guess, which is probably right. Congress won`t distinguish.

KAPUR: And it`s about priorities. The money is there, clearly. He just wants to spend it on certain things and not other things.

GIBBS LEGER: Exactly.

TODD: All right, guys. We`ll take a break here. You guys get to stick around.

Up ahead, inside President Trump`s war on Google.

Plus, a new outage -- outrage at the border. Why are more and more Hispanic American citizens being denied their passports?

TODD: Welcome back. Another entry in a long pattern for President Trump. When his opponents attacked him in 2016, he gave them labels. So he labeled them Lying Ted, Crooked Hillary. When the news media publishes stories he doesn`t like, he cries fake news, enemy of the people.

And now, this week, the President has decided to go after Google for, in his words, suppressing conservative voices in its search results.

The President tweeted, quote, Google search results for Trump news shows only the viewing/reporting of fake news media. In other words, they have it rigged for me and others so that almost all bad -- stories and news is bad. They are controlling what we can and cannot see. This is a very serious situation. Will be addressed.

The President also tweeted a video in which he accused the search engine of highlighting President Obama`s state of the union addresses but not his own.

Google responded by saying, wrong, that they did, in fact, highlight President Trump`s state of the union address this year. Not so last year for a very good reason. The speech President Trump gave to Congress in 2017 was not a state of the union address.

None of them are when you give them in the first year in office.

Joining me now is Kara Swisher. She is the executive editor of the technology news Web site, Recode.
