KATY TUR, MSNBC HOST: My thanks to all of you guys, Matt Miller, Jen Palmieri, Charlie Sykes, Jonathan Capehart. It has been a memorable one.

That will do it for this hour. I'm Katy Tur, again, in for Nicolle Wallace. "MTP DAILY" starts right now with Chuck Todd.

Hi, Chuck. Hello.

CHUCK TODD, MSNBC HOST: Katy Tur.

TUR: Charles.

TODD: How are you? I see -- look, that's what Pete does to me. By the way, next time, if Pete Williams ever does a Katharine on you, just call him Lewis.

TUR: You know, I had someone online yesterday say, I was surprised to find out that Katharine was your full name. And I said, really?

TODD: Well --

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: Yes. Is it that hard to figure out?

TUR: Well, apparently.

TODD: It's like, oh, you're a Charles? Yes, most Chucks are.

TUR: Yes.

TODD: Yes.

TUR: Katy, Katharine. What are you going to do?

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: All right. Thank you, Katy.

TUR: You bet.

TODD: If it's Thursday, it's the eye of the tweetstorm.

Good evening. I'm Chuck Todd here in Washington and welcome to MTP DAILY. If it's Thursday, the President is making assertions that, to some, come across as paranoid, conspiratorial, full of projection, and at times, a bit Orwellian.

And if that isn't concerning enough, we're learning that some of the most important people whose jobs are to act as a guardrail against the President's behavior or instincts are leaving, giving up, rationalizing it, or simply being ousted.

Folks, that is a recipe for bad things getting worse. So let's dive in. The President today all but said reject the evidence of your eyes and ears. He suggested, without evidence, because there is none, that part of the tape of him on camera in that interview with my colleague, Lester Holt, was fudged, as he puts it.

OK. Not true. You might remember that was the interview where the President said, yes, he fired James Comey in part because of the Russia investigation. That was just one baseless allegation in a series of baseless allegations about the press, books, tapes, journalistic sources, and news executives that he claims are all conspiring against him.

The President, also, went after a top Justice Department official by claiming that this official was involved in some kind of Russian collusion and should be fired because of it.

The President suggested that he ousted his White House Counsel, Don McGahn, just 24 hours after saying McGahn was leaving on his own accord.

Folks, McGahn was a key check on some of the President's impulsiveness. McGahn also testified to Bob Mueller extensively about his boss's impulses, which reportedly included at least two attempts to fire Mueller.

So yesterday, we learned that McGahn is leaving. Today, we learned that the White House ethics lawyer is out effective tomorrow. And it looks as if the Attorney General is likely going to be ousted after the midterms according to several top Senate Republicans.

And amid it all, we're hearing some Senate Republicans either shrug their shoulders or tell themselves that Hillary Clinton would be more corrupt or that the President is just too inept to commit a crime like conspiring with Russia.

Let's bring in tonight's panel. Sahil Kapur is a national political reporter with Bloomberg News. And they had a big interview with the President a few minutes ago, so we get some scoop there.

Daniella Gibbs Leger, a senior vice president for the Center for American Progress.

And Brad Todd is a Republican strategist and ad maker. I haven't seen you in a while. Welcome back.

BRAD TODD, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Thanks a lot.

TODD: All right, Sahil, the President -- let's get to the quick news here -- making quick headlines. I guess the biggest one is Jeff Sessions' job is safe for 60 days.

SAHIL KAPUR, NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's correct, at least 60 days. The President would not comment when my colleagues asked him what would happen to the Attorney General after that, but there's widespread speculation, given the President's very public attacks on his A.G., that his job may not last beyond that.

Now, Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, said earlier this week he has total confidence in Jeff Sessions and he should stay exactly where he is. That is a signal that McConnell doesn't want anything to mess with the Kavanaugh hearings.

And the second things is, who do you put in his place if you get rid of Jeff Sessions? It's a 50 to 49 Senate right now. Some of those Republicans are not going to be comfortable supporting another A.G. unless they promise to protect the Russia investigation and the Mueller probe, which is precisely why it seems the President wants Sessions gone. So it's hard to know, you know, what the end game is here.

TODD: Let me underscore this midterm issue, though, Daniella and Brad, because I think the voters are going to have a say as to the future of Jeff Sessions. Meaning this, my theory is if somehow Democrats win the Senate, that actually might change Republicans' calculations in the Senate. If somehow they won the Senate.

Brad, is that a fair -- that, all of a sudden, you'd have a different set of -- because, right now, you have a bunch of Republican senators that are going, look, he's popular with the base.

B. TODD: Well, it wasn't widely noted last fall when Charles Grassley, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, sent out a tweet that that said I have no time to schedule any Attorney General confirmation hearings this year.

Some people may have noted that, last week, he said that now he does have some time. And he changed --

TODD: Yes. And he's got a separate beef.

B. TODD: He does.

TODD: He does have a separate beef with the --

B. TODD: He does. But you can't have a new Attorney General until you have hearings to confirm a new Attorney General, and you can't do it on the floor until you have a majority leader willing to schedule a vote on the floor.

So even if the did want to fire Jeff Sessions, he's going to be replaced with Rod Rosenstein. And so the -- and until the Senate Republicans decide that they think it's time.

TODD: So is that -- that's why it feels as if, at the end of the day, Mitch McConnell is a calculator. And I mean that as a compliment. He reads the tea leaves. And it's about being in power. And if he's not in power, he wants to figure out why he was not in power.

DANIELLA GIBBS LEGER, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR COMMUNICATIONS AND STRATEGY, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS: Yes.

TODD: And he would probably only have one person to blame if he's not Senate majority leader this election year.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes, I think that's right. You know, look, Donald Trump hasn't listened to Mitch McConnell in the past either because I'm pretty sure Mitch McConnell did not want him to nominate Brett Kavanaugh for a host of reasons. So I don't know how that's going to play into his calculus.

I think, you know, we've already said what comes after Jeff Sessions. Donald Trump is not somebody who strikes me as someone who thinks down the line, so he very much just deals with impulses. And his impulse is at I want to get rid of this person who should never have recused himself from the Russian investigation in the first place.

So, you know, he is putting Republicans in a really tight bind. And you're right, I think the voters are going to really speak very loudly -- I think you hear it happening already in these primary elections -- that they don't like what's happening.

TODD: But I guess I'd flipped it this way. If Republicans hold the Senate, even if they lose 50 House seats, Brad, which -- that calculus is not out of the question, right? Republicans could gain a seat, and Democrats could win 50 House seats. And you can --

B. TODD: Probably win three or four.

TODD: Yes, right, they may.

KAPUR: Yes, they may.

B. TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

TODD: If Trump has the cocoon of protection of a Republican Senate, right, that's -- nothing in the House sort of changes his calculus.

B. TODD: Well, in a polarized country, control of the Senate is really important because it's how you see the government.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: You confirm judges. You confirm cabinet secretaries. It's how you can -- are able to control the personnel in your own government, so the control of the Senate is a big deal.

And I think that getting a larger amount of control of the Senate is going to become a bigger and bigger priority of Republicans as we get closer to the election, and they see a lot more challengers who have shots. It gives you a little blanket, too, for 2020.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes. I mean, I think that's really important. But if the Democrats take back the House, there's actually going to be oversight happening on this President.

TODD: No doubt.

GIBBS LEGER: There are actually going to be hearings, and they're going to have subpoena power and all of this. So I don't -- you know, I think, yes, having the Senate will still be a check or a blanket for the President, but if Democrats win back the House, he is going to have to -- like, there is going to be reckoning that's going to happen.

KAPUR: The Senate is --

B. TODD: Every receipt for every holiday in every vendor they will take, at least.

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: There you go. That's right.

KAPUR: The Senate is enormously consequential because of the issue of appointments. Everyone who President wants to appoint to a cabinet position or, you know, a federal position that is confirmable by the Senate would have to go through Chuck Schumer's desk if the Democrats win two seats in November.

Now, judges, probably the most significant, most successful project of the Trump presidency. He got a 60th judge this week. He's got 33 on the district courts, 26 on the appellate courts, one Supreme Court justice already. He's got more eight more district judges coming next week, and a Supreme Court judge in the pipeline.

Imagine the difference if it's Chuck Schumer rather than Mitch McConnell looking at these personal appointees. It would be a massive complexion change.

TODD: Daniella, this has a side note.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

TODD: Your party didn't have a project, actually, that cares about the judiciary the way the conservative movement does. Are you starting to regret that?

(LAUGHTER)

TODD: My gosh.

GIBBS LEGER: Probably yes. I think --

TODD: I mean, they had sort of a very organized effort.

KAPUR: Yes.

TODD: I mean, it's been something.

GIBBS LEGER: I mean, if I was in charge --

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: -- if I had all the moneys, yes, I would -- this should be --

TODD: But this has never been a liberal priority, has it?

GIBBS LEGER: And, you know, it's something I've been talking about with my colleagues a lot. You know, at the Center for American Progress, we actually do have a project called "Why Courts Matter," so we understand the importance of the judiciary.

I don't understand why it isn't something that gets Democrats and progressives out like it does on the right. And money is a part of it. You guys put millions and millions of dollars into these fights, and our side just doesn't do that.

KAPUR: Progressives were furious this week, by the way, when Senate Democrats agreed to fast-track votes on seven of Trump's judges.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

KAPUR: Seven all within about an hour, so seven of them confirmed. That's a huge deal.

TODD: I saw.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

TODD: By the way, what does Chuck Schumer do? Yes, go ahead.

B. TODD: And in the year 2030, there will be virtually no one in the current Senate still there, Donald Trump probably will be dead, and Neil Gorsuch will still be on the Supreme Court.

KAPUR: Long after President --

TODD: Right, Neil Gorsuch.

GIBBS LEGER: But all these --

TODD: How many of these judges?

GIBBS LEGER: Yes, all 60 of them.

TODD: Yes.

KAPUR: Long after Trump's presidency fades into history, they'll be making --

GIBBS LEGER: It's so consequential.

B. TODD: Yes.

KAPUR: They'll be becoming decisions. Almost all of them, I should add, are in their 40s and 50s.

GIBBS LEGER: Yes.

KAPUR: Most of them have been vetted by the Federalist Society. These are very conservative people who will be making decisions for a long time.

TODD: I need to -- we have a whole bunch of other mini news items that the President made in this Bloomberg interview, so let me just resuscitate some of them.

He says an E.U. proposal to animate auto tariffs, not good enough.

He says getting Canada into the new NAFTA -- I guess he doesn't want to call it NAFTA, he calls it into -- the trade deal. It'll be by Friday or within a period of time but it will come. It does feel as if the Canadians are circling that.

He says he does not regret appointing Jerome Powell as Fed Chair, even though he's been upset about the interest rate decisions.

And he says he is thinking of linking capital gains taxes to inflation, which would be a massive tax cut for a lot of people. Would it not, Brad? Like that's something --

B. TODD: God created Republicans to cut taxes.

TODD: So that's what --

KAPUR: By themselves or without --

(LAUGHTER)

KAPUR: -- without congressional approval, though?

TODD: So none of those headlines are -- let me -- real quick, though, on getting a new NAFTA. He's had a horrendous summer. There's not a lot of good headlines, child separation -- you start going down with July. You know, Scott Pruitt happened in July. I was, like, for many people, that was last month.

But getting a new trade deal, getting a new NAFTA. That's not a -- you know, it looks a lot like old NAFTA.

KAPUR: Right.

TODD: But at least he's going to say, I did it.

KAPUR: He's very eager for a victory on NAFTA. He doesn't have much on the deliverable end on the issue of trade other than tariffs that have hurt -- you know, or that are making a number of members of his own party nervous, that are hurting Republican Senate candidates in places like Tennessee and Missouri. And, I think, North Dakota as well.

So I think he wants a victory. He at least wants to rename NAFTA --

B. TODD: Yes, yes.

KAPUR: -- and get the P.R. value of saying, I put my stamp on it. Beyond that, we don't know what the details are going to be. There are some negotiations still happening with the Mexicans.

TODD: Sure.

KAPUR: The Canadians seem to be moving forward on this. But we -- there's more questions than answers right now.

TODD: There's no doubt the Canadians don't want -- like, you could --

B. TODD: To be left out.

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: They don't want --

TODD: Well, and the same time, they'd love to stand up to him but they can't afford it.

B. TODD: I don't --

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

B. TODD: I don't want to -- I think we should understand how important the trade deal renegotiations are to the new coalition that, I think, has been forming not just because of President Trump, but he's a product of that reformation.

You know, I'm from a town in east Tennessee that had two hosiery mills and a paper mill and a steel mill as a kid. They're all gone.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: And for a lot of people there, they would tell you that trade deals that we had in the past two decades were part of that equation. And the last two presidents didn't do anything to change the course of where we were headed on trade.

And so I think for a lot of people that's been in the middle of the country and even blue-collar cities on the east coast will tell you this is a pretty big deal.

GIBBS LEGER: I know. The proof is going to be in the pudding, right? It's all about the details. So he has maybe a minor P.R. win right now, but we'll see what happens. And if this trade deal really is something that benefits the American worker, or like the tax deal, is it going to benefit the wealthiest?

And I'm sorry, after North Korea, I, you know, really don't believe the hype when it comes out of this White House and its people.

TODD: All right, let me bring up one other political thing that the President did today. He sort of bragged about the fact that he's not going to give a pay raise to federal workers. Politically, Brad, I get that not a single -- the base said, great, yes, screw the government.

B. TODD: I think he's writing off Virginia.

TODD: Yes. Well, but this --

GIBBS LEGER: Not just Virginia, you know.

TODD: Yes, not just Virginia. I mean, it is sort of you have -- we don't have it in the budget, he said. You could do the $1.6 trillion tax cut and you can't do this? Again, how good of politics is it to bash government?

B. TODD: This was --

TODD: I mean, I hate to be this cynical.

B. TODD: Well, first of --

TODD: Is this a cynical decision --

B. TODD: First off, the Congress will decide it, not him, in the end. And I think that the public doesn't trust government right now, either party. There are plenty of people in the Republican coalition who trust Donald Trump more than they trust Republicans in Congress.

TODD: Right.

B. TODD: And this is an example of him being a disrupter and trying to say that he -- whether he actually does it or not, he is proving --

TODD: Do you think that is another one of those things, don't believe it?

B. TODD: He is proving he is willing to say things people won't say and that he's not taking cues from other people in Washington.

TODD: He doesn't necessarily do what he says on that one.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

KAPUR: And how does this affect someone like Barbara Comstock who's running for Congress in a tough re-election in D.C.?

GIBBS LEGER: Exactly.

TODD: I think he just --

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Actually, he did better --

B. TODD: -- Virginia in 2020.

GIBBS LEGER: I mean, her opponent already put out --

B. TODD: That tells me Virginia in 2020 for his own race is what I'm sure he's thinking about rather than that.

TODD: Well, there -- I think he realizes Virginia -- it may be a swing state again, not in the Trump era. I think that's fair to say.

GIBBS LEGER: Right. I mean, Barbara Comstock's opponent already put out a press release about it. And it's not just Virginia. There are lots of states where there are lots of civilian employees that are going to be really hurt by this.

KAPUR: Yes, this is a matter of priorities. I mean, the President decided that he -- that the United States didn't have the money and could borrow the money for a big increase in military spending and did have, you know, funds in the Treasury to offer tax breaks. But on this one, he --

TODD: Let's be crass.

B. TODD: He called an increase on the military --

TODD: Let's be crass, let's be crass. There is not a single vote that he would get if he somehow said, I'm giving a raise to all federal government workers.

B. TODD: Not a single vote he would gain.

TODD: Yes.

GIBBS LEGER: Right.

B. TODD: But the military vote does help him.

TODD: Well, and that's --

B. TODD: Because a part of the federal workforce that identifies with Republicans is military.

TODD: Right. Which is why the rest of the federal workforce is probably getting a raise because they'll not separate the two, is my guess, which is probably right. Congress won't distinguish.

KAPUR: And it's about priorities. The money is there, clearly. He just wants to spend it on certain things and not other things.

GIBBS LEGER: Exactly.

TODD: All right, guys. We'll take a break here. You guys get to stick around.

Up ahead, inside President Trump's war on Google.

Plus, a new outage -- outrage at the border. Why are more and more Hispanic American citizens being denied their passports?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Another entry in a long pattern for President Trump. When his opponents attacked him in 2016, he gave them labels. So he labeled them Lying Ted, Crooked Hillary. When the news media publishes stories he doesn't like, he cries fake news, enemy of the people.

And now, this week, the President has decided to go after Google for, in his words, suppressing conservative voices in its search results.

The President tweeted, quote, Google search results for Trump news shows only the viewing/reporting of fake news media. In other words, they have it rigged for me and others so that almost all bad -- stories and news is bad. They are controlling what we can and cannot see. This is a very serious situation. Will be addressed.

The President also tweeted a video in which he accused the search engine of highlighting President Obama's state of the union addresses but not his own.

Google responded by saying, wrong, that they did, in fact, highlight President Trump's state of the union address this year. Not so last year for a very good reason. The speech President Trump gave to Congress in 2017 was not a state of the union address.

None of them are when you give them in the first year in office.

Joining me now is Kara Swisher. She is the executive editor of the technology news Web site, Recode.

Kara, nice to see you.

KARA SWISHER, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, RECODE: How are you doing, Chuck?

TODD: All right. Let's start with the President's accusation.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: And then I want to go to something that I think he is touching on that actually is relevant to this conversation.

SWISHER: OK. Yes.

TODD: So, obviously, he's going after Google. And it's all part -- this is -- you know, Steve Bannon ranted about this a long time ago, big tech.

SWISHER: Yes, and he did also last week.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: He did a bunch last week and he's done it to Amazon -- Amazon, "Washington Post."

TODD: That's right. He is --

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: Part of it is maybe he doesn't understand the tech world.

SWISHER: No.

TODD: I think that's a big part of it, but the other part of it just feels ironic. It's like, is he saying that you guys must stink because I was able to manipulate your system and look what I did? I mean, I don't mean to be that cynical.

SWISHER: Yes, yes.

TODD: But is there any basis to his attack?

SWISHER: No, none whatsoever. And I'm not one to defend the tech industry, you know that. I'm sort of -- I'm very particular about certain things they've done, and I'm very interested in these hearings next week where a lot of the leaders are going to come with some of the problems they had with Cambridge Analytica and things like that.

But, in this case, he's completely wrong. He doesn't know what he's talking about.

TODD: I want to go to that state of the union attack because this is the problem that's happening on social media. The irony is -- and it's basically Twitter has allowed this to happen, whether they like it or not.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: Their platform has been used for this, which is -- and it's been regularly done. Matt Gaetz is a congressman that has done this. Kevin McCarthy is a congressman that has done this. Where they retweet stuff that they say, this is how they're biased against conservatives but it turned out to be fake accusations. Like, the fake accusations about state of the union, all these false accusations.

SWISHER: Yes, but it's beyond --

TODD: But it gets, like, 32,000 retweets.

SWISHER: Of course.

TODD: Or 50,000 likes. So people still believe it.

SWISHER: Well, you know, I wrote a column in "The New York Times" saying this is codswallop. But I just was -- I try to find a word that you could look up on Google very easily.

But the fact of the matter is, conservative voices are very loud on social media. So are liberal voices, so are crazy voices, so are comedians, and so is everyone. And this particular group of people has actually been advantaged by it because they were largely left out of the mainstream media until Fox News came along.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: Now, they have all these platforms to discuss things on. And there's been this sort of online rage-fest among them that they are not heard. And the line I used is, the people that talk loudest about not being heard never shut up. And I think we can all agree that Donald Trump uses Twitter quite a bit.

TODD: One of the mistakes we in the mainstream media made during -- when these false accusations against us being biased for 40 years happen is we started believing, well, maybe we are biased and we got to -- oh, wait, we can't look biased. So then we created a lot of false equivalency issues, OK.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: It looks to me like Silicon Valley is about to fall into that trap. How do they not fall into that trap?

SWISHER: By ignoring it completely. Look at what Jeff Bezos is doing every time he comes after him. He just doesn't say a word. I think Google has to just say this is not true and move along and stuff like that.

And, obviously, there, again, are issues that all these companies should face, you know, of things they have done but not this one.

TODD: All right. But I want to get into an issue that I actually thought Steve Bannon addressed very -- you know, in a -- he ranted at the end, but he, actually, I thought, touched on something that I've gotten into, which is, who's going to regulate the algorithms?

SWISHER: Right.

TODD: At the end of the day, they're not wrong that, these algorithms, none of us know what they have.

SWISHER: Right.

TODD: They have all of our information. Steve Bannon made a recommendation that I didn't think was a bad one, which was should our info at least be in a public trust of some sort that they can access all the time?

And we get that, but -- I buy what he's talking about there. At some point, we have to figure out how to regulate the algorithms so, at least, we know if they're being abused.

SWISHER: Well, no, I know. That's the problem, is you can't do that. That's such -- then make Google an entity of the government?

TODD: No, you wouldn't make it an entity of the government.

SWISHER: It's called Russia.

TODD: No, no, no. But it's --

SWISHER: It's called the Russian government.

TODD: Well, then how do we regulate an algorithm?

SWISHER: We don't. We don't.

TODD: Why?

SWISHER: Because they're big companies, and they are -- they're the ones in charge, just the way CBS used to be in charge of the airwaves.

TODD: OK. But if Google writes an algorithm that somehow directs -- all right, let me do a better one. Let's say one of the --

SWISHER: Facebook or any --

TODD: No, monster.com, like an employment site. And their algorithm seems to always leave out people of color as your job applicants.

SWISHER: Right, that's a different issue.

TODD: But that's my point. How do you --

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: You know, they could say, oh, we just wrote an algorithm, we didn't know it was going to do that.

SWISHER: Right. Well, I think the problem is who is making these things. That's one of the big issues being discussed with Silicon Valley, like A.I. You know, there's an -- you know, the old expression, crap in, crap out.

And so, you know, if certain people are the only ones designing that, what happens? But that's in the Internet. The Internet has largely been designed by the small group of people. That still doesn't mean you should have a government entity regulating any of that sort of thing.

TODD: All right, but let me go to a consumer thing, OK?

SWISHER: OK.

TODD: So I want to know that I am getting -- I am being treated as a consumer equally in the state of Texas as I am in the state of North Dakota.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: And if an Amazon algorithm decides, boy, in Texas, you have more money. You can afford to pay this because I know this by where you live and all this stuff than the north. Boy, I'm getting -- that's not fair as a consumer.

SWISHER: That's called marketing and retail for the past hundred years, so I don't know that can --

TODD: No. Well, I'm wondering -- I get it.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: But on the other hand, if there -- if it's unfair practices, how is it that we're going to --

SWISHER: Is it?

TODD: Well, why shouldn't it?

SWISHER: Why shouldn't it be? Well, here's the thing, privacy issues, yes. I think there's probably going to be a privacy bill, especially if the Democrats come into power. I'm absolutely certain there will be some sort of -- there's been one in California that's been somewhat controversial, but there will be a national privacy bill at some point given all these issues we're having.

TODD: Is it going to look like Europe?

SWISHER: I don't know. Probably not. I don't think U.S. regulators have ever been as strong as the ones in Europe. But, again, there's international issues too because the Europeans are doing something different, the Chinese will do something different. Everyone around the world in a global society will do something different.

TODD: What's next week going to look like for Twitter and Facebook?

SWISHER: Ah, I don't know. It depends who shows up. I mean, if we get Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg -- now, there's been calls to bring in Larry Page who was one of the founders of Google. It probably will be Sundar Pichai.

I think they're going to quiz them. I hope they don't quiz them on all these whether conservatives can speak up or whether anybody can speak out. They should talk about issues of the meddling in the elections. They should talk about privacy. They should talk about how did this -- how did their platforms get hijacked by the Russian government.

These are critical issues, not whether Donald Trump is loud enough on the Internet, which I think he is. I feel he has plenty of voice.

TODD: I was just going to say the Internet has been good to Donald Trump.

SWISHER: That's what I said, they -- Donald Trump should send tech a gold embossed thank you note for the things that it has done, giving him tools and all kinds of ways to get in office.

TODD: Right. So I guess, does the industry --

SWISHER: You want me to say you want to regulate --

TODD: No, no, no, no. But does the industry -- is it ready to come and say, hey, look, we know we've gotten this big and we need help figuring X out?

SWISHER: Right.

TODD: Are they ready to at least do that with the government?

SWISHER: I think they have to engage more with the government. But as you saw from the Zuckerberg hearings, the politicians really are almost clueless about technology.

TODD: It's embarrassing.

SWISHER: And it was embarrassing. And everyone used to say, oh, Mark did really well. I say, well, it's a very really low bar. So, no, he didn't, but they did badly.

TODD: I would love Mr. Zuckerberg to come here.

SWISHER: Well, I will ask him.

TODD: And I would -- no, they haven't. Like, none of them will stay, though.

SWISHER: None of them will?

TODD: Yes, I would love to be quizzed by some of those members of Congress, too.

SWISHER: Yes, yes. I would like members of Congress who actually know something about technology to do the quizzing, but that's, you know.

TODD: I think it's time to let them staffers do the quizzing and all.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: Do you expect any sort of -- I think Donald Trump, Jr. said, oh, we're going to have a conservative alternative. Is that plausible out there and realistic?

SWISHER: Sure, go ahead. They can do it. It's the big wide Internet.

TODD: Right, but is there anybody out there that actually could do it?

SWISHER: You know, there were rumors of Peter Thiel and Steve Bannon getting together. I keep hearing them getting together and creating their own. I'm sure there will be a digital element to it if they do it. There's all kinds of rumors around that.

Obviously, Fox News has digital elements. Are you kidding? There are so many conservative publications on the Internet now, Breitbart, all the others. They've had -- the Internet has been very, very good to them.

TODD: Yes.

SWISHER: So I don't know if they should complain quite so much.

TODD: I think their biggest complaint is called capitalism.

SWISHER: Yes.

TODD: Kara Swisher, thanks for coming on.

SWISHER: Thank you.

TODD: Much appreciated. Up ahead, the uproar over a new crackdown on Hispanic Americans that are American citizens. They're being denied passports or having their passports taken away.

But, first, it's the emotional tribute to Senator John McCain. Some 3,500 people gathered in a Phoenix church to honor McCain's life of service.

Twenty-four sitting U.S. senators attended that service. So did four former senators, including former Vice President Joe Biden who remembered Senator McCain as a leader who always put country before party.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: John was a hero. His character, courage, honor, integrity. But I think the thing that's understated the most is his optimism. That's what made John special. It made John a giant among all of us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Tonight I'm obsessed with President Trump's morning tweetstorm. More unusual than normal, even for him. Those tweets were a plague of defensive outbursts, baseless assertions and outright falsehoods, the kind of statements that have fact checkers working overtime or simply throwing up their hands.

But it got us wondering, what if in some Seinfeld-like Bizarro universe, President Trump tweeted the exact opposite of what he tweeted this morning? What would that look like? Hmm, would it be more believable if President Trump had tweeted something like this? When Lester Holt accurately played my tape on Russia, I was hurt badly.

Or how about this? Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner had everything to do with the pushing out of Don McGahn. The news media has it right. Has it so right. Or how about this one? The legitimate Russia investigation had everything to do with respect to my decision on Don McGahn.

And then another one on Don McGahn. I'm very excited about the person who will be taking the place of Don McGahn as White House counsel. I never liked Don, and he was responsible for me not firing Bob Mueller or Jeff Sessions. And finally, I just cannot state strongly enough how totally dishonest I am. Truth doesn't matter to me. I only have my hatred and agenda.

As Jerry Seinfeld and George Costanza, if every instinct you have is wrong, then the opposite would have to be right. Right?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. The Trump administration's crackdown along the Mexican border isn't just limited to people trying to come here illegally. Now a growing number of Hispanic-Americans are being denied passports because the government is questioning their citizenship.

The Washington Post reports that the Trump administration is accusing hundreds and possibly thousands of people of using fraudulent birth certificates since they were babies. The government alleges that some midwives and physicians along the border gave U.S. birth certificates to people who were actually born in Mexico decades ago.

In a statement to The Washington Post, the State Department said it "has not changed policy or practice regarding the adjudication of passport applications and the U.S.-Mexico border region happens to be an area of the country where there has been a significant incidence of citizenship fraud."

It's true that this happened under George W. Bush and the Obama administrations too, but that mostly ended after a government settlement in 2009. This news as taking away people's citizenship is on the rise under President Trump.

And to try to understand this piece and this issue a little better, I'm joined now by NBC News national security and justice reporter Julia Ainsley and Attorney Jaime Diaz who represents some of the U.S. citizens who have been either denied passports or had them taken away. Welcome to both of you.

Julia, let me start with you. When did this begin? How pervasive do we think it is? And is this connected to the sort of prediction, if you will, that this was the next thing Stephen Miller, who's sort of the chief advisor on all immigration issues in the West Wing, this is the next step he wanted to take?

JULIA AINSLEY, NATIONAL SECURITY AND JUSTICE REPORTER, NBC NEWS: Chuck, context here is critical. You're exactly right. We know that Stephen Miller -- the next step he wants to do is go after legal immigration.

What we're seeing here is part of this new fraud crackdown from DHS and throughout the Trump administration like the State Department. They're trying to go after people who maybe lied on their applications and became citizens or became permanent residents and got green cards who shouldn't have.

So they want to go back and re-adjudicate and take that away. But of course what happens and what The Washington Post laid out in this story is a lot of people who were rightfully in the United States end up getting their rights taken away too.

And as they found under the Obama administration, it's very difficult to decide which ones of those birth certificates signed by those midwives in the '90s were legitimate and which ones weren't. And so they really just decided it was a fruitless cause and that they should just allow them -- take them as legitimate.

But this is part of a broader crackdown. And from people I've spoken to who represent a lot of immigrants who are trying to move up the ladder, get passports, get citizenships, get green cards, they say before you take that next step, you need to go through your record and make sure everything is crystal clear or it could just not even be worth it.

It's too much of a risk because of the scrutiny they're doing going back and looking at everything and every application you've put in earlier, even if they were legitimate, Chuck.

TODD: All right. Let me go to Jaime Diaz. Jaime, I wanted Julia to begin there to help me continue to sort of lay out the context of all of this. Now walk me through what you're dealing with. How many clients do you have that have been impacted?

How many of them are natural born citizens versus those who went through the green card process and became naturalized citizens here, born here versus naturalized, all of those things. I'm curious. What kind of folks are being targeted here?

JAIME DIAZ, IMMIGRATION ATTORNEY: Here we're talking only about people that were born in the United States.

TODD: OK. How many clients do you have on this front?

DIAZ: I have represented over 500 people. I presently have probably 30 people that are in lawsuits in federal court. I have represented over 100 of them in lawsuits in federal court where they have been taken away their documents. They have been put in rooms to admit that they were not born in the United States.

Their mothers have been asked to come to the consulate to admit that they were not born there and the documents were taken. What we see now is that they are detaining them. When they come back -- without allowing them to come back and keep them in Mexico.

There are many clients of mine that I have that were born in the United States, that the government has stopped them and have kept them in Mexico. And the crackdown is starting to be very hard. They are doing it every day. I see someone in my office.

I practice in Brownsville, Texas which is at the border with Mexico. People that were born by midwives down there, there is a lot of them, but I can tell you something, that most of them were born in the United States.

We even have a soldier that was born with a midwife and he applied to become a soldier. They took him in. He applied for a passport and they say, show that you're a United States citizen. This is ridiculous.

TODD: Well, there was one example in The Washington Post, Mr. Diaz, and I'm just curious if you had to deal with something like this where it was a former soldier and he only wanted to give his first name because he was afraid he'd be targeted.

He said that the State Department told him that they weren't convinced he was a U.S. citizen, that they needed a bunch of the following documents. Either his mother's -- evidence of his mother's prenatal care, his baptismal certificate, maybe rental agreements when he was a baby.

This is a grown man. I'm sorry, I don't think my mother has the power bill from when I was born in 1972. Is this the burden of proof that's being put on your clients?

DIAZ: Yes. That is what's going on. They are asking for things that no one has. No one in the whole United States has prenatal record from her mother. A person that is 40 years old, there's no way they have them. So they're asking for things that they know they don't have. People get frustrated.

But if you live on the border, there is a need for you to cross to the other side. You have family, you have things to do on the other side. And when they're coming back, that's when they're detaining them. They're making them sign documents so that they can get away from it.

What has happened is outrageous. An opportunity like this to tell the American people what is going on is incredible. We're not talking about people that are naturalized, we are talking about people that were born in the United States. They just happen to have a Hispanic last name and they were born with midwives, but that's still Americans.

TODD: Mr. Diaz, did you have any client who didn't have a Hispanic last name who had their passport taken away?

DIAZ: Not that I can remember right now on the top of my head. Most of them have been taken away, no. I have people that I represented that are having difficulty getting a passport because they were born in Southern Texas with a midwife. But someone that has a passport taken away or revoked when they were coming back or through a letter in the mail, no, I have never had it.

TODD: So it does feel as if it is Hispanic surnames that get targeted here. Julia, walk me through the due process in this. What are the court procedures here? You're accused of this, you're trying to fight back. Where does it go in the system?

AINSLEY: It's really hard to fight back, Chuck. I mean, you would have to get a lawyer. I know a lot of people who stay outside of places where immigrants are trying to appeal and they know that they will eventually come across the street and find lawyers because it's nearly impossible to navigate this system on your own.

As Jaime just pointed out, they're asking for these documents a lot of people don't have. And as an American citizen, yes, you have the right to have citizenship, but that passport, the documents that you have to have a passport, it's not a right to have a passport if you don't have the documents to back it up.

TODD: Right.

AINSLEY: And when they're raising this bar, there actually very few routes to go. The way this was handled in the past, Chuck, was through a class action settlement and that's frequently the way we see immigrants or even U.S.-born immigrants, the children of immigrants seek their rights, that they're able to go through the ACLU. They have to come in a class action suit with lots of people and then they are able to get justice.

That's what happened in 2009 when the ACLU said, look, you can't tell which one of these midwife birth certificates are illegitimate and which ones aren't, and we think that it's a very small amount of children that were actually born in Mexico. And so, therefore, you can't discriminate based on them having this one type of birth certificate. So the answer is it is really hard to get justice without a class action lawsuit in this case.

TODD: Mr. Diaz, is there anything in the -- why is the burden of proof not on the government to prove you're not a U.S. citizen?

DIAZ: The burden (INAUDIBLE) evidence and this is a civil case. The government does not have any way to prove that you are -- to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that you fraudulently obtained that document. First of all, these are documents that were registered when you were a baby. And the only way to prove it is if you knew that that document was fraudulent when you grew up.

So, you know, what they do is they try to take you away from going to court. That's why they detain you at ports of entry and they keep you and say stay in Mexico. How do you come back if you will stay in Mexico and you were thrown into --

TODD: You're not a Mexican citizen. You're not a Mexican citizen. What are you going to do?

DIAZ: It is really -- the stories -- unfortunately I don't have the time to tell you all the stories that I have seen of people. But I can tell you one thing. We have won all those cases. What is sad is after you win all those cases, you would think the government would say, you know, I have to change. No, they go harder. Eventually there will be no attorney that will represent these people, but I'm here to represent them.

TODD: Let me ask you this. Is there -- how many of your clients that you felt like they were detained longer than they should be thrown in jail and what were they thrown in jail for if they were?

DIAZ: They were thrown to jail -- they get thrown immigration detention centers. I had a guy that was detained for three days at a detention center --

TODD: American citizen? An American citizen?

DIAZ: An American citizen. Yes, sir.

TODD: Detained -- put into a detention center and just because, what, he didn't have a passport or they didn't believe his passport?

DIAZ: No, he had a passport. They just said, we have a note that we need to revoke your passport so they put him in a room. The agent asked him, do you want me to treat you like a Mexican or as a U.S. citizen? What I would have told him, treat him like a human being, give him his rights. He has a right to hear whatever evidence you think you have. But the way they're treating people is not right.

TODD: All right. Julia Ainsley, Jaime Diaz, I've got to leave it there. I thank you both for sharing your expertise and your experiences there, thank you.

Up ahead, the empire state strikes back. We'll show you some of last night's New York gubernatorial debate between Andrew Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon. Let's just say a little feisty.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. In tonight's "Meet the Midterms," the feuding factions of the Democratic Party literally on full display.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D), NEW YORK: The subway system is owned by New York City.

CYNTHIA NIXON, DEMOCRATIC GUBERNATORIAL NOMINEE: The MTA has been controlled by the state since 1965.

CUOMO: Excuse me, can you stop interrupting? Can you stop interrupting?

NIXON: Can you stop lying?

NIXON: Yeah, as soon as you do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: I guess they call that a cell phone. That was New York Governor Andrew Cuomo seeking his third term and challenger Cynthia Nixon, an actress and self-described Democratic socialist going out last night in their one and only debate before New York's primary September 13th. That handshake at the end may have been the most civil moment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NIXON: I'm not an Albany insider, like Governor Cuomo, but I think that experience doesn't mean that much if you're not actually good at governing.

CUOMO: My opponent lives in the world of fiction, I live in the world of fact.

NIXON: We already have a corrupt corporate Republican in the White House. We don't need a corrupt corporate Democrat in Albany as his main opposition.

CUOMO: She released five years of corporate taxes, dumped them in three hours on a Friday with no notice. Only Donald Trump has done less transparency on his taxes than my opponent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: Nixon is still a long shot to win the nomination. She trailed Cuomo by 31 points in a Siena College poll from last month.

But let's see, in a year in which Democrats tapped underdog Andrew Gillum, who wasn't polling very high in many polls to run for governor in Florida and in a year in which Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez who Nixon endorsed won over Congressman Joe Crowley in the Bronx there, are you really going to discount her chances? More "MTP Daily" after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Time now for "The Lid." The panel is back: Sahil, Daniella, and Brad. All right, the president, we got more from your Bloomberg interview. You're just dribbling it out. You know, we in the -- we just put it all out there. But anyway, you dribbled it out. We got a little bit which is, here's what he said about the Mueller probe. We will put it up on the screen here.

I view it as an illegal investigation because great scholars -- that's his quote -- have said that there never should have been a special counsel. This is an answer when asked if he would comply with the subpoena for Mueller, he said I'll see what happens there.

He talks about Mueller being an illegal probe all the time. Let me ask this, Brad. Do any of the supporters wonder why he just doesn't end it? He has the power. He is the president.

BRAD TODD, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST AND FOUNDING PARTNER OF ONMESSAGE INC.: I don't think many of the supporters think very much about the Mueller probe. I think the president thinks about it a lot more than his supporters do.

C.TOOD: I think the president thinks about it more than anybody around this table sometimes.

B.TODD: I think the president's voters are -- we'll wait until the Mueller probe is over with and we'll see what he has and we'll evaluate it. I don't think it's something that they're obsessed about. Washington is obsessed about it. They lead (ph) the paper everyday.

C.TODD: Sure.

B.TODD: It doesn't lead the paper in Kenosho (ph).

C.TODD: No, that I buy. He has the power to end these things if he really wanted to. He obviously knows it would be a problem.

SAHIL KAPUR, NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER, BLOOMBERG NEWS: It's not the prevailing view of members of his own party in Congress, that it's an illegal investigation. The Senate majority leader and the speaker of the House say they support the investigation. That is not only legal but it is proper that it should come to an end.

So I think this is the president feeling like there is a lot happening around him. The walls may be closing in on him. I think he is lashing out. He may be binging cable news, according to some people around him that I spoke to.

DANIELLA GIBBS LEGER, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, COMMUNICATIONS AND STRATEGY AT AMERICAN PROGRESS: Yes.

(LAUGHTER)

C. TODD: He needed something to do. I think they're glad they scheduled this rally this afternoon.

GIBBS LEGER: Yeah, very well timed.

B.TODD: The special counsel has a responsibility too. He presumably supports the idea that special counsel should exist and he has to know when he's gone past the time limit of when he has credibility.

C.TODD: What time limit are we at? This is not even at the halfway point.

B.TODD: He's had more than a year.

C.TODD: Not even a halfway point.

GIBBS LEGER: So what? You just arbitrarily stop because --

B.TODD: He has to decide when the public thinks he's gone too far on time and show his cards.

GIBBS LEGER: He has to go until the investigation is over. If he keeps uncovering more crimes --

B. TODD: All appointments are political, though, you have a certain amount of political rope. He has to judge where the American public is and whether it's willing to let him go on.

C. TODD: Here is what I've learned about Bob Mueller. Not a single person that has known him been with him, worked with him, would say if he didn't have any -- he would have ended this investigation if there is no collusion, that he already would have ended it.

B. TODD: We can't tell that though until he tells us something.

C.TODD: That's true. Right, we are just left here in what is the last chapter --

(CROSSTALK)

KAPUR: This is not the issue that resonates in most of the country. I do think public opinion is calcified on this issue for now. New developments in this case are not necessarily going to move the needle unless they directly relate to the president. I don't know that the fall of people around him is going to affect the midterm elections. But this is baked in. It's one of the reasons that the president --

D.TODD: But here is the question --

KAPUR: -- not like it doesn't affect him at all.

B.TODD: We're at Labor Day. And I think if Mueller comes back with anything between Labor Day and the election, half the country is going to reject it.

(CROSSTALK)

C.TODD: I think he knows, more than anything, he keeps quiet between Labor Day and election day, don't you think?

B.TODD: Then he's going to be pushing up against two years before you know it. I mean, it's too long.

C.TODD: No, no, no --

GIBBS LEGER: That's why I feel like --

C. TODD: This is a trap that Giuliani is trying to set, I think, PR-wise, which is you're taking forever. Wait, why are you speaking during the election --

GIBBS LEGER: Exactly. That's why I feel like maybe January 2019 is going to be the time when Mueller announces everything. Because it's enough time before the 2020 election, but you wait until after this election so you don't have people saying --

C. TODD: I'm not missing work tomorrow. I wouldn't miss work tomorrow.

GIBBS LEGER: That's right.

C. TODD: Tomorrow is the last business day of the pre-Labor Day to election day window, Sahil.

KAPUR: And this is where there's so much at stake in the 2018 elections because whoever controls the House is going to decide what the fate -- what comes of this report that Mueller files.

Now, to the issue of subpoenas and, you know, potentially what the White House would do if he's forced to -- or if he's subpoenaed, they will very likely challenge this in court and the president probably won't end up speaking executive privilege.

The White House can find a way around this, I think, to make sure that they don't face any court conviction because it's not -- I'm sorry, indictment because it's not happened to a sitting president so far. Congress is going to decide.

C. TODD: Not to be totally cliche, 5:00 tomorrow is a big deadline, isn't it?

GIBBS LEGER: Yeah.

C. TODD: Unofficially for a lot of people. I mean, we assume Mueller wouldn't do it until -- tomorrow at 5:00 p.m. is the last possible time.

B.TODD: Chuck, every Friday night is entertaining in this presidency.

C.TODD: Let's try putting on a Sunday show.

(LAUGHTER)

C. TODD: We don't find it entertaining, we find it mind boggling.

B.TODD: You always wanted things to get a little more exciting. You wanted a little more of a president who is unscripted.

GIBBS LEGER: It would be perfect, the Friday before Labor Day to have like this big thing.

C.TODD: Today we had an arrest of somebody who threatened The Boston Globe using "you're the enemy of the people." Sahil, you're the other working journalist here. The U.S. attorney went after and arrested this person. This person, "you're the enemy of the people, and we're going to kill every" -- whatever the caller said to Globe.

You know, there's always this decision, do we alert authorities or not? At this point the guy called so many times and, you know, maybe holding somebody criminally responsible does sort of make people responsible for their rhetoric.

KAPUR: Yeah. There were 14 phone calls here of this man using all kinds of nasty language that I can't repeat here. Yes, he used the phrase "the enemy of the people," where have we heard that before.

I want to be very clear, the president is not condoning violence against anybody, but it's not difficult to see how someone can listen to that, see that rhetoric and want to do something crazy if they are not mentally stable.

C. TODD: This has always been our point. We know the president is not -- he needs to actually say that he doesn't mean it. All right. Sahil, Daniella, Brad, thank you all. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: That's all we have for tonight. We'll be back tomorrow with more "MTP Daily." Remember, 5:00 p.m. tomorrow is a big deadline, perhaps in the Mueller probe. "The Beat" starts right now. Ayman Mohyeldin is in for Ari. Ayman, good evening, sir.

AYMAN MOHYELDIN, JOURNALIST, MSNBC: Good evening, Chuck.
