urn:contentItem:5V0W-JKH1-DXH2-63KJ-00000-00MTP DAILY WITH CHUCK TODD for December 19, 20182018-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMTP DAILY5:00 PM ESTEugene Scott, Matthew Continetti, Jeff Flake, Chris Coons, Kara SwisherNEWSDomestic121901cb.454MTP DAILY WITH CHUCK TODD for December 19, 2018Chuck Todd, Ruth Marcus

President Trump and his legal team have denied the plan to build Trump Tower in Moscow and also about the hush money payments made but the president`s statements from the past suggested the other way around. A bipartisan bill is raised to protect Robert Mueller`s Russia probe but for the third time, it was blocked by Republicans. Kara Swisher joins to discuss the latest from Facebook`s privacy breaches and why the company seems to keep using the same denial, debunk, downplay strategy the Trump administration has adopted. Dems march two-by-two into 2020. Do Dems have a Noah`s Ark trend going for the next election? Multiple states have two candidates vying for president in 2020, including Colorado where Sen. Michael Bennet and Gov. John Hickenlooper have both expressed interest in running. President Trump is facing some criticism from fellow Republicans for his decision to withdraw troops from Syria and claiming victory over ISIS in doing so. For NASA`s newest hire, space runs in the family.

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

MICHELLE GOLDBERG, COLUMNIST, "THE NEW YORK TIMES": So, the fact that here is an upside actually of having people in the White House who come from families that have a lot of criminal exposure.

(CROSSTALK)

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: Criminal families.

GOLDBERG: Right. And this is going to make a lot of people`s life better.

WALLACE: I love you for finding a silver lining. It`s a great point. Thank you for bringing that. My thanks to Ron Klein, Jason Johnson, Michelle Goldberg, and Nick Confessore.

That does it for our hour. I`m Nicolle Wallace. "MTP DAILY" starts right now. Hi, Chuck.

CHUCK TODD, MSNBC HOST: Hey. The last time they come they got a lot of nods around here, too.

WALLACE: Yes.

TODD: So, that`s well said. That`s well said. Thank you, Nicolle.

Yes, if it`s Wednesday, deny, debunk, downplay.

Good evening. I am not Patches O`Houlihan. I`m Chuck Todd here in Washington. And for the five of you that got that joke, enjoy it. Welcome to MTP DAILY.

We are following two major stories at this hour. A key part of the president`s legal defense involving that infamous Trump tower Moscow project has been debunked and you`re not going to believe how the president`s lawyer is responding to this one.

We are also following the fallout from a bombshell story in the New York Times that suggests Facebook may have lied about what it was doing with data as sensitive as your private messages. Which raises this question. Has Facebook, and frankly most of the social media companies been as dishonest as the president`s team has been when it comes to Russia? We`re going to get to that story in a moment as well.

But we will begin tonight with another unraveling denial involving the president`s ties to, you guessed it, Russia, and another brazen attempt to try to downplay that falsehood.

Just three days ago, the president`s lawyer said this about the Trump tower Moscow deal. Which remember, Mr. Trump was negotiating with Russia as Russia and Putin were executing its campaign against our democracy.

"There was a letter of intent to go forward, but no one signed it." But then reporters got their hands-on that letter of intent, and of course it was signed, none other than by a person`s signature we have all become familiar with. Donald J. Trump`s.

Now here`s Giuliani`s response according to an interview he gave to the New York Daily News. Giuliani told the Daily News said, "of course, Trump signed it. How could you send it but nobody signed it," he said? But Giuliani claimed the letter was B.S. because it didn`t go anywhere. "That was the end of it," Giuliani said. "It means nothing but an expression of interest that means very little unless it goes to a contract and it never did."

So, the president`s team didn`t publicly disclose the project. Then when they did, they didn`t mention the letter of intent. Then when they did, they claimed it wasn`t signed. Then when we learned it was, they claimed it`s all B.S. anyway.

Folks, this pattern of deny, which gets debunked so they downplay is frankly a story that we told so many times. And it`s always about the same topic. This one, Russia. When will it stop? Maybe when enough people demand that it stop.

Let`s bring in tonight`s panel. Eugene Scott, political reporter at the Washington Post. Ruth Marcus, Washington Post columnist and deputy editorial page editor, she`s also an MSNBC contributor, Matthew Continetti, editor-in-chief of the Washington Free Beacon. Welcome all.

Eugene, if I just stop there, we could just say this is Rudy Giuliani being Rudy Giuliani, but the same defense, deny, then downplay when it comes to firing Comey. Let me put up the examples here. "The day it was happened the Russia investigation is not what this is about," said Mike Pence on May 10th.

Donald Trump on May 12th, "when I decided to do it, I said to myself this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story." Then of course, the Trump legal team memo, on January 29, 2018 where they said, "A president can fire an FBI director at any time for any reason." The point is this is a pattern.

EUGENE SCOTT, POLITICAL REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: It certainly is. And it`s not doing the president any favors at all. At least at the very least it`s certainly bringing in Rudy Giuliani`s legacy into question as we`ve seen someone who at least made headlines or was praised for being tough on law, among, you know, more conservative politicos.

Turn to someone who seems to dismiss criminal activities altogether when it involves someone that he is personally connected to. And it`s very problematic in this situation because there could be very real implications for the American people and those who rely on the president to serve citizen`s best interest when it comes to national security.

TODD: Matthew, I just don`t understand where, because like I said, let me do the Trump tower meeting. The same thing happened there. The story comes out on July 8th, 2017 Donald Trump, Jr., says we primarily discussed a program about the adoption of Russian children.

Five days later, the answer is this. Donald Trump, "it`s called opposition research. It`s very standard where they have information, you take the information." But July 30th, "collusion is not a crime."

MATTHEW CONTINETTI, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, WASHINGTON FREE BEACON: We go back even further in time and probably go to some of those articles in the New York Daily News and New York Post--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: I got more here, don`t worry.

CONTINETTI: -- and National Enquirer.

TODD: I got hush money payments, Matt.

CONTINETTI: I mean, this is who the man is, right?

TODD: Yes. This is the pattern. It`s the same pattern. When does it stop?

CONTINETTI: Probably never. But here`s the difference, though, starting in January, Democrats are going to have control of the House and they are going to be in charge of those investigating committees and they are going to have subpoena power.

And even if that doesn`t reach the president, himself, it`s going to start getting at kind of the people in the president`s orbit and they are going to be held to kind of higher standard for truth and veracity than say the president has been or his lawyer in the national media.

TODD: Rush, as I`ve said, I got the hush money payment example. And I`ll be darn if I`m going to get all these examples on air. On November 4, 2016 the Trump campaign statement, "We have no knowledge of any of this." By December 14, it became, Michael Cohen, "Mr. Trump directed me to make the payments." And by December 14, "This was not a big crime."

RUTH MARCUS, DEPUTY EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, THE WASHINGTON POST: Right.

TODD: That one took almost two years for them to their eventual--

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: To unravel.

TODD: They at least kept that one afloat for a while.

MARCUS: Well, from the president on down the first instinct is to lie to not tell the truth when confronted with an inconvenient fact or allegation and then you just start to peel the onion and the layers that you laid out until you get to the truth.

And for me, the touchstone is, if we knew during the campaign--

TODD: Right.

MARCUS: -- what we know how about all the things you`ve unspoiled about the fact that the president was negotiating to build a tower in Moscow when he was running, about the Trump tower meeting, about the hush money payments, where would we be? Would he be in the White House? I think that`s a serious question and you have been asking the next serious question, which is, when will it be enough? And maybe the answer is in the next election.

TODD: Eugene, does this even happen on policy? We put together, it`s a little bit out of order, it was decry, deny, downplay when it came to child separation. So that happened.

And then the president said, "I hate to see the separation of parents and children." Secretary Nielsen says a couple of days later, "We do not have a policy of separating families at the border. Period."

Of course, we end up finding up that yes, this was the intent of doing this. And then by November 25th, the president said, "We had the exact same policy as the Obama administration."

Again, I know it`s instinctual. It goes to what Ruth just said, but I guess the question is, you have about 55 percent of the country that`s worn out from this. But you do have you 40 to 45 percent that it doesn`t bother them.

SCOTT: Absolutely. And one thing that we know the president is mindful of is his base. These supporters who have gone--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: That`s the only thing he`s mindful of.

SCOTT: Very much so. We usually we see presidents when he head towards the midterm start to think about the people who weren`t supportive of them initially hoping to win them.

TODD: You want to grow? Right?

(CROSSTALK)

SCOTT: It`s the new people--

TODD: I know that`s crazy.

SCOTT: It`s the new people on the Trump train. Right? That`s not something that he`s seen. And one of the things that`s been really fascinating and disheartening about how the president has handled this Russia investigation, is he seems to be very mindful of his base, knowing these people will support him regardless. But he didn`t pay attention to the fact that the base is not as large as it was in 2016.

There are people who voted for Trump and Trump-like characters, candidates should I say, in 2016 who did not in 2018 and in part it`s because of this pattern of dishonesty.

TODD: You know, Matthew, I think he`s right. You know, watching the Trump base, and you look at it. It got as high as 46. But you do see it`s like if you look at it maybe it`s down to 34, 35, who believe he`s never been dishonest about it. You know, you`re starting to see it`s not a -- it`s like a small leak out of an inflated raft. You know, it`s not sinking yet, but.

CONTINETTI: Sure, his personal approval has always been pretty low even among the people who support him.

TODD: Right. People like -- that`s right. Yes.

CONTINETTI: Exactly. And so, he still retains pretty high support among Republicans, probably enough to deter any primary challenge.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Higher -- higher than the last two -- higher than the last two Republican presidents.

MARCUS: I went back and I looked at the approval ratings for the party of the president in power. He is above where President Obama was, above where most presidents have been in recent years. It`s extraordinary. But it is a kind of condensed stock that`s boiled down to its essence as the party base strengths.

SCOTT: And on this issue, they`re not really supportive. I`ve wrote about it today in the Washington Post, only about a third of Republicans actually believe what Trump is saying about Russia and the 2016 election. They still support him but they don`t believe him.

TODD: There is a, you know, the rhetorical question I asked is simply, when will it stop? When will enough people demand that it stopped? Well, there is a group of people that could have done something about it or attempted to, it`s elected Republicans in Washington. They have chosen not to. Here`s Paul Ryan today in his farewell speech.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL RYAN, UNITED STATES SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I leave as I came here, an optimist to the core. Just as remarkable as what we have achieved is what we have the capacity to do still. So, here`s to the people. Here`s to the people`s House. Here`s to possibilities. Thank you for everything. God bless America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: I lump the two here because you could make the Republican Party rank and file care if other Republicans like him cared.

CONTINETTI: Yes, maybe. I mean, other--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: I`m just -- maybe not.

CONTINETTI: -- Republicans raise this issue are rejected by the Republican base, which is--

TODD: That`s true.

CONTINETTI: -- totally the president`s corner. So, I`m not so sure. But the irony is--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But that`s the truth. That look like an alien.

CONTINETTI: The Republican Congress--

TODD: Today.

CONTINETTI: -- or the Republican caucus in next year`s Congress is actually going to be more pro-Trump--

TODD: More Trumpy.

CONTINETTI: -- than the one that Paul Ryan led for the last two years, so.

TODD: Because he and a bunch of others are leaving.

CONTINETTI: This is where we are. I mean, the people who are going to stop Trump are not going to be Republicans, they are going to a combination of Democrats and independents.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But do you believe that?

CONTINETTI: Some Republicans in 2020 if they stop him.

TODD: I believe that if it`s at the ballot box. But if your -- if he is -- if you are going to hold him accountable before the election, then it is going to take Republicans jumping on board. Right?

MARCUS: Republican elected officials will desert the president if and only if, when and only when, it is in their political interest. And that will be, if something happens or the facts develop to the point where they understand that the base is deserting the president and that it will be safe for them in primaries. Period.

That`s why I think your question has it backwards. Paul Ryan isn`t leaving the people. The people are leaving Paul Ryan. It`s not just Paul Ryan.

TODD: I understand politically why he didn`t.

MARCUS: I think you did. I think that you understood politically.

TODD: No, I understand why he did it politically. But if you are frustrated, my whole point is there is one whole group of people that could have an impact if they chose to.

SCOTT: If they chose to, but they haven`t felt empower to do it because they are so mindful of the base. Now we did see after the midterms, some Republican lawmakers are bit more willing to speak out against Trump because they looked at the numbers and realized that the Republican electorate was not as on board with Trump as they perhaps previously thought.

And so, if that base continues to decline, and I don`t know what it would make for them to maybe some changes in the economy, I think we could see the Republican lawmakers stand up to Trump in ways we haven`t in the past two years.

MARCUS: We do. Do you see some outpourings of frustration on Khashoggi, on Yemen--

SCOTT: Right.

MARCUS: -- on Syria today. So, a little. Not a lot.

TODD: No, I mean, I know--

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: But it`s something.

TODD: I know it`s there. And you do -- but I also get like those that have popped up. I mean, Bob Corker wanted to get back in the race. He couldn`t have won. And Jeff Flake he didn`t retire because he wanted to retire. I mean, he, himself, if he could have gotten elected, I think he`d run.

CONTINETTI: I think the bargain that Trump has made with Republican lawmakers, is I`ll sign on to your agenda and in exchange for that you give me a pass on a lot of this other stuff. Once he starts departing from that agenda, that traditional Republicanism, if he starts flirting with taxes.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: What`s left? What do you mean if he is departing for judicial Republicanism?

CONTINETTI: If he nominates a Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court.

TODD: OK, that`s what it would take. Yes.

CONTINETTI: Judges, taxes, if he doesn`t build a wall.

TODD: But on national security.

CONTINETTI: National security we saw an outrage today from the United States Senate because he`s withdrawing precipitously from Syria. So, it`s there. It`s just on policy, not on the stuff that occupies a lot of (Inaudible)--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But even on--

CONTINETTI: from Washington.

TODD: But even on policy, it`s rhetorical and they do back off at the end of it.

CONTINETTI: What? I mean, what do you--

TODD: Meaning like they give you the sense of the Senate.

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: Brace a resolution.

TODD: That`s right. They--

CONTINETTI: That`s all they can do with a lot of these policies.

TODD: Well, no, they could do more if they chose to. Here they could have funding fights, they could do some things like this. They`re not --I guess- -

(CROSSTALK)

CONTINETTI: They are -- they are members of the same party.

TODD: I understand.

CONTINETTI: So, they do have to work together to some extent.

TODD: Right. I guess the question is, do any of them worry about what this is going to look like in two years?

SCOTT: I think certainly, and I think that`s what we got a taste of with the whole Khashoggi situation. Where we saw people come out and say, absolutely, Trump, the way you are responding to Saudi Arabia is not consistent with how we believe an American president or any elected leadership.

And they are very mindful of their legacy. So, I think in part because they`re looking at some of these farewell speeches that they saw Orrin Hatch give, Jeff Flake give, Paul Ryan give and some of these people were getting laughed out a bit.

TODD: Well, that is what`s funny. Every one of these farewell speeches, whether Republican or Democrat all contain these subtle shots at Trump. It is sort of remarkable whether really subtle or not, Ruth.

MARCUS: Well, maybe they`re looking at those farewell speeches and thinking I don`t want to be saying farewell like that guy had to. Because a lot of them as you pointed out--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Yes. Wanted to stay.

MARCUS: -- weren`t exactly leaving on the best of terms.

TODD: Right. All right. We got a lot more. Wait until we get to Facebook. That`s going to be quite the story in a little bit. But anyway, you guys are sticking around.

Up next, the bipartisan plan to try to protect Robert Mueller. How is that working out? They`re trying it one more time.

TODD: Welcome back. Well, you know the saying if at first you don`t succeed, try, try again.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: We need to protect the independents of the special counsel and allow this crucial investigation and any like it in the future to run their course.

SEN. CHRIS COONS, (D) DELAWARE: This is an effective and ongoing federal investigation that must be allowed to reach its conclusion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: Those, of course, were Senators Jeff Flake and Chris Coons a few hours ago trying for the third time to force a vote on legislation protecting Robert Mueller`s investigation, and just as before, Republicans blocked this third attempt.

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has called it a solution in search of a problem. So now in a week in which President Trump tweeted again that the Russia probe should be shut down, and in a week in which a new report claimed that Russia disinformation teams targeted Robert Mueller, himself, will anything change?

With me now are those two senators, Republican Jeff Flake of Arizona, in his last few days as a senator and Democrat Chris Coons of Delaware. Welcome, gentleman.

COONS: Thank you.

FLAKE: Thanks, Chuck.

TODD: All right. Senator Flake, why was today not any different than before and will tomorrow be any different than today when it comes to this Mueller bill?

FLAKE: You know, this bill passed the judiciary committee back in April, so we have been waiting nine months. It passed on a bipartisan basis two to one. Even and including our chairman he has a languish on the House floor awaiting for -- I`m sorry, awaiting for action on the Senate floor since that time.

And since that time, notably, in November, the president fired the attorney general. So, to say, you know, the solution is in search of a problem, I think the problem is that the Mueller probe is in danger and we need to protect it.

TODD: Senator Coons, obviously, Mitch McConnell`s rationale has been it`s unconstitutional. He`s not convinced. Forget whether the president would veto it or not, he probably would unless you put it on the spending bill. But he argues it`s unconstitutional anyway so why bother?

COONS: I am certain that it`s not unconstitutional. And frankly, the fact that the Republican chairman of the judiciary committee, that a bipartisan majority of 14 to 7 on the judiciary committee voted it out and says it`s ready for action on the floor, strongly suggest that we think it is more important to protect the rule of law to provide a judicial review in the case of the inappropriate, without cause abrupt firing of the special counsel, than to litigate the fine points of its constitutionality on the floor of the Senate.

TODD: Senator Flake, why do you think your colleagues are willing to push back at the president on Saudi Arabia, how they`ve handled Khashoggi.

FLAKE: Right.

TODD: On Syria today. And I want to get you, guys, reactions to that actually in a second. But not on this. Why the fear on this but no fear at pushing back on him on trade, no fear on Saudi Arabia? Why so much fear on pushing back on this?

FLAKE: Well, this is so central to what the president talks about every day and he has been on this for months and months and months, how this is a witch hunt.

And I think my colleagues realize, they`ll be on the wrong end of a tweet or an outrage by the president. So, but I think it`s far more important to protect the integrity of this investigation. It is not a witch hunt. It has led to 12 indictments of Russian nationals, as well as indictments of Americans.

So, this is a serious investigation that has to reach its conclusion. I just don`t understand how my colleagues can be so sanguine about this. I really don`t.

TODD: Senator Coons, are you comforted by the fact that it looks like Mueller himself has protected himself. I mean, when you look at pieces of the investigation that he`s farmed out to the Southern District of New York, the U.S. attorney in D.C., the eastern district of Virginia, he seems to both been very careful about sticking to his mandate, staying very narrow on Russia and every other criminal enterprise he finds, he makes sure a fixed U.S. attorney has it. Does that make you feel better?

COONS: That`s right. That`s right, Chuck. I am reassured by the ways in which Robert Mueller is diligently, carefully, and with great persistence pursuing his mandate and then sending to other jurisdictions criminal matters that deserve prompt follow-up that they can handle.

But that doesn`t mean that the Mueller investigation is not at risk. As the tempo has picked up. As the number of indictments, and sentencing hearings and charges has picked up, I think it is at its greatest moment of risk.

When we leave when Congress goes out of session which I think may happen as soon as tonight or tomorrow--

TODD: Yes.

COONS: -- I am very concerned President Trump will act on what he repeatedly tweets or says almost every day. He has asserted over and over again that this is a baseless witch hunt that should be shut down. Why most of my Republican colleagues won`t take him at his word and act to stop this slow rolling constitutional crisis coming at us is beyond me.

I am so thankful to Senator Flake for standing up, for blocking 23 Republican judges in the judiciary committee and for again, joining me and Senator Booker on the floor today, forcing the majority leader to come out and object to our request for a live U.C. vote.

TODD: Let me pivot the conversation to Syria. Senator Flake, what concerns you more, the decision, itself, or how the president went about doing it and the lack of informing, it looks like state, Pentagon, and Congress at this point? Everybody seemed to cancel their briefings today for fear of not being able to answer any questions about it.

FLAKE: You know, any time the Pentagon is caught flat-footed, when the president says that he has agreed to withdraw troops from a country, you know you`re in trouble. And so, the process more than anything, but there are serious concerns about the policy implications as well.

But my golly, the process here to not consult among agencies, particularly with the Department of the State and the Department of Defense is just jaw dropping. It really is.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Senator Coons--

COONS: President Trump is the first president in our nation`s history with no previous experience either in the military or an elected service. TODD: Yes.

COONS: -- and reinforce Putin`s bad behavior, not just in Syria but globally.

TODD: There is one other group I`m concerned about that I wanted to -- and Senator Flake, I wanted to bring up, and that`s the Kurds, who, of course, basically have been perhaps the best ally the U.S. military has had.

We know the Turks are thinking, there has been a lot of speculation that Erdogan and Turkey is about to -- you know, that he views the Kurds in northern Syria as more of a threat to him than to ISIS.

FLAKE: Right.

TODD: If the U.S. military isn`t in there, are they going to get slaughtered?

FLAKE: You know, that concern was raised today certainly with the vice president here on Capitol Hill and that is a big concern that many of us have. So, you know, yes, the policy implication of this move are legion, and certainly, the way that the president has gone about this just leaves us all scratching our head.

TODD: Senator Coons, I can`t tell you, I`ve got a lot of reaction that asks the question of, you can`t help but wonder considering who the major players are in this issue, that the president`s ties to Russia the president`s ties to Saudi Arabia, suddenly are popping up here?

COONS: I`m gravely concerned by this abrupt decision. I do think it will lead to a lot of loss of life on the ground. And I think it raises the question, the Kurds who have fought so bravely and so hard alongside American troops to take on ISIS and to drive ISIS out of a whole region of Syria, a fight that is not yet over and not yet won.

For us to abandon them and to see this ground potentially to Turkey, I think more likely to Iran, is a grave mistake. And it does raise concerns about on what basis the president has made this decision.

TODD: Right.

COONS: Not just the process but the substance, not just the process and substance, but the consequences of this decision I think are gravely concerning to all of us who heard about it today.

FLAKE: Let me just say this points up the need again that something that Chris and I have worked on and Tim Kaine and others is to pass an AUMF for- -

TODD: Yes.

FLAKE: -- Authorization for Use of Military Force that will allow at least at this point the president, if ISIS pops back up again, to clear authority to get back in. So that desperately, it should have been done by now.

COONS: Yes.

FLAKE: But it desperately needs to be done as soon as January.

TODD: Well, the equal branch of government. We`ll see if the president will abide by it when it comes to these issues of war and peace. Anyways, Senators Flake and Coons, thank you both for coming on together and sharing your views. I appreciate that.

COONS: Thank you.

FLAKE: Thank you, Chuck.

SWISHER: Yeah.

TODD: That`s attack that we would have expected from a campaign. This is a company that claims, oh, let`s go back to the way it was in the old days of Facebook. Whatever that was.

The question is how they`re doing it and how they`re communicating to users of what they`re using your data for. It`s an advertising business. It`s designed to advertise and to sell toilet paper or toothpaste or whatever.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: You got to keep that in mind. Facebook hates when I say this and they hate when a lot of people say it. In many ways, you are the product they`re selling in some way, but they`re not directly selling you.

A.I. and humans and there`s all the sort of -- it`s global. There are issues that are different in India versus here versus Venezuela.

SWISHER: It is such a massive -- and then it has societal impact, political impact. These are massive problems as if you took a newspaper and made it a global newspaper that everybody read at once. SWISHER: Yes, that`s true.

urn:contentItem:5V13-X5B1-DY0W-40V7-00000-00MTP DAILY WITH CHUCK TODD for December 19, 2018, MSNBC2018-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMTP DAILY WITH CHUCK TODD for December 19, 2018, MSNBCLanhamFULL TEXT

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

MICHELLE GOLDBERG, COLUMNIST, "THE NEW YORK TIMES": So, the fact that here is an upside actually of having people in the White House who come from families that have a lot of criminal exposure.

(CROSSTALK)

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: Criminal families.

GOLDBERG: Right. And this is going to make a lot of people's life better.

WALLACE: I love you for finding a silver lining. It's a great point. Thank you for bringing that. My thanks to Ron Klein, Jason Johnson, Michelle Goldberg, and Nick Confessore.

That does it for our hour. I'm Nicolle Wallace. "MTP DAILY" starts right now. Hi, Chuck.

CHUCK TODD, MSNBC HOST: Hey. The last time they come they got a lot of nods around here, too.

WALLACE: Yes.

TODD: So, that's well said. That's well said. Thank you, Nicolle.

Yes, if it's Wednesday, deny, debunk, downplay.

Good evening. I am not Patches O'Houlihan. I'm Chuck Todd here in Washington. And for the five of you that got that joke, enjoy it. Welcome to MTP DAILY.

We are following two major stories at this hour. A key part of the president's legal defense involving that infamous Trump tower Moscow project has been debunked and you're not going to believe how the president's lawyer is responding to this one.

We are also following the fallout from a bombshell story in the New York Times that suggests Facebook may have lied about what it was doing with data as sensitive as your private messages. Which raises this question. Has Facebook, and frankly most of the social media companies been as dishonest as the president's team has been when it comes to Russia? We're going to get to that story in a moment as well.

But we will begin tonight with another unraveling denial involving the president's ties to, you guessed it, Russia, and another brazen attempt to try to downplay that falsehood.

Just three days ago, the president's lawyer said this about the Trump tower Moscow deal. Which remember, Mr. Trump was negotiating with Russia as Russia and Putin were executing its campaign against our democracy.

"There was a letter of intent to go forward, but no one signed it." But then reporters got their hands-on that letter of intent, and of course it was signed, none other than by a person's signature we have all become familiar with. Donald J. Trump's.

Now here's Giuliani's response according to an interview he gave to the New York Daily News. Giuliani told the Daily News said, "of course, Trump signed it. How could you send it but nobody signed it," he said? But Giuliani claimed the letter was B.S. because it didn't go anywhere. "That was the end of it," Giuliani said. "It means nothing but an expression of interest that means very little unless it goes to a contract and it never did."

So, the president's team didn't publicly disclose the project. Then when they did, they didn't mention the letter of intent. Then when they did, they claimed it wasn't signed. Then when we learned it was, they claimed it's all B.S. anyway.

Folks, this pattern of deny, which gets debunked so they downplay is frankly a story that we told so many times. And it's always about the same topic. This one, Russia. When will it stop? Maybe when enough people demand that it stop.

Let's bring in tonight's panel. Eugene Scott, political reporter at the Washington Post. Ruth Marcus, Washington Post columnist and deputy editorial page editor, she's also an MSNBC contributor, Matthew Continetti, editor-in-chief of the Washington Free Beacon. Welcome all.

Eugene, if I just stop there, we could just say this is Rudy Giuliani being Rudy Giuliani, but the same defense, deny, then downplay when it comes to firing Comey. Let me put up the examples here. "The day it was happened the Russia investigation is not what this is about," said Mike Pence on May 10th.

Donald Trump on May 12th, "when I decided to do it, I said to myself this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story." Then of course, the Trump legal team memo, on January 29, 2018 where they said, "A president can fire an FBI director at any time for any reason." The point is this is a pattern.

EUGENE SCOTT, POLITICAL REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: It certainly is. And it's not doing the president any favors at all. At least at the very least it's certainly bringing in Rudy Giuliani's legacy into question as we've seen someone who at least made headlines or was praised for being tough on law, among, you know, more conservative politicos.

Turn to someone who seems to dismiss criminal activities altogether when it involves someone that he is personally connected to. And it's very problematic in this situation because there could be very real implications for the American people and those who rely on the president to serve citizen's best interest when it comes to national security.

TODD: Matthew, I just don't understand where, because like I said, let me do the Trump tower meeting. The same thing happened there. The story comes out on July 8th, 2017 Donald Trump, Jr., says we primarily discussed a program about the adoption of Russian children.

Five days later, the answer is this. Donald Trump, "it's called opposition research. It's very standard where they have information, you take the information." But July 30th, "collusion is not a crime."

MATTHEW CONTINETTI, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, WASHINGTON FREE BEACON: We go back even further in time and probably go to some of those articles in the New York Daily News and New York Post--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: I got more here, don't worry.

CONTINETTI: -- and National Enquirer.

TODD: I got hush money payments, Matt.

CONTINETTI: I mean, this is who the man is, right?

TODD: Yes. This is the pattern. It's the same pattern. When does it stop?

CONTINETTI: Probably never. But here's the difference, though, starting in January, Democrats are going to have control of the House and they are going to be in charge of those investigating committees and they are going to have subpoena power.

And even if that doesn't reach the president, himself, it's going to start getting at kind of the people in the president's orbit and they are going to be held to kind of higher standard for truth and veracity than say the president has been or his lawyer in the national media.

TODD: Rush, as I've said, I got the hush money payment example. And I'll be darn if I'm going to get all these examples on air. On November 4, 2016 the Trump campaign statement, "We have no knowledge of any of this." By December 14, it became, Michael Cohen, "Mr. Trump directed me to make the payments." And by December 14, "This was not a big crime."

RUTH MARCUS, DEPUTY EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, THE WASHINGTON POST: Right.

TODD: That one took almost two years for them to their eventual--

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: To unravel.

TODD: They at least kept that one afloat for a while.

MARCUS: Well, from the president on down the first instinct is to lie to not tell the truth when confronted with an inconvenient fact or allegation and then you just start to peel the onion and the layers that you laid out until you get to the truth.

And for me, the touchstone is, if we knew during the campaign--

TODD: Right.

MARCUS: -- what we know how about all the things you've unspoiled about the fact that the president was negotiating to build a tower in Moscow when he was running, about the Trump tower meeting, about the hush money payments, where would we be? Would he be in the White House? I think that's a serious question and you have been asking the next serious question, which is, when will it be enough? And maybe the answer is in the next election.

TODD: Eugene, does this even happen on policy? We put together, it's a little bit out of order, it was decry, deny, downplay when it came to child separation. So that happened.

And then the president said, "I hate to see the separation of parents and children." Secretary Nielsen says a couple of days later, "We do not have a policy of separating families at the border. Period."

Of course, we end up finding up that yes, this was the intent of doing this. And then by November 25th, the president said, "We had the exact same policy as the Obama administration."

Again, I know it's instinctual. It goes to what Ruth just said, but I guess the question is, you have about 55 percent of the country that's worn out from this. But you do have you 40 to 45 percent that it doesn't bother them.

SCOTT: Absolutely. And one thing that we know the president is mindful of is his base. These supporters who have gone--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: That's the only thing he's mindful of.

SCOTT: Very much so. We usually we see presidents when he head towards the midterm start to think about the people who weren't supportive of them initially hoping to win them.

TODD: You want to grow? Right?

(CROSSTALK)

SCOTT: It's the new people--

TODD: I know that's crazy.

SCOTT: It's the new people on the Trump train. Right? That's not something that he's seen. And one of the things that's been really fascinating and disheartening about how the president has handled this Russia investigation, is he seems to be very mindful of his base, knowing these people will support him regardless. But he didn't pay attention to the fact that the base is not as large as it was in 2016.

There are people who voted for Trump and Trump-like characters, candidates should I say, in 2016 who did not in 2018 and in part it's because of this pattern of dishonesty.

TODD: You know, Matthew, I think he's right. You know, watching the Trump base, and you look at it. It got as high as 46. But you do see it's like if you look at it maybe it's down to 34, 35, who believe he's never been dishonest about it. You know, you're starting to see it's not a -- it's like a small leak out of an inflated raft. You know, it's not sinking yet, but.

CONTINETTI: Sure, his personal approval has always been pretty low even among the people who support him.

TODD: Right. People like -- that's right. Yes.

CONTINETTI: Exactly. And so, he still retains pretty high support among Republicans, probably enough to deter any primary challenge.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Higher -- higher than the last two -- higher than the last two Republican presidents.

MARCUS: I went back and I looked at the approval ratings for the party of the president in power. He is above where President Obama was, above where most presidents have been in recent years. It's extraordinary. But it is a kind of condensed stock that's boiled down to its essence as the party base strengths.

SCOTT: And on this issue, they're not really supportive. I've wrote about it today in the Washington Post, only about a third of Republicans actually believe what Trump is saying about Russia and the 2016 election. They still support him but they don't believe him.

TODD: There is a, you know, the rhetorical question I asked is simply, when will it stop? When will enough people demand that it stopped? Well, there is a group of people that could have done something about it or attempted to, it's elected Republicans in Washington. They have chosen not to. Here's Paul Ryan today in his farewell speech.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL RYAN, UNITED STATES SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I leave as I came here, an optimist to the core. Just as remarkable as what we have achieved is what we have the capacity to do still. So, here's to the people. Here's to the people's House. Here's to possibilities. Thank you for everything. God bless America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: I lump the two here because you could make the Republican Party rank and file care if other Republicans like him cared.

CONTINETTI: Yes, maybe. I mean, other--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: I'm just -- maybe not.

CONTINETTI: -- Republicans raise this issue are rejected by the Republican base, which is--

TODD: That's true.

CONTINETTI: -- totally the president's corner. So, I'm not so sure. But the irony is--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But that's the truth. That look like an alien.

CONTINETTI: The Republican Congress--

TODD: Today.

CONTINETTI: -- or the Republican caucus in next year's Congress is actually going to be more pro-Trump--

TODD: More Trumpy.

CONTINETTI: -- than the one that Paul Ryan led for the last two years, so.

TODD: Because he and a bunch of others are leaving.

CONTINETTI: This is where we are. I mean, the people who are going to stop Trump are not going to be Republicans, they are going to a combination of Democrats and independents.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But do you believe that?

CONTINETTI: Some Republicans in 2020 if they stop him.

TODD: I believe that if it's at the ballot box. But if your -- if he is -- if you are going to hold him accountable before the election, then it is going to take Republicans jumping on board. Right?

MARCUS: Republican elected officials will desert the president if and only if, when and only when, it is in their political interest. And that will be, if something happens or the facts develop to the point where they understand that the base is deserting the president and that it will be safe for them in primaries. Period.

That's why I think your question has it backwards. Paul Ryan isn't leaving the people. The people are leaving Paul Ryan. It's not just Paul Ryan.

TODD: I understand politically why he didn't.

MARCUS: I think you did. I think that you understood politically.

TODD: No, I understand why he did it politically. But if you are frustrated, my whole point is there is one whole group of people that could have an impact if they chose to.

SCOTT: If they chose to, but they haven't felt empower to do it because they are so mindful of the base. Now we did see after the midterms, some Republican lawmakers are bit more willing to speak out against Trump because they looked at the numbers and realized that the Republican electorate was not as on board with Trump as they perhaps previously thought.

And so, if that base continues to decline, and I don't know what it would make for them to maybe some changes in the economy, I think we could see the Republican lawmakers stand up to Trump in ways we haven't in the past two years.

MARCUS: We do. Do you see some outpourings of frustration on Khashoggi, on Yemen--

SCOTT: Right.

MARCUS: -- on Syria today. So, a little. Not a lot.

TODD: No, I mean, I know--

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: But it's something.

TODD: I know it's there. And you do -- but I also get like those that have popped up. I mean, Bob Corker wanted to get back in the race. He couldn't have won. And Jeff Flake he didn't retire because he wanted to retire. I mean, he, himself, if he could have gotten elected, I think he'd run.

CONTINETTI: I think the bargain that Trump has made with Republican lawmakers, is I'll sign on to your agenda and in exchange for that you give me a pass on a lot of this other stuff. Once he starts departing from that agenda, that traditional Republicanism, if he starts flirting with taxes.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: What's left? What do you mean if he is departing for judicial Republicanism?

CONTINETTI: If he nominates a Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court.

TODD: OK, that's what it would take. Yes.

CONTINETTI: Judges, taxes, if he doesn't build a wall.

TODD: But on national security.

CONTINETTI: National security we saw an outrage today from the United States Senate because he's withdrawing precipitously from Syria. So, it's there. It's just on policy, not on the stuff that occupies a lot of (Inaudible)--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: But even on--

CONTINETTI: from Washington.

TODD: But even on policy, it's rhetorical and they do back off at the end of it.

CONTINETTI: What? I mean, what do you--

TODD: Meaning like they give you the sense of the Senate.

(CROSSTALK)

MARCUS: Brace a resolution.

TODD: That's right. They--

CONTINETTI: That's all they can do with a lot of these policies.

TODD: Well, no, they could do more if they chose to. Here they could have funding fights, they could do some things like this. They're not --I guess- -

(CROSSTALK)

CONTINETTI: They are -- they are members of the same party.

TODD: I understand.

CONTINETTI: So, they do have to work together to some extent.

TODD: Right. I guess the question is, do any of them worry about what this is going to look like in two years?

SCOTT: I think certainly, and I think that's what we got a taste of with the whole Khashoggi situation. Where we saw people come out and say, absolutely, Trump, the way you are responding to Saudi Arabia is not consistent with how we believe an American president or any elected leadership.

And they are very mindful of their legacy. So, I think in part because they're looking at some of these farewell speeches that they saw Orrin Hatch give, Jeff Flake give, Paul Ryan give and some of these people were getting laughed out a bit.

TODD: Well, that is what's funny. Every one of these farewell speeches, whether Republican or Democrat all contain these subtle shots at Trump. It is sort of remarkable whether really subtle or not, Ruth.

MARCUS: Well, maybe they're looking at those farewell speeches and thinking I don't want to be saying farewell like that guy had to. Because a lot of them as you pointed out--

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Yes. Wanted to stay.

MARCUS: -- weren't exactly leaving on the best of terms.

TODD: Right. All right. We got a lot more. Wait until we get to Facebook. That's going to be quite the story in a little bit. But anyway, you guys are sticking around.

Up next, the bipartisan plan to try to protect Robert Mueller. How is that working out? They're trying it one more time.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Well, you know the saying if at first you don't succeed, try, try again.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: We need to protect the independents of the special counsel and allow this crucial investigation and any like it in the future to run their course.

SEN. CHRIS COONS, (D) DELAWARE: This is an effective and ongoing federal investigation that must be allowed to reach its conclusion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: Those, of course, were Senators Jeff Flake and Chris Coons a few hours ago trying for the third time to force a vote on legislation protecting Robert Mueller's investigation, and just as before, Republicans blocked this third attempt.

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has called it a solution in search of a problem. So now in a week in which President Trump tweeted again that the Russia probe should be shut down, and in a week in which a new report claimed that Russia disinformation teams targeted Robert Mueller, himself, will anything change?

With me now are those two senators, Republican Jeff Flake of Arizona, in his last few days as a senator and Democrat Chris Coons of Delaware. Welcome, gentleman.

COONS: Thank you.

FLAKE: Thanks, Chuck.

TODD: All right. Senator Flake, why was today not any different than before and will tomorrow be any different than today when it comes to this Mueller bill?

FLAKE: You know, this bill passed the judiciary committee back in April, so we have been waiting nine months. It passed on a bipartisan basis two to one. Even and including our chairman he has a languish on the House floor awaiting for -- I'm sorry, awaiting for action on the Senate floor since that time.

And since that time, notably, in November, the president fired the attorney general. So, to say, you know, the solution is in search of a problem, I think the problem is that the Mueller probe is in danger and we need to protect it.

TODD: Senator Coons, obviously, Mitch McConnell's rationale has been it's unconstitutional. He's not convinced. Forget whether the president would veto it or not, he probably would unless you put it on the spending bill. But he argues it's unconstitutional anyway so why bother?

COONS: I am certain that it's not unconstitutional. And frankly, the fact that the Republican chairman of the judiciary committee, that a bipartisan majority of 14 to 7 on the judiciary committee voted it out and says it's ready for action on the floor, strongly suggest that we think it is more important to protect the rule of law to provide a judicial review in the case of the inappropriate, without cause abrupt firing of the special counsel, than to litigate the fine points of its constitutionality on the floor of the Senate.

TODD: Senator Flake, why do you think your colleagues are willing to push back at the president on Saudi Arabia, how they've handled Khashoggi.

FLAKE: Right.

TODD: On Syria today. And I want to get you, guys, reactions to that actually in a second. But not on this. Why the fear on this but no fear at pushing back on him on trade, no fear on Saudi Arabia? Why so much fear on pushing back on this?

FLAKE: Well, this is so central to what the president talks about every day and he has been on this for months and months and months, how this is a witch hunt.

And I think my colleagues realize, they'll be on the wrong end of a tweet or an outrage by the president. So, but I think it's far more important to protect the integrity of this investigation. It is not a witch hunt. It has led to 12 indictments of Russian nationals, as well as indictments of Americans.

So, this is a serious investigation that has to reach its conclusion. I just don't understand how my colleagues can be so sanguine about this. I really don't.

TODD: Senator Coons, are you comforted by the fact that it looks like Mueller himself has protected himself. I mean, when you look at pieces of the investigation that he's farmed out to the Southern District of New York, the U.S. attorney in D.C., the eastern district of Virginia, he seems to both been very careful about sticking to his mandate, staying very narrow on Russia and every other criminal enterprise he finds, he makes sure a fixed U.S. attorney has it. Does that make you feel better?

COONS: That's right. That's right, Chuck. I am reassured by the ways in which Robert Mueller is diligently, carefully, and with great persistence pursuing his mandate and then sending to other jurisdictions criminal matters that deserve prompt follow-up that they can handle.

But that doesn't mean that the Mueller investigation is not at risk. As the tempo has picked up. As the number of indictments, and sentencing hearings and charges has picked up, I think it is at its greatest moment of risk.

When we leave when Congress goes out of session which I think may happen as soon as tonight or tomorrow--

TODD: Yes.

COONS: -- I am very concerned President Trump will act on what he repeatedly tweets or says almost every day. He has asserted over and over again that this is a baseless witch hunt that should be shut down. Why most of my Republican colleagues won't take him at his word and act to stop this slow rolling constitutional crisis coming at us is beyond me.

I am so thankful to Senator Flake for standing up, for blocking 23 Republican judges in the judiciary committee and for again, joining me and Senator Booker on the floor today, forcing the majority leader to come out and object to our request for a live U.C. vote.

TODD: Let me pivot the conversation to Syria. Senator Flake, what concerns you more, the decision, itself, or how the president went about doing it and the lack of informing, it looks like state, Pentagon, and Congress at this point? Everybody seemed to cancel their briefings today for fear of not being able to answer any questions about it.

FLAKE: You know, any time the Pentagon is caught flat-footed, when the president says that he has agreed to withdraw troops from a country, you know you're in trouble. And so, the process more than anything, but there are serious concerns about the policy implications as well.

But my golly, the process here to not consult among agencies, particularly with the Department of the State and the Department of Defense is just jaw dropping. It really is.

(CROSSTALK)

TODD: Senator Coons--

COONS: President Trump is the first president in our nation's history with no previous experience either in the military or an elected service. And I would have hoped that he chose some humility and consult and rely upon the professional advice of the leaders of our military and also seek input from the State Department.

But, frankly, this abrupt and ill-considered decision is going to have terrible consequences on the ground in Syria. It's going to hand the keys to a whole region of Syria to Iran's forces, to Bashar al-Assad's murderous regime--

TODD: Yes.

COONS: -- and reinforce Putin's bad behavior, not just in Syria but globally.

TODD: There is one other group I'm concerned about that I wanted to -- and Senator Flake, I wanted to bring up, and that's the Kurds, who, of course, basically have been perhaps the best ally the U.S. military has had.

We know the Turks are thinking, there has been a lot of speculation that Erdogan and Turkey is about to -- you know, that he views the Kurds in northern Syria as more of a threat to him than to ISIS.

FLAKE: Right.

TODD: If the U.S. military isn't in there, are they going to get slaughtered?

FLAKE: You know, that concern was raised today certainly with the vice president here on Capitol Hill and that is a big concern that many of us have. So, you know, yes, the policy implication of this move are legion, and certainly, the way that the president has gone about this just leaves us all scratching our head.

TODD: Senator Coons, I can't tell you, I've got a lot of reaction that asks the question of, you can't help but wonder considering who the major players are in this issue, that the president's ties to Russia the president's ties to Saudi Arabia, suddenly are popping up here?

COONS: I'm gravely concerned by this abrupt decision. I do think it will lead to a lot of loss of life on the ground. And I think it raises the question, the Kurds who have fought so bravely and so hard alongside American troops to take on ISIS and to drive ISIS out of a whole region of Syria, a fight that is not yet over and not yet won.

For us to abandon them and to see this ground potentially to Turkey, I think more likely to Iran, is a grave mistake. And it does raise concerns about on what basis the president has made this decision.

TODD: Right.

COONS: Not just the process but the substance, not just the process and substance, but the consequences of this decision I think are gravely concerning to all of us who heard about it today.

FLAKE: Let me just say this points up the need again that something that Chris and I have worked on and Tim Kaine and others is to pass an AUMF for- -

TODD: Yes.

FLAKE: -- Authorization for Use of Military Force that will allow at least at this point the president, if ISIS pops back up again, to clear authority to get back in. So that desperately, it should have been done by now.

COONS: Yes.

FLAKE: But it desperately needs to be done as soon as January.

TODD: Well, the equal branch of government. We'll see if the president will abide by it when it comes to these issues of war and peace. Anyways, Senators Flake and Coons, thank you both for coming on together and sharing your views. I appreciate that.

COONS: Thank you.

FLAKE: Thank you, Chuck.

TODD: Up ahead, we told you about deny, debunk, and downplay. Well, it's not just the team Trump strategy for Russia investigations. It's also the strategy of most social media companies apparently. And now there is an entirely new uproar over what Facebook may be doing with your personal data. That's ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Tonight I'm obsessed with lunch, maybe dinner, maybe (INAUDIBLE). It all started with my obsession yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Going at loggerheads.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Loggerheads.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sort of loggerheads.

TODD (on camera): Loggerheads. Wait, loggerheads? We hear the term a lot that's why I'm proud to announce our newest MTP Daily business idea. It's Lagerheads Bar & Grill. You know what they say, Washington's always coming to Lagerheads. And do you know what goes perfectly with a loggerhead lager?

SEN. TED CRUZ (R), TEXAS: The underlying meaning is a nothingburger.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's a nothingburger.

TODD (on camera): There you have it. Come to Lagerheads and get a great, big nothingburger.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TODD: Well, guess what? A lot of you and a lot of us got to thinking, hey, maybe this ridiculous idea could actually work. So you know, let's build a menu. So of course, you can't build a whole restaurant on nothingburgers alone. What else could you put on the Lagerheads' menu?

Of course, a good meal has to start with bread, right? So how about a breadbasket of deplorables? It is the best of the world's grain, served naturally with a side of margarine of error. On the appetizer menu, it's a vast barbecue wing conspiracy. We'll serve the right or the left wings. It's your choice. We're bipartisan at Lagerheads.

Maybe a side of lame duck fat fries is to your liking. Yes, we do all of our frying in duck fat, so it's really good. Or for the health conscious costumer, how about a tossed word salad? And hey, you can even get it with Russian dressing on the side.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Earlier, we talked about the denial, debunked downplay strategy employed by President Trump and his allies with the Russian probe. Folks, they are not the only ones running this PR strategy.

The same playbook is being used by big tech. Here's Facebook CEO and chairman Mark Zuckerberg testifying before the House in April, telling Congresswoman Doris Matsui that Facebook users have complete control over their data.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: One core tenant of our advertising system is that we don't sell data to advertisers. Advertisers don't get access to your data.

REP. DORIS MATSUI (D), CALIFORNIA: But we're not controlling that data.

ZUCKERBERG: No, you have complete control over that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: Ah, not true. According to a story out in The New York Times today, some companies had access to users' data even if they had disabled all sharing. Facebook allowed Microsoft's Bing search engine to see the names of virtually all Facebook users' friends without consent, and by the way gave Netflix and Spotify the ability to read Facebook users' private messages.

Facebook told the Times that most of its partner companies are "service providers," which exempts them from data regulations. Ah, see, deny, then debunk. You see where they are going here.

Joining me now is somebody who just loves social media companies these days. It's Kara Swisher, the executive editor of Recode.

KARA SWISHER, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, RECODE: Hi, Chuck.

TODD: Hi, Kara. I thought of you today. I thought of our podcast a few weeks ago.

SWISHER: Yep.

TODD: When you basically said, I don't know if a social media, if there is any good that comes out of a social media company anymore, and I thought it was a pretty rough --

SWISHER: Yeah.

TODD: -- rough thing to say, and then the Facebook story this morning.

SWISHER: Well, I think the question is what control you have over it and what you know about it. I thin one of the issues -- when I read the story, one of the things that really struck me is how little, how sloppy they were around the data. I think that's what people are worried about. What happens to data? What they think consent is? What they don't think consent is?

And the fact that there are no real rules, even though they say their rules and say you have complete control, until regulators step in and really make it very clear what the rules of the road are, these companies are able to make rules of their own instead of stretch them.

And so that's what gets confusing in this whole thing, is that they stay -- I think Mark Zuckerberg does believe you gave consent to do the things he's allowed his partners to do.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: So that's the problem here.

TODD: Let's be realistic. We talked about it this morning. The consent -- their whole goal is to not inform you how often they plan on using your data, right? So, it's like, OK, we're going to get your consent --

SWISHER: Right.

TODD: -- as quickly and early as possible.

SWISHER: Yeah.

TODD: We'll make you do it. If you want to download this app, give us all your consent now.

SWISHER: Right.

TODD: It's like a pressure tactic. I don't think we realize we are basically under a privacy sharing pressure tactic in that moment that they tell us, download that app.

SWISHER: Or if you want to use an app, you want to use Spotify by signing in with Facebook. All kinds of things. It's highly confusing. It's meant to be convenient. I think it's hard (ph) it's meant to be convenient. And what it is, is they tend to pars words. I was just having a Twitter war with someone who used to work at Facebook.

We don't sell your data. Well, they actually don't sell your data to advertisers. Mark is absolutely accurate in that. What they do is they take data and then they match (ph) it with other data and they pull it and they target and they put it on and then they sell the insights to advertisers and they let you target.

(LAUGHTER)

SWISHER: So they are kind of selling your data without selling your data. And so what you do is you get arguments with these ad people over -- the fact of the matter is you don't have control over what happens. Are you are uploading so much data into these systems, not just via Facebook, via Twitter, via your cell phone, via your home nest machine, whatever, they're everywhere.

So that's the question, who has control over this data and what should happen to it? It is a really good question for regulators.

TODD: The other thing I have here is -- you know, we talk about all the time the trust that I think has been lost by the president and particularly his legal team with how far they've gone to spin Russia developments. Every one of them gets debunked. And suddenly if you apply the same standard to social media companies, we can start with Facebook, is Facebook aware of how bad they look?

Let me just put up four examples, three examples here to point this out. Obviously, it was Mark Zuckerberg's first reaction, November 11, 2016 when he said, the idea that fake news on Facebook, which is a very small amount of the content, influence the election in anyway I think is a pretty crazy idea.

Obviously, his tune has changed. What have we now learned? Two hundred sixty-three million engagements by the internet research agency of the Russians, a Russian troll content on Facebook platforms. That was from the Senate Intelligence Committee.

And then the story about Facebook employing a Republican oppositin research firm essentially to go after George Soros. That is a political tactic.

SWISHER: Yeah.

TODD: That's attack that we would have expected from a campaign. This is a company that claims, oh, let's go back to the way it was in the old days of Facebook. Whatever that was.

SWISHER: Yeah. I think you keep mistaking it for not a company. I mean, these are companies that make billions of dollars. Mark Zuckerberg is a multi-billionaire, $64 billion. These are very wealthy people that are doing a lot of growth at all cost strategies.

And so I think what happens is, you know, you sort of put them in hoodies and sneakers and you think they're still not sort of people that want to make as much money as possible. And so these companies need to be aggressive and they should be competitive.

The question is how they're doing it and how they're communicating to users of what they're using your data for. It's an advertising business. It's designed to advertise and to sell toilet paper or toothpaste or whatever.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: You got to keep that in mind. Facebook hates when I say this and they hate when a lot of people say it. In many ways, you are the product they're selling in some way, but they're not directly selling you.

TODD: That's Tim Cook's favorite line.

SWISHER: Yeah, it is. I think he's right. Even though it's in Tim Cook's interest to say, he's correct when he says it.

TODD: Here's I guess the other aspect about this. Do you believe that the social media companies can get their arms around this problem now? You seem to think it's too late, like as much as maybe they are actually genuinely would like to figure out how to keep these social media networks from being abused, as you have said, Russia used it the exact way it was meant to be used.

SWISHER: Yeah, I said that yesterday in a column in the Times. Yeah, exactly. I mean, they're customers of Facebook. That's what I call them. I said they're customers of Facebook or Twitter or Google and YouTube.

I think the problem is the amount of stuff that is coming over these social networks or whatever, any of these digital platforms, it's so vast. You have to use a combination. A.I. and humans and there's all the sort of -- it's global. There are issues that are different in India versus here versus Venezuela.

TODD: Right.

SWISHER: It is such a massive -- and then it has societal impact, political impact. These are massive problems as if you took a newspaper and made it a global newspaper that everybody read at once. Who controls that? That's the big problem. Who can be in charge of figuring this out? And at Facebook, there is only one person, that is Mark Zuckerberg.

TODD: Is Facebook a media company?

SWISHER: Yes. Different kind.

TODD: Well, if they were a media company, the amount of fines they would have incurred by now would have put it out of business. Is it time for the federal government to essentially force Facebook to -- because what are you describing all the ways that they could stop this means they have to spend money to essentially on a whole bunch of stuff that will cost them money, not make them money.

SWISHER: That's right.

TODD: And the only way you can make the tobacco companies stop selling, you have to force them. They are never going to do this out of the goodness of their heart.

SWISHER: There are lots. There is the Communications Decency Act which has Section 230 which grants broad immunity to these platforms. Should these platforms have this broad immunity to do whatever they want?

It is like they created a city without police, firemen, anything else, and everyone is running wild. It is like a version of "The Purge" that goes on every day. You know what I mean. It just keeps going on. The question is who can control this. Probably the government eventually.

TODD: We're a long way from when we thought, oh, my god, the Arab spring, social media --

SWISHER: Yeah.

TODD: Now, it's the authoritarian's favorite tool of choice, is it not?

SWISHER: It is. It is. And that's the problem. There is good and bad to it. There is good to it. I love tech. You love tech. It's not a question of that. It's a question of how do we manage this so that we can figure out how to make it all the good that it could bring to this world.

TODD: We just all want to have control of our own privacy.

SWISHER: Yes, that's true.

TODD: That's all. Not a lot to ask. Probably a lot to spend money, Mr. Zuckerberg. Anyway, Kara Swisher, thank you for never holding back.

SWISHER: Thanks a lot.

TODD: Up ahead, why Democrats might have an election situation of biblical proportions. 2020 Vision is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Welcome back. Today in 2020 Vision, do Democrats have a Noah's Arc situation, marching two by two into the fray? We love this. The potential field includes at least two Californians, two Ohioans, two Texans, two from Massachusetts and now maybe two Coloradans.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. MICHAEL BENNET (D), COLORADO (voice over): I'm thinking about it.

TODD (voice over): Colorado Senator Michael Bennet confirmed in an interview with Yahoo News that he is considering a run for president, and he is already showing how he'd offer a contrast to President Trump.

BENNET (voice over): What we have is carnage of our institutions.

TODD (voice over): But believe it or not, he might find himself competing against his former boss in the 2020 primary. Then it used to be the chief of staff to a mayor of Denver by the name of John Hickenlooper who of course is now about to be the outgoing governor of Colorado. And guess what, he sounds like he wants to be president, too.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: How close are you?

GOV. JOHN HICKENLOOPER (D), COLORADO: I'd say we're past 50-50, I think we're probably 63, 64 percent.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TODD: I love the accuracy there. It's 63 percent, not 62 and not 65. At this rate, though, we can get Democrats from every state marching into the 2020 primary. So why not? Let's make it 100 candidates, Democrats. We will be back with more MTP Daily right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: Time now for The Lid. President Trump as you heard earlier is facing some withering criticism from some fellow Republicans for his decision to withdraw troops from Syria and claiming victory over ISIS in doing so. Take listen to some of the push back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MARCO RUBIO (R), FLORIDA: The decision to withdraw American -- an American presence in Syria is a colossal in my mind a mistake, a great error.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: If Trump withdraws from Syria and they do come back, like I think they will, he will be one of the reasons they came back.

SEN. BOB CORKER (R), TENNESSEE: Honestly, this makes what Obama did in Iraq, it's replicating that, but in many ways, it's even worse.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: The panel is back. Eugene Scott, Ruth Marcus, Matthew Continetti. Matthew, there are sort of two pieces of criticism the president is receiving today. How he unveiled it and the substance of it, what was interesting is the near unanimous, apparently like even the president's own cabinet is not happy with this decision. I'm referring to both Mattis and Pompeo.

MATTHEW CONTINETTI, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, WASHINGTON FREE BEACON: Well, they have reason not to be happy with it. That's our presence in Syria providing reassurance there to our allies and presence to kind of deter Assad and the Russia, Turkey, Iran, all the various bad actors in that country from taking hostile actions, we are now removing that.

And just as American power is off in the lid on that pressure cooker and around the world, you remove that lid from pressure cooker, bad things come out.

TODD: Ruth, I do think it was interesting to watch the president's tweets by this. He said I was only there because of ISIS. As we know, he's a bit of a dove when it came to troops in the Middle East, period. So, he's always actually been at odds with that one wing of his party (ph).

RUTH MARCUS, COLUMNIST, THE WASHINGTON POST: More like Obama in that sense than like --

TODD: I think he's less hawkish than Obama is. I think you would put him actually to the left on some of these issues.

MARCUS: I think that's true. But the thing that's so tragic to me in this decision is our apparent inability to learn from the mistakes of the past. His own advisers were saying just last week and the other day that the one thing we've learned is if you withdraw physical presence, you allow the same problem to recreate itself. Yet, we did it in Afghanistan years ago. We did it in Iraq. We're about to do it again.

TODD: And what happened each time? Each time, we have to send more troops back.

MARCUS: Precisely.

EUGENE SCOTT, POLITICAL REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: I think there are two things happening. One, it's a reminder that we have a president who has not visited any of our troops in action and therefore is perhaps making decisions with a lack of awareness and knowledge that one would hope that a commander in chief would be able to do.

But something else I'm thinking about is that we see our president campaigning for reelection based on the slogan promises kept. This is a promise he made to his voters in 2016 about ISIS and has not been able to deliver on.

So whether or not it's the best decision or the most well informed decision, he wants to double down on it because he can lean in on that, just kind of like the wall, right? Something he campaigned on and that he has to push through despite there being no support for it really or significant support from the base.

MARCUS: I'm not even sure -- I understand he wants to be out of there, but there's not a clamor from the base to withdraw the troops.

TODD: Yeah.

MARCUS: It's a small number of troops.

TODD: Yeah.

MARCUS: While I think he should go visit the troops, you don't have to go visit troops to understand that your policy makers, your Republican compatriots in the Senate and the House understand, for good reason, that this is a really bad idea. I wonder if if it's not a base appeasing mechanism, it's a distraction mechanism. That's really scary, terrible thing to suggest.

CONTINETTI: Or it's just an impulse that he has and so --

TODD: It doesn't help though that there's a whole bunch of countries involved here that also are being investigated for their ties to Trump.

CONTINETTI: Sure, but they don't --

TODD: I'm just saying --

CONTINETTI: Saudi Arabia doesn't benefit from this decision. Saudi Arabia --

TODD: They don't but Russia does.

CONTINETTI: Russia does.

TODD: Erdogan does. Turkey does.

CONTINETTI: Americans fired on Russian troops. It's not like we have the - -

TODD: No doubt.

CONTINETTI: Here's what this reminds me of. His decision to have the summit with Kim earlier this year. If you go back to last spring, that decision came about because Trump was in a conversation with the South Korean national security adviser who brought up President Moon's progress with Kim and Trump seized on that and said, oh, we're going to have a summit.

MARCUS: What does he seize on here?

CONTINETTI: He seized on a conversation recently he had with the Turkish president, Erdogan.

TODD: When he found out that Erdogan --

(CROSSTALK)

CONTINETTI: We don't know the contents of that conversation but the fact that this decision is following rapidly on the heels of it suggests to me something was said during that phone call that has led to this result which I believe threatens the national security of the United States.

TODD: And what happens if the Kurds do get slaughtered there without our presence?

MARCUS: Well, you know, we will have abandoned them yet again. This is a tragedy in its own right. It's a mistake in its own right. It also so undercuts the ability of not just the Kurds but of other allies to rely on the United States to do the job, keep its word. Have a policy that is rational and predictable policy. That's not what we have here.

SCOTT: And it reinforces some data we have seen in the past year about how the standing of the United States has declined globally in the eyes of many world leaders and just citizens abroad who look to the United States to make the best and most informed decisions on things like this.

TODD: It's just a case of us not being there. Thank you, guys. Much appreciate it. Up ahead, something really is out there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TODD: In case you missed it, space. It's quite literally all around us. But do we really know anything about it? Well, perhaps we're going to know more now. Thanks to one of NASA's newest hires. Meet Bettina Inclan. She's a long time GOP spokesperson and activist, and now she's the newest associate administrator for communication.

And for Bettina Inclan, talking about space runs in the family. This is her mom. Battina Rodriguez Aguilera. This year, she ran unsuccessfully for Congress in Florida. She was even endorsed by they way by the Miami Herald which called her an unusual candidate. Now, why, you might ask why she is so unusual. Because Bettina Rodriguez Aguilera claims she was once abducted by aliens.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BETTINA RODRIGUEZ AGUILERA, REPUBLICAN CANDIDATE FOR FLORIDA'S 27TH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT IN THE U.S. HOUSEI (through translator): My first experience was when I was seven years old. I had a dark connection with three people who look a little bit like you.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translator): Seriously?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TODD: Look, I can't say for sure whether she was abducted or not, but I can say I know someone who would be jealous.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Beam me up. Beam me up. Beam me up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TODD: It never did work for legendary Ohio Congressman Jim Traficant. I would tell you why but unfortunately, we're out of time.

That's all for tonight. "THE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER" starts right now.

ARI MELBER, MSNBC HOST: Incredible. Thank you for that. Good evening to you at home.
