Ambani's company is in talks with domestic assemblers to make a version of its Jio phone that would run on Google's Android Reliance Industries Ltd has asked local suppliers to ramp up production capacity in India so they can make as many as 200 million sm...

Ambani's company is in talks with domestic assemblers to make a version of its Jio phone that would run on Google's Android Reliance Industries Ltd has asked local suppliers to ramp up production capacity in India so they can make as many as 200 million smartphones over the next two years, according to people familiar with the matter, a potentially enormous boost for the country’s technology ambitions and a warning shot to rivals such as Xiaomi Corp. India’s most valuable company is in talks with domestic assemblers to make a version of its Jio phone that would run on Google’s Android and cost about 4,000 rupees ($54), said the people, asking not to be identified since the plans are private. The inexpensive phones will be marketed with low-cost wireless plans from Reliance Jio, the parent company’s carrier, they said. Reliance Chairman Mukesh Ambani is aiming to remake the country’s smartphone industry much like he did in wireless services, where his aggressive prices and simple plans quickly made him the dominant force. The billionaire is also aligning himself with the Indian government’s plans to build more domestic manufacturing, a possible boost for local assemblers like Dixon Technologies India, Lava International and Karbonn Mobiles. “We are of course trying to build our domestic companies. We have a sweet spot in entry level phones,” said Pankaj Mohindroo, chairman of the India Cellular & Electronic Association, during an interview on Bloomberg Television. “The world has realized that India is a great place to do business and a great place to do manufacturing also.” ALSO READ: Mukesh Ambani's $2 chutzpah unlocks another fortune for Reliance Industries Reliance’s target of selling 150 million to 200 million phones over two years would represent a massive boost for local factories. India assembled an estimated 165 million smartphones in the year ended March, and about an equal number of basic feature phones, according to Mohindroo’s association. About a fifth of the smartphones cost less than 7,000 rupees, or about $100. Reliance rival Bharti Airtel is also in talks with assemblers to build its own 4G device, local media has reported. The Business Standard reported earlier that Ambani was considering outsourcing phone-making. Reliance in July struck a broad alliance with Google, in which the Alphabet Inc. unit would invest $4.5 billion and cooperate on technology initiatives. The partnership is still under regulatory review so Reliance is proceeding with the mobile phone initiative on its own for now. Ambani has drawn more than $20 billion in investments from U.S. giants like Facebook Inc. for Jio Platforms Pvt, whose subsidiary Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd. is placing the order. It’s worked with assemblers on prototypes for at least two years in secret and can bring a phone rapidly to market, though it’s likely to miss the November Diwali shopping season, the people said. If Reliance succeeds in popularizing the new gadget, it could lift the prospects for Jio Platforms, accelerating Ambani’s efforts to build an empire spanning e-commerce, social media and games. Many of Jio’s nearly 400 million users use no-frills second-generation devices, paying $2 monthly for voice and data -- a large potential market for the new device. It could eventually erode the market share of Chinese phonemakers such as Xiaomi. “Jio has an opportunity to target more than half billion Indians who don’t own a smartphone and trigger a blue ocean market opportunity,” said Neil Shah, research director at Counterpoint Research. “With Reliance expected to work with Indian vendors, Chinese brands will lose out on a potential opportunity and market share.” ALSO READ: For big tech, all roads to India's digital space seem to go through Ambani Reliance’s own requirements could hover around 5 million gadgets per month initially, but no single Indian company currently has that kind of capacity so the order will get split between multiple assemblers, the people said. At least two domestic smartphone makers are in discussions with the telecom giant, the people added. Phones have become essential for accessing lite versions of apps from WhatsApp to YouTube in a country with an average GDP per capita of around $2,000. That’s why basic devices costing between $100 and $250 accounted for three-quarters of sales in the second quarter of 2020, according to Counterpoint. Reliance’s fourth-generation wireless gadgets -- one tier below 5G -- are aimed at the estimated 350 million users of basic or feature phones that now dominate India’s industry. Speaking at an industry event a few weeks ago, Ambani said millions were “trapped in the 2G era.” “Their feature phones keep them excluded, even from the basic uses of internet at a time where both India and the rest of the world are standing at the doorsteps of 5G telephony,” he said. The pandemic is spurring people to upgrade and creating new market opportunities. For example, parents are anxious to put a device in the hands of their kids so they can keep up with online lessons. There’re an estimated 250 million children between the ages of 6 and 16, according to UNICEF. “If they’re successful in getting even 10% of this base to upgrade, Jio can become one of the leading smartphone brands of 2021,” Shah said.

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Welcome to a special edition of TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT, our Tech Tyranny edition. Multi-billion dollar companies in Silicon Valley are waging, in effect, a war on your privacy, your culture, your freedom of speech.

They are the portal through which all human information flows and they have their thumb on the scale. The results of the searches you conduct online they control those. Your phone, they own it, in effect. They track you everywhere you go. Even when the phone is off, they collect intimate information on you. They sell it to advertisers for a profit. They give you no details about this.

These companies are politically radical. They are funding the activism that's changing our country right now. There's nothing that you can do to check their power. Congress should be doing that but they're not.

Increasingly, these countries are using their power and influence to shape the world around us. Some of these companies are bigger than the economies of entire nations. This show is an examination of those companies and the effects they have on our lives, our country, and our politics. The scale of their reach is enormous. And it is finally drawing the attention of policymakers including the President.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD J. TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think that Google and Facebook and Twitter, I think they treat conservatives and Republicans very unfairly. And I think it's a very serious problem because they're really trying to silence a very large part of this country. And those people don't want to be silenced. It's not right. It's not fair. It may not be legal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: FOX News Headlines Anchor Brett Larson has been on the tech beat for us for quite some time. And he's going to set the table for us tonight. Brett?

BRETT LARSON, ANCHOR, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7: All right Tucker, yes. Earlier this week, the President sent out a tweet in which he said in part "Google Search results for Trump News shows only the viewing/reporting of Fake News Media. In other words, they have it rigged for me and others so that almost all stories and news is bad."

Now Google was quick to respond to the claim in a statement saying in part "Search is not used to set a political agenda and we don't bias our results toward any political ideology."

As for how Google Search works that is a closely guarded secret. Algorithms used by online sites including Google, Twitter and Facebook are protected like the recipe for Coca-Cola. Why? Well if sites knew exactly how the search site worked, it would be easier to rig their web content to reach a larger audience.

But a few things are known about how Google Search works. Google is scanning the web for new pages around the clock and they're looking for a variety of things to ensure that the right pages are delivered to the right people.

They check to see that a site is mobile-friendly, so it renders properly on your smartphone if you're on the go. They also check to make sure the content is original and not just some plagiarized information with a bunch of ads slapped around it.

But where you go online also affects your search results. As we know, and we have reported here before, Google keeps track of virtually everything you do mainly to ensure they show you the right ads. We'll have more on our investigation later this hour.

But, in this case, it's also to ensure you're getting the right search results. As for news search, it's a little different. As we know, news is happening 24 hours a day. But a reliable source is needed for a news story.

A site that creates more content that is optimized for search will likely get a higher ranking but also a site that gets click-through from the results. So if, for example, you search for California wildfires and in the results more people are going to our FOX affiliate, KTVU, their site, they will move higher in the rankings.

Now this is where the mainstream media has an advantage. Though as they present more middle-of-the-road news without leaning to the left or to the right, so they'll have a larger reach within those results. Tucker?

CARLSON: Depending upon who defines what middle-of-the-road is.

LARSON: Yes.

CARLSON: Brett, thank you very much.

LARSON: Thanks Tucker.

CARLSON: We're going to see you later this hour.

LARSON: Yes.

CARLSON: So you just heard what Google says it does. The question is can we trust them? That is the central question. Here's some background on the company.

Google just removed its famous catchphrase "Don't be evil" from its corporate code of conduct earlier this year. It was a symbolic change but also maybe ominous for the most powerful company in human history.

Google's market cap is now about $860 billion. That's more than the gross domestic product of almost every country in the world. 170 countries have smaller GDPs than Google. But I guess it kind of fits with Google's new move into China where, of course, and you know, China, they assign social media scores or media scores or, you know, scores to people that loud that then follow them throughout their lives, so, you know, the government can control where you - whether you get to travel and all of that based on this information.

And in Silicon Valley, it's almost the same thing. If you're assigned a socially undesirable label by big media or big tech then all of a sudden you are now out. You're persona non grata.

CARLSON: So, this is the company who's trying to destroy a young man's life because it didn't agree with a memo he wrote. This is the company we trust to hold all human information and sort it for us?

DHILLON: I mean I don't trust it anymore. A lot of people use, you know, their services. But I think people should be very careful. And again, you know, not to, you know, sort of bring in this other issue but when - when they have all this information about you and they're openly agreeing to censorship in foreign countries at the demand of foreign countries, how long is it before you can expect to see that more openly done here? We - we know--

CARLSON: It's exactly right.

DHILLON: --it already happens here with search results and so forth but, you know, in - in a couple of years when they're doing business in China, are you going to be able to search for the Dalai Lama in America and get accurate search results?

I think that's a huge question that we should be asking and the government should be asking that because, you know, these companies all operate with tremendous market power and they meet regularly. Just, I think, last week--

CARLSON: Yes.

DHILLON: There was a meeting of the top tech companies to talk about election interference and, you know, what does that really mean and are they--

CARLSON: That's a great question.

DHILLON: --operating as a cartel (ph) in certain ways?

CARLSON: Of course they are.

DHILLON: Sure (ph).

CARLSON: And Congress should act immediately. But they're too afraid. Harmeet Dhillon, thank you for this. Good to see you.

DHILLON: My pleasure.

CARLSON: So once you decide that it's OK to censor opinions you disagree with, where does that wind up? That's next.

CARLSON: Well, the tech giants see themselves as gatekeepers of the internet and, as such, routinely engage in censorship of political speech, speech they disagree with. In most cases, that affects conservatives.

But non-mainstream liberals have been targeted too, especially those who express opposition to the democratic establishment or to endless war. What are the boundaries of censorship once a company starts making decisions about what speech is permissible and which speech is not?

Jesse Kelly is a Marine Corps combat veteran who has fought for free speech abroad. He is the host of the Jesse Kelly Radio Show in Houston and he joins us tonight. Jesse, thank you very much for coming on.

So, you wrote this piece that I thought was really compelling about Alex Jones. And you said "Look, I don't agree with Alex Jones, his views but that's not the point." The point, as you articulated, was if you can silence this guy because you don't like what he says why can't they silence you or me?

JESSE KELLY, UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS COMBAT VETERAN: That's - that is the point, Tucker. And they're coming for you and me next.

Alex Jones was the weak member of the herd because of his insane views on certain things. They knew they could pick him off, and what he was, was a test-run. If we can pick off this nutjob then maybe sooner or later we can come for the more mainstream voices on the right.

This is not - the social media, Facebook, Twitter, that's 2.5 billion people they reach. People have to understand it's no longer a couple of nerds sitting in a college dorm room swapping stories about a made-up girlfriend. It's real and it's powerful.

CARLSON: So, I watched feeling nauseous as almost no figures on that as you just said mainstream right rose to the defense of Alex Jones, not defending what he said but defending his right to say it, the most basic American principle. Why did they sit silently as this happened?

KELLY: Because everybody wants to be the one that's eaten last, Tucker. They convince themselves--

CARLSON: Yes, exactly.

KELLY: --in the interest of never having to have a fight that if the lion will just gorge himself on enough of those antelope eventually he'll never come eat me. But that's not how it works. It is - it is we're really whistling past the graveyard.

We gave them Hollywood. We gave them the education system. And to rely on Google Now or Facebook for your news is like pouring a cup of coffee and then filtering it through a jockstrap before you drink it.

CARLSON: Which doesn't work, I've checked. Yes, I mean social media very quickly really is the last place where dissent is allowed. It's not allowed in the workplace. It's not allowed in public parks. If they take that away people with different views are silenced, correct?

KELLY: It is - it is - correct. It is the final frontier. It's no longer just a random thing. It is how you break news. It's how you make news.

CARLSON: Yes.

KELLY: Social media makes careers. It's - it's how things are done. It's what's used by law enforcement to track people. It is the information age and if we--

CARLSON: That's exactly right.

KELLY: --let Left to censor that that's modern book-burning is what that is.

CARLSON: Jesse Kelly, so nicely put. God bless you for standing up for speech especially against the backdrop of all the cowardice around us. It's distressing. Thank you.

KELLY: Appreciate you.

CARLSON: That's it for the special edition of TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT, investigation into big tech topic. We're going to keep up with every night at 8:00, so join us there. We'll see you.

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Welcome to a special edition of TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT, our Tech Tyranny edition. Multi-billion dollar companies in Silicon Valley are waging, in effect, a war on your privacy, your culture, your freedom of speech.

They are the portal through which all human information flows and they have their thumb on the scale. The results of the searches you conduct online they control those. Your phone, they own it, in effect. They track you everywhere you go. Even when the phone is off, they collect intimate information on you. They sell it to advertisers for a profit. They give you no details about this.

These companies are politically radical. They are funding the activism that's changing our country right now. There's nothing that you can do to check their power. Congress should be doing that but they're not.

Increasingly, these countries are using their power and influence to shape the world around us. Some of these companies are bigger than the economies of entire nations. This show is an examination of those companies and the effects they have on our lives, our country, and our politics. The scale of their reach is enormous. And it is finally drawing the attention of policymakers including the President.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD J. TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think that Google and Facebook and Twitter, I think they treat conservatives and Republicans very unfairly. And I think it's a very serious problem because they're really trying to silence a very large part of this country. And those people don't want to be silenced. It's not right. It's not fair. It may not be legal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: FOX News Headlines Anchor Brett Larson has been on the tech beat for us for quite some time. And he's going to set the table for us tonight. Brett?

BRETT LARSON, ANCHOR, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7: All right Tucker, yes. Earlier this week, the President sent out a tweet in which he said in part "Google Search results for Trump News shows only the viewing/reporting of Fake News Media. In other words, they have it rigged for me and others so that almost all stories and news is bad."

Now Google was quick to respond to the claim in a statement saying in part "Search is not used to set a political agenda and we don't bias our results toward any political ideology."

As for how Google Search works that is a closely guarded secret. Algorithms used by online sites including Google, Twitter and Facebook are protected like the recipe for Coca-Cola. Why? Well if sites knew exactly how the search site worked, it would be easier to rig their web content to reach a larger audience.

But a few things are known about how Google Search works. Google is scanning the web for new pages around the clock and they're looking for a variety of things to ensure that the right pages are delivered to the right people.

They check to see that a site is mobile-friendly, so it renders properly on your smartphone if you're on the go. They also check to make sure the content is original and not just some plagiarized information with a bunch of ads slapped around it.

But where you go online also affects your search results. As we know, and we have reported here before, Google keeps track of virtually everything you do mainly to ensure they show you the right ads. We'll have more on our investigation later this hour.

But, in this case, it's also to ensure you're getting the right search results. As for news search, it's a little different. As we know, news is happening 24 hours a day. But a reliable source is needed for a news story.

A site that creates more content that is optimized for search will likely get a higher ranking but also a site that gets click-through from the results. So if, for example, you search for California wildfires and in the results more people are going to our FOX affiliate, KTVU, their site, they will move higher in the rankings.

Now this is where the mainstream media has an advantage. Though as they present more middle-of-the-road news without leaning to the left or to the right, so they'll have a larger reach within those results. Tucker?

CARLSON: Depending upon who defines what middle-of-the-road is.

LARSON: Yes.

CARLSON: Brett, thank you very much.

LARSON: Thanks Tucker.

CARLSON: We're going to see you later this hour.

LARSON: Yes.

CARLSON: So you just heard what Google says it does. The question is can we trust them? That is the central question. Here's some background on the company.

Google just removed its famous catchphrase "Don't be evil" from its corporate code of conduct earlier this year. It was a symbolic change but also maybe ominous for the most powerful company in human history.

Google's market cap is now about $860 billion. That's more than the gross domestic product of almost every country in the world. 170 countries have smaller GDPs than Google. The Federal Trade Commission prepared an anti- trust case against the tech giant a few years ago but the Obama Justice Department didn't take it.

Google now controls roughly 90 percent of the search engine market, 65 percent of the internet browser market. It controls 85 percent of the mobile operating systems on the phones in our pockets right now.

Google controls an outsized portion of the online ad market which means they also control the companies that rely on online advertising that is every single digital news company in the United States.

Google has an army of lobbyists in Washington. It bankrolls politicians in both parties. It contributes to virtually every major think tank in Washington regardless of ideologies including, hilariously, a think tank dedicated to fighting monopolies.

At least one of those think tanks has fired a staff for being critical of Google. So the question is, and it may be rhetorical, is Google too powerful to regulate?

Scott Cleland is the author of Search & Destroy: Why You Can't Trust Google Inc. He joins us now.

So Scott, very quickly on the search question that seems like one of the most basic questions, all of our information comes through this tiny little portal, Google says "Trust us. We're not putting our thumb on the scale." Can we?

SCOTT CLELAND, PRESIDENT, PRECURSOR LLC, INTERNETIZATION STRATEGIST: No, we can't because it's blanket trust. It's blind trust because no one does really know what goes on there.

The problem is when you put all of access of supply and demand to access all the world's information through one black box, one thing that we have no transparency to, we don't understand. And let's not forget, the whole purpose of it is to rank, so it is to choose--

CARLSON: Right.

CLELAND: --what is best. They said for years it's algorithmic. So if it's algorithmic it must be OK. Well an algorithm is just a computer program that - that people decided what the biases would be.

CARLSON: Right.

CLELAND: Their purposeful biases. But the problem of Google is the fact that we have concentrated all that power in one company because if it's - it's the most harmful monopoly you can imagine. Information is power. Power corrupts - absolute - power corrupts absolutely.

In a constitutional republic, in a free market, the free flow of information and the competition of ideas are paramount and central. And when you go through one black box and say that is all occurring only here and there's one person that basically sets what the ideology and the approach is going to be, and it's Larry Page, and then that filters through, you have a - it's a very scary situation.

You want a competition for ideas. You want a competition for sources. He has created an unbelievably innovative and great search engine. No criticism there in the sense of its capability. But how the government - and I, for 10 years, been trying to prevent this monopoly and the government screwed up over time and time again in allowing Google to become this monopoly.

CARLSON: That's for sure. So - so quickly, news reports have reported that Google is working to devise a search engine that would help the Fascist Government of China repress its own people. So given that we know we believe we know that they are willing to suppress information on behalf of a government to achieve repressive political ends, why should we trust them not to do that to us?

CLELAND: Well we shouldn't. And my goodness, this is always Orwellian as it comes because when that was brought up and when somebody, you know, on who we know criticized Google for bias in its search, the President of the United States, they had their answer that says "We never make our search results based on a political ideology." Well they are committing to do it for China, for the entire country, soup-to-nuts for everything they're going to bow down to the Chinese ideology, so--

CARLSON: You're (ph) not a big deal. A country that executes political prisoners and sells their organs, seems like just the kind of people you'd want, you know, to help remain in power.

CLELAND: But how they can say that with straight face and then saying that they're not bending it - their will to ideology. They do it all around the world.

CARLSON: Well, they're lying. Scott, you have been fighting a lonely crusade on behalf of this idea and we're obviously rooting for you. Thank you.

CLELAND: Thank you.

CARLSON: So European regulators fined Google billions after they accused the company of abusing its power in engaging in anti-competitive practices. American regulators meanwhile are nowhere to be found. Why is that exactly?

Luther Lowe is the Senior Vice President of Public Policy for Yelp. And he joins us now. Luther thanks for coming.

LUTHER LOWE, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT OF PUBLIC POLICY, YELP: It's good to be here (ph).

CARLSON: And I'm always particularly happy to talk to you since you're right in the middle of this world. You work for a big tech company. It's a really simple question. Google has a monopoly. Nobody debates that. Monopolies are supposed to be banned by U.S. law. We have a whole Congress with 535 people designed to protect us from monopolies but they're not. Why?

LOWE: Well I think there are - there's political capture going on. And I think if you have a - a search engine that is clearly guilty of self- serving bias, and I'm not talking about the type of self-serving bias that President Trump tweeted about earlier this week, I'm talking about demonstrable, easy-to-prove bias in the most common area of what we do on Google, which is local search.

This should be a slam dunk. You - we should be able to show consumer harm. And in fact, we have done so. You know, when a mom does a search for a pediatrician in Salt Lake City, she is basically trusting Google to match her with the best information from across the web.

CARLSON: Yes, absolutely (ph).

LOWE: That has been the implicit promise to Google's users throughout its growth. But what's happened is that Google has swapped out that information and put their own inferior information there. And so, this creates consumer harm and it gets back to your question about monopoly.

If you can show that consumer harm then you can easily prosecute an anti- trust case. And this is why, I think, we should focus on the business conduct of Google as it relates to search bias.

CARLSON: Well, I agree completely. But it - the - the monopoly is prima facie, and so is the harm.

LOWE: Right.

CARLSON: You work in Washington on this issue. Doubtless, you've spoken to Members of Congress and you've told them what they already know. This is - company's too powerful. It has a monopoly. It's hurting consumers. How did they respond?

LOWE: I mean I think we are starting to see the tide turn. And I was really heartened to see, for example, Senator Hatch's letter yesterday to the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission where he basically said listen, you know, we closed the last investigation in 2013.

One expects that when you close an anti-trust investigation the market is going to be less calcified that there are going to be, you know, the company in question is going to be less entrenched. There's got to be more start-up and so forth but we're seeing the opposite. And so, maybe we should take another look at this. And so, I think we're beginning to see the tide turn--

CARLSON: Good, good for Senator Hatch. But I think there are 99 other guys in the same chamber. Where are they? What would be the justification quickly for not acting? I don't understand.

LOWE: Well the FTC, we have a completely new slate of FTC commissioners. They're running public hearing - hearings now to collect information. And I'm cautiously optimistic that we're going to re-examine a lot of these questions as we should.

CARLSON: Google is not an American company. It's a multinational. This is a foreign threat to our country. That's my view. It's a national security threat. Thank you for the work you've done.

LOWE: Thank you, Tucker (ph).

CARLSON: Free online services aren't actually free. You may have known that. They come at a cost. You're paying that cost in privacy. We've got details ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Welcome back to our special TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT, Tech Tyranny. And tyranny is not an overstatement in this case. The man behind the book and the movie Clinton Cash that exposed the Clinton Foundation's pay-for- play relationship with various foreign governments is coming out with a new film and the target is big tech. Here's a preview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: They can suppress certain types of results based on what they think you should be seeing, based on what your followers are presenting.

PETER FRANZ SCHWEIZER, AMERICAN INVESTIGATIVE JOURNALIST, NOVELIST, AUTHOR, POLITICAL CONSULTANT: It's what Google and Facebook are doing on regular basis by suppressing stories like steering us towards other stories rather than the stories we're actually seeking.

ROBERT EPSTEIN, SENIOR RESEARCH PSYCHOLOGIST, AMERICAN INSTITUTE FOR BEHAVIORAL RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY: It will always favor one online music service over another and one candidate over another.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Google crosses the creepy line every day.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Film comes out September 17th. Peter Schweizer, of course, is the man behind the project. And he joins us tonight. Peter, first, congratulations on this film, remarkably prescient. And I'm sure it'll be as smart as your last project was.

As you did it, you spent all those time looking into this subject, tell us what are (ph) the salient things you learned? What - what blew your mind in researching this?

SCHWEIZER: Well what blew my mind is a couple of things, Tucker. First of all, the dominance that Google has in the marketplace. But second of all, Google is unlike pretty much almost any other company in the world.

What do I mean by that? Sure, they're motivated by profit. They have shareholders. They have owners. But this is a company that in its core is utopian or, at least, the founders have a utopian vision.

They don't view themselves as another company. So, when people say "Oh, Google would never manipulate the algorithm, they would never engage in this kind of behavior because they don't want to hurt their market share," they don't think in those terms.

They make decisions all the time that are based on their vision of what is good and right rather than what consumers want. And with the power they have, combined with this sort of idealism, I think creates the problems that we have today with censorship and with manipulation.

CARLSON: So give us a sense. I mean I think you just got right to the heart of it. They have a vision.

SCHWEIZER: Yes.

CARLSON: Is their vision, would you say, in sync with the views of your average American? What is their vision?

SCHWEIZER: Well I think their vision, you know, certainly is partly epitomized by Burning Man, sort of this festival that they go to. In fact, when they hired Eric Schmidt to be the CEO, you know, 15 or so years ago, one of the reasons they picked him is because he went to Burning Man.

And this is sort of a - a, you know, secularist sort of religious gathering in the Nevada desert. There's a lot of things about traditional values they don't like. There are lot of views about sort of conservative free-market capitalism they don't like.

And they have a vision that they want to be transformative. And that's fine except they want to be transformative to, I think, an American public that isn't interested in being transformed by them.

CARLSON: Right.

SCHWEIZER: And the problem is, Tucker that we don't know what they're doing. We don't know what we don't know. We know the end results. We know that there's provable evidence of manipulation but we don't know how it's being done. That's what makes it, I think, so troubling and difficult to get underneath.

CARLSON: They're not an American company, obviously. They're a multinational company despite the fact Al Gore owns a lot of the stock. Do they see themselves as a company that has an obligation to America, American society, American culture, our economy, or no?

SCHWEIZER: No. No, they don't. They don't. I think they view themselves as a transformative country. And look, you know, when they - they read that statement to say that we don't manipulate the algorithm, you know, for a political benefit I mean that rings hollow, you know.

CARLSON: Yes.

SCHWEIZER: Go back five to 10 years ago, they were charged with manipulating the algorithm for commercial purposes. Luther Lowe was talking about that on the show.

CARLSON: Exactly.

SCHWEIZER: What was Google's position? It was the same absolute denial. The problem is, the European Union, the Federal Trade Commission, scholars at Harvard, and elsewhere have looked at this, and says that Google is lying. So why should we believe them now? The evidence is overwhelming. They're engaging in political manipulation as well.

CARLSON: Of course they are. And our Congress does nothing. Peter Schweizer. Again, the movie comes out September 17th and you just know it's going to be worth watching. Thank you for that.

SCHWEIZER: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Well what would happen if the social media companies started to pick winners and losers in elections? It's not a small question. It could invalidate our democracy instantly. We'll investigate that coming up on this special edition of TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS CHANNEL: Live from America's News Headquarters, I'm Trace Gallagher in Los Angeles. Congress gave John McCain its highest honor today. Members assembled under the Capitol rotunda to pay their final respects to the man known as the maverick.

One by one, Democrats and Republicans paid tribute to his flag-draped casket. Among those attending the service was McCain's mother, Roberta, a 106 years old. House Speaker Paul Ryan called McCain one of the bravest souls our nation has produced. He died last Saturday, four days before his 82nd birthday.

In Detroit, mourners paid an emotional farewell to another American icon, the Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin. Performers at her eight-hour ceremony included Stevie Wonder, Faith Hill, Ariana Grande and Chaka Khan. Former President, Bill Clinton, spoke at the service. Franklin died earlier this month from pancreatic cancer. She was 76 years old.

I'm Trace Gallagher. Now back to Tucker Carlson.

CARLSON: So, here's the central question for all of us who live in this country, how much power do the tech companies have over our democratic elections? American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology Senior Research Psychologist, Robert Epstein, weighed in on that question on this show. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EPSTEIN: We should be extremely concerned because I can tell you the bottom line here is content no longer matters. All that matters is the filtering and ordering of content. And that is completely in the hands of Google and Facebook. I think the problems can be solved at some point. But at the moment, I think, democracy is in trouble.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well that probably woke you up. Dan Bongino is a contributor at NRATV and a frequent guest on this show. He joins us tonight. So Dan, why is this not a much graver threat than Russia? Why is this not a foreign threat from a foreign country to the heart of our democracy?

DANIEL JOHN BONGINO, FORMER AGENT OF THE UNITED STATES SECRET SERVICE, NRATV CONTRIBUTOR: Well - well it is, Tucker. I think that's obvious to rational people but that assumes we're dealing with rational people. We're not. We're dealing with politicians and a media swamp that's interested simply in combating Donald Trump.

And they believe, I believe, wrongly that the Russian narrative works for them. But this targeting of conservative content is very real. Any one on these social media platforms has experienced it.

I've experienced it myself. I actually have the trifecta for you. I was banned from running ads on Twitter for what they cited as inappropriate content, which is odd because all I post is conservative content. That's all I do.

They never explained what the inappropriate content was. On YouTube, our videos for our - our podcast get flagged all the time. They have a little yellow button. And when it turns yellow you can't earn any money on it.

Now, that doesn't happen as often to Liberal friends who might (ph) do the same thing. And on Instagram, we have a tough time getting a blue checkmark despite, you know, 60,000 followers.

So, this is very real. And when it happens to candidates running for office, which we've seen, it's even worse.

CARLSON: But it doesn't even need to happen to candidates to threaten the rest of us because it shuts down part of the conversation and that inevitably is--

BONGINO: Yes.

CARLSON: --got to have an effect on how people vote. If you don't hear ideas, obviously, you can't internalize them. So why isn't that right there a threat to our elections?

BONGINO: No, it is. And - and they want - what they want is they want their, you know, they want to have it both ways. What they want, Tucker, these social media platforms, let's be clear on this, they want the protections of being an open platform. In other words, in plain English, "Hey we're not responsible for what people post. Don't screw (ph) us."

CARLSON: Right, exactly.

BONGINO: But then on the other hand they treat themselves like publishers. They have these - they call them - the new - the new catchphrase is the algorithm, Tucker. That's really a selective process of weeding out conservative content and giving--

CARLSON: Yes.

BONGINO: --favor to liberal content in the new public space. You can't have it both ways guys.

CARLSON: Exactly. An algorithm is editing. That's exact - that's what we used to call it in journalism. Dan Bongino, thank you for that.

BONGINO: OK. Yes, sir (ph).

CARLSON: So impressed (ph) as always. The tech giants are obviously politically biased against conservatives. No one really disputes that. But Exhibit A is special hostility to people with pro-life views. They're hated above all.

Lila Rose would know. She's Founder and President of Live Action that's a pro-life group. And she joins us tonight. Lila Rose, thank you for coming on. Tell us your experience with social media.

LILA ROSE, FOUNDER & PRESIDENT, LIVE ACTION ADVOCATE: Sure. So, Live Action is the large - has a largest following online for the pro-life movement, over 3 million people. Our videos have hundreds of millions of views online.

And for the last three years, we have been totally banned from doing any advertising on Twitter. Meanwhile, Planned Parenthood and other pro- abortion groups are advertising and they're even advertising petitions to further suppress and censor Live Action and other pro-life groups. So, this is what we've been facing now for three years.

CARLSON: Look, and can I (ph) stand three steps back and make an obvious point. If the advocates for abortion really believed it was such a good thing they wouldn't be so hysterically intent on shutting you down or letting another voice in. They - they know they're wrong and that's why they suppress speech.

But let me just ask sort of practical question, how can that be? Do you have any recourse? I mean these are, in effect, public utilities. Is there anything you can do about it?

ROSE: Well we've - we've looked at it. I mean we are - we're ultimately going on other platforms and then making sure that we can reach people directly through our own website and finding other ways to reach people because ultimately Twitter has sided with the abortion industry.

I mean that's what's clear, despite their claims, despite Jack Dorsey, their CEO, going on the news in the last several weeks and saying "Look, we do not discriminate based on viewpoint. That's what we do not do at Twitter," he's flat-out lying. He's lying to people.

And we are, as you say, Exhibit A. Look, the other part of this, like you just said, Tucker, is the fact that when people learn the truth, especially about this human rights issue of abortion, when they learn about what abortion is, what it does to it to the child in the womb, we have an abortion procedure series of videos that have been viewed over a 100 million times.

We survey people and they change their minds on abortion. People are having Aha moments saying "Wait a minute. This is - this is violence against a child. This is harmful to women. We don't want this anymore."

That's what Twitter, I believe, is afraid of because they know when the truth gets out there about the humanity of the child in the womb, about what abortion is, the abortionists lose every time.

CARLSON: Right.

ROSE: And that's why Twitter is so interested in defending abortion interest because that's their ideology despite the lies of their own CEO about them not having a viewpoint.

CARLSON: Yes, the last thing they want is a conversation about it. They want to squelch anything they don't agree with.

ROSE: Exactly.

CARLSON: Lila Rose, thank you. Good to see you.

ROSE: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: If you have an Android phone and you should check then Google is collecting information on you right now whether you know it or not, and you probably don't. If you've got a Google app on your iPhone you could also be exposed to surveillance from Google. Our exclusive investigation into this, the new surveillance state, is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Welcome back to our special tonight on Tech Tyranny because tyranny is what it has become. Google, by far, the biggest corporate threat to the privacy of your personal life, the company recently submitted patent applications that reveal Google's willingness to put cameras in your bedroom and spy on your children, then use that information to sell things.

Currently, Google does not have a camera in every home but it does have a phone in millions of pockets. So, the question is how much information does Google get from those phones, information about you?

FOX News Headlines 24/7 anchor Brett Larson went out to investigate this exclusively for our show. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: We wanted to figure out what exactly Google is learning about us throughout the day. So here's what we're going to do. We have two identical phones.

The only difference between these two phones is this one is in airplane mode. Both of the phones lack a SIM card and they haven't been set up to access any Wi-Fi networks. So for all intents and purposes these phones have no connection to a data network.

We're going to keep them with us throughout the day. And while I travel around D.C., we're going to figure out just what Google is finding out about me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Our first stop, Sim's (ph) Convenience Store just outside our FOX Bureau for a quick coffee. From there, we took a walk to the Capitol and took a quick walk around the Senate office buildings and then decided to hop in a car and head around town.

LARSON: Hello.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey.

LARSON: We're going to the Children's Hospital please.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To run our test we had to do more than walk the block, so we took a tour around our nation's capital. First, due north, to the Children's National Medical Center hospital, then west to St. Albans School, and the National Cathedral. Our tour around town was a 14-mile journey that lasted more than an hour. The entire time the phones had no access to the internet.

LARSON: Oh my goodness.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Not a Wi-Fi connection and not any cellular data service. It almost seemed quaint to assume that Google wouldn't even be able to collect data on me.

LARSON: That's it. Back to the Bureau, my friend.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sure.

LARSON: That church is beautiful.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Google's business model is simple. Collect data on its users and then use that data to sell targeted ads. It's a business model called Surveillance Capitalism. But does that critical data collection work even when your phones aren't connected?

LARSON: So, we're back here at our FOX Bureau in D.C. And we've got both of our phones exactly how we left with them. The only difference really, I snapped a couple of bad selfies at the National Cathedral.

Uh-ho.

But otherwise they have stayed in my pocket for the entire day. So let's find out what they know. This is our man-in-the-middle device. It's basically a Wi-Fi network that these phones are going to connect to once we turn their Wi-Fi on.

It's going to pass data through it on the way to Google. But on the way we're actually going to get a copy of the same data that Google's going to get. We'll be able to decrypt it and then find out where we've been throughout the day.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Within minutes the numbers rolled in. The phone that wasn't on airplane mode registered more than 100 locations, 130 activities, and even a 152 barometric readings. As soon as it hooked up to our Wi-Fi, it transmitted 300 kilobytes of data straight to Google. The phone even logged our exact locations tracking us all around town, the Capitol, the hospital, the school, and the Cathedral.

LARSON: Now, you may notice what's missing here is the exact route that we took but it got that data too. It knows when I got out of the car.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The metadata has a time log down to the very second, tracking everything when they think that you're walking, riding, and yes, even getting out of the car.

LARSON: OK. So, you're thinking "This isn't a big deal. I'll just put my phone in airplane mode." Yes, we thought of that too. This is the other phone that we had with us that no SIM card, also remained in airplane mode the entire time. Let's see what kind of data it captured.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The phone with airplane mode activated actually logged more locations and activities than the other phone. And it also transferred hundreds of kilobytes of data to Google as soon as it was activated.

LARSON: The only thing that's missing from this map is our stop at the Children's Hospital. But it still knows we were there. There it is, exiting vehicle, a 100 percent accuracy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Through complicated user agreements and free software, Google gets users to sign away their privacy for nothing. They're even following you in the places that most people would expect total privacy, government buildings, a children's hospital, a private school, a church, every move you make, every step you take, Google is watching you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: It is a - a scary conclusion to come to if you are using an Android device. Tucker, we should also, we should point out, as - as we mentioned in the piece there, that when you are using Gmail, if you're using Google Drive, any of their services, you're actually not using a - you're not using a product, you are the actual products.

CARLSON: Right.

LARSON: You are what Google is selling to advertisers. And that data that they collect about you is then turned around and sold to advertisers to more - to give you that very specific level of advertising.

CARLSON: I don't think people fully appreciate that. So, I mean this is a remarkable report because it reveals--

LARSON: Right.

CARLSON: --you don't have control of the surveillance.

LARSON: Yes.

CARLSON: They, in effect, lie to you and say that you do but you don't.

LARSON: Right, all the time (ph).

CARLSON: But what about iPhone users?

LARSON: This is an interesting twist here. With iPhone users, Apple is capturing a lot of information about you but they're not using it to sell you advertising. They're using it to better the services that they offer. But if you are using Google applications on your iPhone, it, in many instances, is actually capturing all of that same data.

CARLSON: So, any Google app, so if you have Google Maps, for example--

LARSON: If you're using Google Maps it can take (ph)--

CARLSON: --which I think every living human being with an iPhone does.

LARSON: Yes, you do because Apple Maps, I'm sorry, Apple Maps is as - an inferior product.

CARLSON: Right.

LARSON: But yes, if you are using Google Maps, which most of us are, it is constantly tracking your data. Also, as we learned earlier in the month, if you're using Google Search and said "Stop tracking me" but you're using Google Search on your mobile device, be that on an iPhone or an Android device, they are again capturing your location information.

CARLSON: It's unbelievable. It wouldn't be such a big deal if you could trust the company if they weren't working on behalf of the Fascist Government of China. It might (ph) make us feel better. Brett thank you for that reporting.

LARSON: Yes. Tucker, thanks for having me.

CARLSON: I thought it was groundbreaking.

Well when it's not spying on you, Google is cracking down on ideological dissent within its own ranks just as the former Google Engineer, James Damore, who was fired in the name of inclusion and diversity for writing a memo that called for inclusion and diversity. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Last summer, James Damore learned what happens when you question the groupthink of Silicon Valley. While working for Google as an Engineer, Damore privately circulated a paper he wrote that asked why isn't a company so committed to diversity more ideologically diverse?

He didn't attack anyone. He just questioned the internal logic of what he was being told. For that, the company fired him and then attacked him and tried to prevent him from working anywhere else. They tried to destroy his life.

Damore came on this show, a safe space for dissent, to discuss what happened to him.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: What did they say to you when they canned you? They - when they called you in, how did the conversation go? What was the justification for ending your career at Google?

JAMES DAMORE, FORMER GOOGLE ENGINEER: So, the official justification was perpetuating gender stereotypes.

CARLSON: Of all places, you wouldn't think Google would have a culture where emotional outrage drives decision-making. I mean I thought the whole point of Google was they're rational but they don't sound rational at all

DAMORE: Yes, there's certain dogmas that you really can't dissent against at Google and one of them being that there's any difference between people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: The Orwellian future is increasingly the Orwellian present. Tech barons are our new commissars. Liberals, who for generations, stood up for free expression and an opposition to corporate power have been so thoroughly co-opted they're now against speech and for Google. Why? Because they're getting rich from it.

Harmeet Dhillon is a lawyer who represents James Damore. And she joins us tonight. Harmeet, thanks very much for coming on. We followed the saga since the very beginning. I know obviously you've been intricately involved from the very beginning. Google, when last we checked with you, was basically trying to destroy his life for this memo. Is that still the case?

HARMEET DHILLON, AMERICAN LAWYER, REPUBLICAN PARTY OFFICIAL: Well they have certainly attempted to destroy his career. They started out after firing him by smearing him in the international media and then, you know, continuing this narrative and - and hunting down people in the company who had supported him internally as well. So, full-blown purge going on there at Google.

They also, we believe, helped interfere with James' job search. A prominent company in Silicon Valley called Hire.com that helps people at the high tech industry find jobs mysteriously, you know, suddenly dis - disappeared James from its website within one day and has, you know, belligerently told us that, you know, they can pick and choose who they help, which is actually not California law. You cannot do that.

So, you know, we feel like there's a coordinated effort to make sure that not just James but people who espouse those types of views are hounded out of employment in Silicon Valley, and it's really scary.

CARLSON: Has he not found a job?

DHILLON: He is employed, you know, because of the fact that - recently by the way, but because of the fact that, you know, people are being harassed for supporting him, he's, you know, keeping the location of his workplace confidential.

CARLSON: That's - that's - it's unbelievable. And by the way, for our viewers who may not be fully read into this story if you think that we're putting a thumb on the scale, go read his memo. It's available online and see if there's anything, even one sentence in it that is offensive. No, there isn't. It's the whole thing is bewildering.

DHILLON: Yes.

CARLSON: Are there - is there any movement within Google to diversify? Is there any dissent within Google? Is there anyone who agrees with James who can speak out or has?

DHILLON: Well, those people who agreed with James are leaving the company voluntarily or involuntarily one by one, so it's hard to find out. And what Google has done, as reported in the media, it is in the wake of the whole controversy with James has actually tried to revamp its internal message board policies to, you know, appoint employees of the company to be basically narcs to spy on each other and then report back to - back to the management.

And, you know, I - I wouldn't have thought a year ago if you told me this was happening in an American company that it would be true.

But I guess it kind of fits with Google's new move into China where, of course, and you know, China, they assign social media scores or media scores or, you know, scores to people that loud that then follow them throughout their lives, so, you know, the government can control where you - whether you get to travel and all of that based on this information.

And in Silicon Valley, it's almost the same thing. If you're assigned a socially undesirable label by big media or big tech then all of a sudden you are now out. You're persona non grata.

CARLSON: So, this is the company who's trying to destroy a young man's life because it didn't agree with a memo he wrote. This is the company we trust to hold all human information and sort it for us?

DHILLON: I mean I don't trust it anymore. A lot of people use, you know, their services. But I think people should be very careful. And again, you know, not to, you know, sort of bring in this other issue but when - when they have all this information about you and they're openly agreeing to censorship in foreign countries at the demand of foreign countries, how long is it before you can expect to see that more openly done here? We - we know--

CARLSON: It's exactly right.

DHILLON: --it already happens here with search results and so forth but, you know, in - in a couple of years when they're doing business in China, are you going to be able to search for the Dalai Lama in America and get accurate search results?

I think that's a huge question that we should be asking and the government should be asking that because, you know, these companies all operate with tremendous market power and they meet regularly. Just, I think, last week--

CARLSON: Yes.

DHILLON: There was a meeting of the top tech companies to talk about election interference and, you know, what does that really mean and are they--

CARLSON: That's a great question.

DHILLON: --operating as a cartel (ph) in certain ways?

CARLSON: Of course they are.

DHILLON: Sure (ph).

CARLSON: And Congress should act immediately. But they're too afraid. Harmeet Dhillon, thank you for this. Good to see you.

DHILLON: My pleasure.

CARLSON: So once you decide that it's OK to censor opinions you disagree with, where does that wind up? That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Well, the tech giants see themselves as gatekeepers of the internet and, as such, routinely engage in censorship of political speech, speech they disagree with. In most cases, that affects conservatives.

But non-mainstream liberals have been targeted too, especially those who express opposition to the democratic establishment or to endless war. What are the boundaries of censorship once a company starts making decisions about what speech is permissible and which speech is not?

Jesse Kelly is a Marine Corps combat veteran who has fought for free speech abroad. He is the host of the Jesse Kelly Radio Show in Houston and he joins us tonight. Jesse, thank you very much for coming on.

So, you wrote this piece that I thought was really compelling about Alex Jones. And you said "Look, I don't agree with Alex Jones, his views but that's not the point." The point, as you articulated, was if you can silence this guy because you don't like what he says why can't they silence you or me?

JESSE KELLY, UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS COMBAT VETERAN: That's - that is the point, Tucker. And they're coming for you and me next.

Alex Jones was the weak member of the herd because of his insane views on certain things. They knew they could pick him off, and what he was, was a test-run. If we can pick off this nutjob then maybe sooner or later we can come for the more mainstream voices on the right.

This is not - the social media, Facebook, Twitter, that's 2.5 billion people they reach. People have to understand it's no longer a couple of nerds sitting in a college dorm room swapping stories about a made-up girlfriend. It's real and it's powerful.

CARLSON: So, I watched feeling nauseous as almost no figures on that as you just said mainstream right rose to the defense of Alex Jones, not defending what he said but defending his right to say it, the most basic American principle. Why did they sit silently as this happened?

KELLY: Because everybody wants to be the one that's eaten last, Tucker. They convince themselves--

CARLSON: Yes, exactly.

KELLY: --in the interest of never having to have a fight that if the lion will just gorge himself on enough of those antelope eventually he'll never come eat me. But that's not how it works. It is - it is we're really whistling past the graveyard.

We gave them Hollywood. We gave them the education system. And to rely on Google Now or Facebook for your news is like pouring a cup of coffee and then filtering it through a jockstrap before you drink it.

CARLSON: Which doesn't work, I've checked. Yes, I mean social media very quickly really is the last place where dissent is allowed. It's not allowed in the workplace. It's not allowed in public parks. If they take that away people with different views are silenced, correct?

KELLY: It is - it is - correct. It is the final frontier. It's no longer just a random thing. It is how you break news. It's how you make news.

CARLSON: Yes.

KELLY: Social media makes careers. It's - it's how things are done. It's what's used by law enforcement to track people. It is the information age and if we--

CARLSON: That's exactly right.

KELLY: --let Left to censor that that's modern book-burning is what that is.

CARLSON: Jesse Kelly, so nicely put. God bless you for standing up for speech especially against the backdrop of all the cowardice around us. It's distressing. Thank you.

KELLY: Appreciate you.

CARLSON: That's it for the special edition of TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT, investigation into big tech topic. We're going to keep up with every night at 8:00, so join us there. We'll see you.
