urn:contentItem:5X9B-VJ71-JB20-G0JF-00000-00Mulvaney's Comments; G-7 Summit Controversy; Biz of Subscription Boxes; Trump talks Cease-Fire in Syria; China's Slowdown; Parliament to Vote on Brexit Tomorrow; Tariffs on European Goods2019-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, John Lonski, Craig Erlam, Christopher Bedford, Riki Meris-Koulouroudis, Effie SakellisNEWSFinancial101801cb.231Mulvaney's Comments; G-7 Summit Controversy; Biz of Subscription Boxes; Trump talks Cease-Fire in Syria; China's Slowdown; Parliament to Vote on Brexit Tomorrow; Tariffs on European GoodsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Ashley Webster

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning.

We've got a big show this morning.

Joining the conversation, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, Moody's Capital Markets chief economist John Lonski, and "The Wall Street Journal's" editorial page assistant editor James Freeman.

Great to see you guys this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here. Thanks, Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Happy Friday, everybody.

We've got a big story this morning in terms of Syria.

A potential ceasefire in Syria in doubt. Turkey agreed to a five-day suspension of military activities in northern Syria, but that deal is now being questioned this morning after reports of fighting in a Syrian-Turkish border town. President Trump weighed in on this last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've all agreed on a pause or a ceasefire in the border region of Syria. And it was unconventional what I did.

So now we're doing a -- during a five-day period, we're going to see if we can get it all finalized. And I think it will be. I think it will be. So Turkey's going to be happy. The Kurds are going to be happy. ISIS is going to be unhappy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, a lot of pushback on this move.

James, your reaction?

FREEMAN: Yes, I think -- obviously it doesn't seem to have held very long. Maybe the peace will be restored. But there was kind of a problem where the Turks wanted more in terms of weapons and the -- and Kurdish positions being moved further away from their border than seemed like was part of announced agreement.

This is really -- we're seeing the difficulty of the president trying to fulfill that 2016 promise to extricate the U.S. from some of the foreign interventions that he opposed. He really stood out in terms of challenging Republican orthodoxy on that. And you're now seeing, not just Republicans, Democrats, really bipartisan pushback on this.

BARTIROMO: It's true. In fact, last night I was at the Al Smith Dinner and James Mattis -- General Mattis was the speaker. And I saw him as he approaches the dinner and I talked to him a bit about this and he said, this is why I left 10 months ago. This has been talked about that long in terms of the president wanting to do this. And this is exactly why General Mattis said he could not say because the president was adamant about taking the troops out of Syria.

MCDOWELL: And the -- one of the issues that I brought up here is that it was abrupt, this phone call, and it was, again, based on Jennifer Griffin's reporting, that the president went off script and didn't say to Erdogan initially in that Sunday night phone call, I think it was October the sixth, what was -- say stay north of the border or -- and if Erdogan said, well, I'm coming into northern Syria, then, well, we will give the Kurds air cover.

So this was abrupt move out of northern Syria and a betrayal of our Kurdish allies. And to James' point, and his editorial page has a great piece on it today, the Republicans, not just the Democrats, but the Republicans are pushing back against this move by the president with a 354-60 vote to oppose the move. That was in the House. And the sanctions that Lindsey Graham introduced in the Senate yesterday are a great deal tougher than what President Trump even proposed. "The journal" calls it, makes President Trump sanctions look like a love tap.

So this is -- these are Republicans who are standing against the president's foreign policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I will say this. There's a Rasmussen poll that says that the majority of likely voters tend to agree with President Trump. And they say that the U.S. is too involved in middle east conflicts, a plurality of 37 percent say so. Less than 20 percent said that the U.S. should be more involved.

So I don't -- I don't think this becomes an issue for the election because I don't think most Americans understand what's happening in terms of ISIS perhaps getting back in business. I mean we'll see how bad things get. But certainly he's facing a fair amount of pushback on both sides of the aisle.

MCDOWELL: But in -- but in terms of troops coming home, I think it was just about three or four days ago that the president said those troops that are being moved aren't coming home and we are sending an additional 1,800 troops to Saudi Arabia. So in terms of getting out of the Middle East, that's just not happening.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, that is true. He said he's going to be sending help to Saudi Arabia.

Want to look at futures this morning because, once again, markets are following this bouncing ball of what happens out of the trade deal with China. Sluggish economic growth came out of China overnight. The country's third quarter GDP was the slowest in more than 25 years. President Trump commented on the tariffs and the potential trade deal last night at that rally.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Hopefully the agreement gets signed sometime prior to a big summit that we have with President Xi and others in Chile. So that's in about four weeks.

In the meantime, we've taken in tens of billions of dollars of tariffs and China's eaten the cost because they devalued their currency and they're putting money out. Tens of billions of dollars. It's cost us nothing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see about that. We've got tariffs that are going to go into effect in the Eurozone this weekend.

What's your reaction in terms of the China story, John?

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S CAPITAL MARKETS: Well, you know, China's economy now growing at the slowest pace since 1992. I mean, if China is going to take a policy action to try to rejuvenate its economy, the best policy action is to get a trade deal done as soon as possible.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LONSKI: Forget about fiscal stimulus, monetary stimulus. Focus on trade. And I think both parties have to realize, and they have to perhaps sunder some of their pride, some of their egos in order to get this issue out of the way.

BARTIROMO: Now, earlier this week Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said that there was a mechanism in place to insure that the intellectual property is not stolen. We'll see. We're going to speak to Peter Navarro coming up. I don't know how hard those rules or mechanisms to enforce it are within this -- within this deal, but we'll hear what Navarro has to say.

Your reaction?

FREEMAN: Yes, well, it is a question of how much pain is enough to motivate a communist regime, which does not want to compromise on these issues, to finally get a deal. And this is -- yes the worst economy they've had in decades. But we'll see whether it's enough to change their behavior.

MCDOWELL: What's hard to quantify, though, is -- and just -- when you talk to people, as you do all day long every day behind the scenes, people in the technology industry, for example, will tell you that President Trump now gives them the strength to push back. So it's not just the U.S. government, it is also every CEO who's been spied on by China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Every CEO who has had their intellectual property stolen, or the company's intellectual property stolen because, well, China could get away with it.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: Every CEO whose wanted to do business in China but basically hand -- had to hand over the keys to the business in order to do that. So it's not just the president, it is literally behind the scenes CEO's, technology and other industries pushing back or moving their manufacturing out of China. And China knows once -- as the president has said, once that supply chain moves it ain't coming back.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and they're not going back. And, yes, I've said many times, I feel like this president changed the conversation on China. And it was a really important move that he made.

I want to turn to the draft Brexit deal as well that was struck between the U.K. and the EU yesterday. The agreement still has to be ratified. We're expecting that tomorrow from parliament from the U.K.

Ashley Webster is live this morning in London with more on that.

Ashley, good morning to you.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning to you, Maria.

Well, this new deal from Boris Johnson agreed with the EU is essentially Theresa May's plan, but it has removed the Irish backstop that lawmakers were worried would keep northern Ireland within the EU for many years. So Boris Johnson did something the EU said it wouldn't do and got them to eliminate that backstop.

But the question is, is it enough to get it through parliament? Boris Johnson needs 320 votes tomorrow. There are 287 conservatives. If you assume they all vote for it, he still has to find 33 votes from somewhere else. So right now, as we speak, he's on a charm offensive, trying to persuade lawmakers it is time to get this thing done.

In fact, yesterday in Brussels, when this deal was announced, he said, look, it's time to get Brexit done. It's time to come together. Time to move on. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BORIS JOHNSON, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: This is a great deal for our country, for the U.K. I also believe it's a very good deal for our friends in the EU.

I'm very confident that when my colleagues in parliament study this agreement, that they will want to vote for it.

It's been long, it's been painful, it's been divisive. And now is the moment for us, as a country, to come together.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: Well, now is the time for the country. It has been long. It has been painful and extremely divisive. The question is, can he get it over the line? This is only the fourth time, by the way, since the start of World War II that parliament has actually sat in session on a Saturday.

If they vote it down, Boris Johnson is required to ask for an extension from the October 31st deadline. He says if there's a deal, great. If there's no deal, the U.K. will still leave on October the 31st. No one can quite figure that out. Maybe Boris has something up his sleeve.

We'll wait and see, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Ashley, what about Nigel Farage's pushback yesterday? He basically said that there are still too many things that bind the EU and the U.K. within this deal.

WEBSTER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Nigel Farage's pushback?

WEBSTER: Well, I mean, if you're a pure Brexiteer (ph), as Nigel Farage is, and there are many others, they do say that this keeps the U.K. far to tied to the EU in other ways. What they really want is a clean break. A, thank you very much, good-bye, we'll figure it out on ourselves. We'll be able to do free trade agreements. A big one could be done with the United States. And he says this deal just is not enough. This is not in the spirit of what people voted for three and a half years ago.

BARTIROMO: All right, Ashley, we'll be watching. Thanks so much.

Ashley Webster on the ground this morning in London.

We are just getting started this morning.

Also on deck, "The Daily Caller" editor-in-chief Christopher Bedford with us this morning on the impeachment inquiry, what happens now that Carolyn Maloney will take over for Elijah Cummings? Hermitage Capital CEO Bill Browder is here on the Brexit deal. Assistant to the president for trade for manufacturing policy, Peter Navarro joining us on China trade. And the co-founders of Warby Parker in the house, Neil Blumenthal and David Gilboa are here to talk frame fitting and augment -- with augmented reality, as well as going public. We'll talk about all that coming up.

First, though, the vaping crisis. Juul suspending online sales amid reports of even more illnesses being linked to e-cigarettes.

Then, history in space. NASA trying again to get its all-female spacewalk in the books.

We're back right after this short break.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Two sheriff's deputy shot in Iowa.

Cheryl Casone with headlines right now.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Maria, good morning.

These deputies were shot while trying to serve a search warrant early this morning in Stewart, Iowa. At least one suspect taken into custody following a standoff. The deputies had to be air-lifted to a local hospital, but they are said to be, luckily, in stable condition.

Well, Juul is now haunting online -- halting, excuse me, online sales of all flavored e-cigarettes, except for tobacco, mint and menthol. The company pulled those flavors from retail stories last year. Juul is under scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers over its marketing practice as the teen vaping rate continues to rise. And, of course, we reported on those deaths across the country.

Well, history taking place in outer space. Today astronauts Jessica Meir and Christina Koch, yes, the ladies are going to be stepping out of the International Space Station for the first all-female spacewalk in NASA's 61-year history. The pair is going to replace, Maria, a faulty battery charge discharge unit. And we're going to be rooting for them right here in New York City.

BARTIROMO: We sure are.

CASONE: I love it.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: All right, we want to take a short break.

When we come back, Brexit is on the line. The newly reached deal hangs in the balance this morning as parliament gets ready to vote on it tomorrow. How it's moving markets coming up next.

And then NBA backlash. China reportedly going after Daryl Morey for his pro-Hong Kong tweet. Now the league is really feeling the heat. We've got all the details on that. Wait till you hear this one.

Stay with us

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

There is Brexit drama playing out overseas. The draft Brexit deal drafted between British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the EU now has to get the go ahead from parliament. That's expected to happen -- well, it could be difficult, but the vote is happening this Saturday, tomorrow. The Democratic Unionist Party is opposing the deal. The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbin, says it's even worse than the one negotiated by former Prime Minister Theresa May. Things are expected to heat up in parliament tomorrow during a super Saturday vote, as you heard from Ashley in London.

John, is this going to take away some uncertainty for these markets or we're still sort of in that holding patter?

LONSKI: Well, it would be -- obviously it's going to be of more help to the U.K. and the EU than for the United States. It really hasn't been on the radar when you're looking at the performance of U.S. financial markets.

BARTIROMO: OK, because I know that it is an uncertainty there for managers and CEO's who have businesses in the U.K. --

LONSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And weren't sure if they should move people in Germany, move people elsewhere in the EU.

LONSKI: Yes, listen, I -- we do have many U.S. financial service and banks that have big operations in U.K. and perhaps other companies and this may be entering into their planning, where they're going to be locating people, whether it be on the continent or do they stay in England.

FREEMAN: Yes, obviously, Boris Johnson has to get the votes. So that's a big maybe.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: I'm not going to make a prediction. But if he can work it out to where they have zero tariffs with the EU, and then he can do a deal with the U.S. where they have a better tariff deal than the rest of the EU with the United States, this could be pretty groovy for the U.K. economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: And, obviously, you've talked about people considering moving, but they -- financial services companies, all companies love that British legal system.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: They love contracts being enforced in London courts. So I -- I would be very blush about the U.K. going forward if this --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: Especially if this vote goes through.

BARTIROMO: And especially if the U.K. does a deal, like almost immediately, with the U.S.

Meanwhile, we were talking about tariffs. Tariffs go into effect on about $7.5 billion in goods from Europe. That includes wine, cheese, whiskey, olive oil. The World Trade Organization authorized measures against the EU due to decades of illegal subsidies to Airbus. A big win for the Trump administration when they were able to put these -- these tariffs into effect, which happened today.

Any impact? What do you think?

FREEMAN: Well, I -- I mean this is just more cost. So you -- you can't -- you can't argue with the method in this case. Obviously this is not a unilateral play. This was a WTO decision. But I would hope this is motivation to get a lower tariff's deal across the board with the EU.

BARTIROMO: We'll see.

MCDOWELL: And see if there's any retaliation coming from Europe down the road. That would -- that would, again, have to go back to the WTO. But that's been the problem for -- with the initial fight because of the steel tariffs. You had the retaliation and that hurt like everybody from Jack Daniel's to Harley Davidson.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that right now and bring in Craig Erlam, market analyst from Oanda, senior market analyst from Oanda.

Craig, good to see you. Thanks so much for being here.

CRAIG ERLAM, SENIOR MARKET ANALYST, OANDA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: What do you expect in terms of the Brexit situation and -- and its impact on markets and the U.K. economy?

ERLAM: Well, we've already seen a very positive impact on the markets, really building up over the last week, ever since Boris' meeting with Leo Varca (ph) in the northwest of England a week ago. The idea that we were on a pathway towards a possible deal got people excited and that really carried through into the end of this week when the deal was actually announced.

The next hurdle, of course, is parliament on Saturday. Are they going to approve the deal? My gut says no. I feel like the extension is probably still the most out -- likely scenario at this point an election and then I think the deal gets through later on this year.

BARTIROMO: So do you think markets trade down on Monday if you -- if they get a no-vote tomorrow? I mean will there be a real market reaction?

ERLAM: I think they maybe will come off a little bit. We already saw it come off a little bit yesterday when the DUP confirmed that they wouldn't back the deal. So that made the arithmetic really difficult in parliament. And we saw the pound pull off a little bit. Now maybe a little bit of profit taking following a week of very substantial gains. So we may see it pull off a little bit, but I don't think it necessarily alters the longer term -- the longer term goal, which is to get this Brexit deal over the line.

And, of course, we've got to remember as well that an election doesn't' just give -- potentially give Boris the numbers in parliament for a deal. If Boris, with the conservatives and the Brexit party as well don't get a majority between them, then all of a sudden you've got this -- a situation whereby the opposition parties could have a majority between them, that we see another coalition government and all of a sudden remain (ph) becomes a possibility because the second referendum impact as well. urn:contentItem:5Y72-6JD1-F021-60RV-00000-00MUM'S PLEA Heartbroken mum whose daughter, 13, took her own life tells Boris Johnson to jail tech bosses who fail to protect kids2020-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:02ZLexisNexisNEWS,UK NEWS,FACEBOOK,INSTAGRAM,SNAPCHATVersion:2MUM'S PLEA Heartbroken mum whose daughter, 13, took her own life tells Boris Johnson to jail tech bosses who fail to protect kidsGraeme Culliford

A HEARTBROKEN mum sends a hard-hitting message to the Prime Minister over social media regulation, saying: "It is time to put our children before your friends in big tech."

Ruth Moss agonisingly lost her daughter six years ago when Sophie Parkinson, 13, took her own life after viewing suicide "guides" online.

Now Ruth is demanding social media bosses go to prison if they have inappropriate material on their sites, from images of self-harm to child abuse.

She said: "Executives should be held criminally accountable. If child abuse is found on their websites, they should be facing jail.

"They should be doing everything they can to bring these things down."

Last year Ruth met with Facebook exec Nick Clegg, who promised to rid the site of harmful material.

But Ruth, 48, was appalled to learn this week that while Ofcom will finally regulate social media companies, it might not be given the power to prosecute execs whose firms fall short.

Speaking exclusively to The Sun on Sunday, Ruth said: "Boris Johnson needs to show some backbone on this.

"He needs to show he has morals and cares about issues such as children being groomed by paedophiles on social media.

"How would he feel if his child had become a victim? What would his view be then?

"We all want a strong economy but not at the expense of our children.

'GOOD COMPANIES DON'T FEAR REGULATION'

"Good companies have nothing to fear from regulation.

"We should not give in to idle threats that they will go somewhere else if we hold them to account.

"The UK is a huge market for these companies.

"There is no reason why we should allow big tech firms to come in and do whatever they want.

"That's why we have laws - to protect the public."

Images of self-harm are not the only concern.

Experts say one in 20 kids have been sent a semi-naked pic online by an adult.

Of those, 70 per cent were contacted on Instagram, Snapchat or Facebook.

NSPCC chief executive Peter Wanless said: "News on Wednesday that Ofcom would be the country's first internet watchdog, ahead of promised new online harms laws, is a huge step forward.

"New laws need to be top of the in-tray for new Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden. Ofcom needs teeth. It needs the power to hit firms with hefty fines.

"Tech bosses need to be hauled from the boardroom into the courts if they fall foul of the rules."

Ruth, a research nurse from Edinburgh, added: "I fear these companies will be given nothing more than a slap on the wrist and will continue to do whatever they like. We're not just talking about 'offensive' material.

"We're talking about things related to child exploitation and human trafficking. We are talking about child-abuse images. This stuff is illegal in every other domain, so why not on social media?

"If you saw child abuse on TV, that station would be shut down. But the Government seems willing to let tech firms get away with it.

"It is still too easy to access illegal content. Now is the time for Boris Johnson to stand up, be strong and show what it means to be a leader - for everyone, not just the few."

YOU'RE NOT ALONE

EVERY 90 minutes in the UK a life is lost to suicide.

It doesn't discriminate, touching the lives of people in every corner of society - from the homeless and unemployed to builders and doctors, reality stars and footballers.

It's the biggest killer of people under the age of 35, more deadly than cancer and car crashes.

And men are three times more likely to take their own life than women.

Yet it's rarely spoken of, a taboo that threatens to continue its deadly rampage unless we all stop and take notice, now.

That is why The Sun launched the You're Not Alone campaign.

The aim is that by sharing practical advice, raising awareness and breaking down the barriers people face when talking about their mental health, we can all do our bit to help save lives.

Let's all vow to ask for help when we need it, and listen out for others... You're Not Alone.

If you, or anyone you know, needs help dealing with mental health problems, the following organisations provide support:

CALM, www.thecalmzone.net, 0800 585 858

Heads Together, www.headstogether.org.uk

Mind, www.mind.org.uk, 0300 123 3393

Papyrus, www.papyrus-uk.org, 0800 068 41 41

Samaritans, www.samaritans.org, 116 123
